summary: Paul Merson criticized Andros Townsend's England squad call-up in a Sky Sports column, stating Townsend's inclusion "opens it up to anybody." After Townsend came on as a substitute in Tottenham's 0-0 draw with Burnley (with only seven minutes remaining), Merson mocked him on Twitter. Townsend later scored for England in a 1-1 friendly against Italy, proving Merson wrong. Merson admitted he was incorrect but still made another Twitter dig after the Burnley match, to which Townsend replied, "Not bad for a player that should be 'nowhere near the squad'."

Chelsea has made a formal offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, who has played for FC Tokyo since 2013. Muto, with 37 appearances, 16 goals for FC Tokyo, and 11 international caps for Japan (1 goal), would join Chelsea's Dutch partner Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season if the move to Stamford Bridge is completed. The offer is unrelated to Chelsea's £200m sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber. Muto, who recently graduated with an economics degree from Keio University, has not decided to join Chelsea despite finding the offer an honour. A £4m deal has been mooted. Muto has scored three goals in four games this season for FC Tokyo.

Babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight or obese as toddlers, according to a study of over 12,000 children. The Finnish researchers found that antibiotic use before age two, particularly repeated prescriptions, was associated with increased body mass in healthy children, with boys showing higher risk. The study suggests antibiotics may contribute to the childhood obesity epidemic by altering gut bacteria, though causation was not proven. By age two, 1 in 5 boys and 1 in 10 girls were overweight or obese, and the researchers emphasized the importance of judicious antibiotic use in infancy.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony, falling and dropping his rifle while being filmed by tourist David Meadwell. The embarrassed soldier quickly scrambled to his feet as colleagues marched past, with the incident witnessed by hundreds of tourists. The slip was reportedly caused by metal protectors on his boots.

A&E, Lifetime and History networks will simulcast a 2016 remake of the "Roots" miniseries, originally airing in 1977 with over 100 million viewers. The remake, described as "original" and "contemporary," will draw more from Alex Haley's novel and consult historians for authenticity. LeVar Burton, who portrayed Kunta Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce it. The networks aim to bring the saga to both original fans and a new generation of viewers.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, claims palace staff at Clarence House attempted to force him into an orgy in January 1978 when he was 27. He stated he was pinned to a chair, groped, and subjected to a sexual assault after entering a bedroom to find a pen. Lawler left his job immediately, made a complaint met with anger, and was threatened to stay quiet. His complaint was ignored for months before being passed to police last year following inquiries into historical child abuse. Police are now investigating. A retired royal aide denied involvement, stating he was working at Balmoral at the time. The Palace stated it would co-operate with the police probe.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy through a rap video set to the theme song from '90s sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air', which has garnered over 1.7 million YouTube views. The video, made to inform distant family, includes lyrics about family pressure regarding parenthood and Melissa's pregnancy test moment, ending with a shared sonogram. The couple stated the video's success was unexpected.

A Vivien Leigh dress worn as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film *Gone With the Wind* sold for $137,000 at Heritage Auctions. The gray jacket and skirt ensemble, featuring a black zigzag applique, was worn in key scenes including Scarlett meeting Rhett Butler and the shanty town attack. Originally slate blue-gray, it faded to light gray over time. The dress was part of James Tumblin's private collection, acquired for $20 when it was nearly discarded. Tumblin, who collected over 300,000 film memorabilia pieces since the 1960s, preserved it. Other top auction items included a $52,500 hat worn by Leigh and a $55,000 suit worn by Clark Gable as Rhett Butler.

A two-year-old boy fell 10-12ft into a cheetah exhibit at Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the railing. He was rescued by his parents before emergency services arrived, suffering minor bumps and bruises but no animal attacks. The zoo's executive director confirmed the child was dangled and stated the boy was in stable condition at the hospital. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family, and the exhibit was closed following the incident.

A speed camera was repositioned to point at a house in Handsworth, Birmingham, after being non-functional for over two years since all fixed cameras were decommissioned across the West Midlands in March 2013 due to obsolete technology. Around 300 fixed cameras were turned off, replaced by mobile units and patrols. Birmingham City Council is aware of the camera's position, will send an engineer to assess it, and may remove it. The council confirmed no plans to include this camera in a new digital pilot program.

Usain Bolt will compete for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3, confirming he is "fit, healthy and ready to run." He stated he aims to "make the country proud" as part of Jamaica's relay tradition, with the JAAA expressing excitement about his participation. The full Jamaican team list will be announced shortly.

Neymar and Dani Alves supported Barcelona's basketball team by attending their Euro League match against Real Madrid, which Barcelona won 85-80. Real Madrid remains top of the Euro League division by points difference. Neymar also helped Brazil beat Chile 1-0 in a football match, enduring brutal challenges. Before the international break, Barcelona had won El Clasico to lead La Liga by four points. They return to La Liga to face Celta Vigo while competing for a treble.

Italy is experiencing a rising number of migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe, with 8,480 rescued by the Italian coast guard from Friday to Monday. On Monday alone, 20 boats sent SOS calls. Save the Children reported 400 migrants missing after a 550-person boat capsized near Libya, but the coast guard stated it found no evidence of the incident and 145 were rescued. The International Organization for Migration reported over 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy in the first three months of 2015, with about 2,000 rescued at sea in early April. Most migrants come from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit point. At least 480 migrants have died crossing the Mediterranean this year, often due to bad weather, overcrowded vessels, and abandonment by crews.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger states he does not know why Alexis Sanchez chose Arsenal over Liverpool but is glad he joined the club. Sanchez, who scored 19 goals this season, was courted by elite clubs after Barcelona allowed him to leave, and Wenger believes Liverpool's interest may have related to negotiations over Luis Suarez's transfer. Wenger also downplayed speculation about signing Liverpool's Raheem Sterling.

Sir Bradley Wiggins will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The 35-year-old four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner aims to surpass the current record of 52.491km set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February. Wiggins describes the hour record as a "holy grail" for cyclists and will race in front of a capacity crowd with tickets on sale from April 19. His attempt follows his finish at Paris-Roubaix and precedes his preparation for the Rio 2016 Olympics, where he targets a British record eighth Olympic medal.

Serena Williams defeated Sara Errani 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3 in the Fed Cup play-off but called it an "eye-opener" as she was unprepared for clay court, stating she played like it was hard court. The US team lost 3-2 overall, including a doubles defeat (6-0 6-3) by Williams and Alison Riske, relegating them to World Group II. Williams, despite winning her 19th singles grand slam at the Australian Open, noted the French Open has been her least successful major despite two titles. US captain Mary Joe Fernandez emphasized the need to work harder to return to the World Group.

River Plate are interested in signing Radamel Falcao, who previously played for them from age 15 to 2009, scoring 34 goals in 90 appearances across four seasons. Vice president Matias Patanian stated the club "dream of Falcao" and "the doors are open." Falcao is currently on loan at Manchester United, where he has scored only four Premier League goals this season, and it is unclear if United will keep him or if he will return to Monaco. Falcao recently equalled Colombia's all-time goalscoring record with 24 goals, scoring three times in two international matches.

Ella Henderson, a 19-year-old X Factor finalist and pop star, has become the official face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The partnership, arranged by the MILES agency, features campaign images showcasing her hairstyles against a city background. Henderson, who uses Batiste regularly, is featured in a TV ad for the campaign with her single "Mirror Man." Her manager described the collaboration as a natural fit between the artist and the UK's number 1 dry shampoo brand.

Family and friends of Aaron Siler, 26, who was fatally shot by Kenosha police officer Pablo Torres on March 14 after being confronted during a vehicle and foot pursuit while wanted on a felony warrant, are in shock over a billboard erected by the Kenosha Professional Police Association. The billboard features Torres and his dog with the message "Thank you for your support, Kenosha." Siler's family and friends call it "disrespectful," stating it felt like "thank you for killing Aaron." The police association claims the billboard was meant to thank the community for support following recent incidents, including Torres's shooting of Terry Knight 10 days earlier, which was deemed justified. Torres is on leave pending investigation into Siler's death, while the investigation into Knight's shooting concluded it was justified.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Pakistan border in southeastern Iran's Negur town, with three militants also killed by Iranian forces. The militant group Jaish al Adal, an anti-Iranian Sunni group targeting Shiites to reduce Iranian influence in Pakistan, claimed responsibility. The group, active in Balochistan, has previously claimed attacks including a 2013 incident killing 14 Iranian border guards. Iranian officials requested Pakistan apprehend surviving assailants, while Pakistan condemned the attack, stated security agencies are investigating, and promised to apprehend militants who fled to Pakistan.

Japan's Defense Minister Gen Nakatani stated the Air Self Defense Force has never encountered extraterrestrial unidentified flying objects, responding to a query from politician Antonio Inoki. Inoki, a former wrestler and lawmaker, asked if aircraft were scrambled for extraterrestrial threats and claimed to have seen a UFO himself, though he admitted not knowing if aliens exist. The exchange follows a 2007 discussion by another defense minister about legal implications of defending against an alien invasion under Japan's pacifist constitution.

Passenger Jin Pai, 35, was hospitalized with deep cuts to his leg and buttocks after a toilet he was standing on collapsed at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in Hefei, Anhui Province, China. He had stood on the toilet rim due to concerns about seat cleanliness, causing it to shatter. He called companions for help but was too embarrassed to shout, leading to hospitalization for multiple stitches. He later changed his story from squatting to sitting to avoid compensation, but authorities deemed it an accident and warned toilets are for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested on charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy after a 15-year-old girl discovered a hidden camera in her bathroom. Investigators found 41 videos recorded over a three- or four-year period, including 34 showing the victim and others showering, which Rebbie had filmed while the girl was undressing or asleep from age nine to thirteen. He admitted to filming multiple victims but purchased the camera specifically to record the now-15-year-old. Rebbie faces a preliminary hearing on May 1 and is held on $500,000 bail.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama's series "Daughter and Salary Man" features daughters standing po-faced and smiling while their fathers leap energetically into the air, dressed in sharp suits against Japanese landmarks. The fathers' expressions sometimes appear pained despite the energetic poses, contrasting with the daughters' casual clothing. The images aim to let fathers express a fun side, described as "a hero jumping the sky," and have generated significant online interest for their curious concept.

Paul Downton's dismissal as England's managing director has created an opportunity for Kevin Pietersen to potentially return to the England team after being controversially axed in 2014. Pietersen has rejoined Surrey for the County Championship season, aiming to force his way back into the Test set-up ahead of England's home Ashes series. Surrey's season begins on April 19, with Pietersen hoping to regain international selection following his last appearance during England's disastrous 2014 Ashes tour in Australia.

Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week following a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani, leaving them 16th in the standings, six points from safety. Ze Maria had been reinstated briefly after being fired for a poor run, but was dismissed again after the defeat. He replaced Florin Marin in January as the club's third coach this season and will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Nabil Dirar, Radamel Falcao's former Monaco teammate, believes Falcao regrets his failed loan move to Manchester United despite not being happy in France. Falcao struggled after a serious knee injury, scoring only four goals this season. Manchester United must pay £46 million to make the transfer permanent but are unlikely to do so. Dirar states Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he was not feeling well, and suggests he is now regretting the move.

New Zealand police are seeking public assistance to identify a tall man who robbed a Christchurch dairy on Saturday, wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and fluoro orange sweatshirt. The offender took approximately $1500 from the till and threw the cash register to the ground. Police reported no weapons were used and the robber remains at large, urging anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers.

Kaitlyn Granado, 24, a math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested twice. First, on March 19, she was arrested for an inappropriate relationship with a 15-year-old student, admitting to kissing him and allowing him to touch her breasts in April of the previous year. She was suspended and placed on administrative leave. Second, on Monday, she was arrested again after a second 15-year-old student accused her of having sex with him in her car on two consecutive nights in January near a Dallas school. She was booked into Irving County Jail, released on $50,000 bail, and remains on administrative leave preventing her from working with students or being on school property.

A video showing a crocodile swimming through Puerto Vallarta's marina with a dead black dog wearing a red collar in its jaws has been viewed over 500,000 times online. The incident, witnessed by New Zealander Tim Weston, occurred when the dog approached the water's edge near a crocodile sanctuary; the crocodile held the dog for hours before disappearing. Crocodiles are common in Puerto Vallarta due to the mangrove habitat and urbanization, with American Crocodiles reaching up to 6 meters. Social media reactions to the video were negative, with users calling it "horrible" and expressing hatred toward crocodiles.

Steve Bruce is confident Hull City can avoid relegation despite a 2-0 defeat to Southampton leaving them two points above the drop zone. Hull have six wins this season (below Bruce's initial target of 10), with six games remaining against top teams. Bruce attributes their struggles to long-term injuries to key players including Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass. He believes nine or eight wins might be sufficient to survive.

Ian Guffick, a 31-year-old teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School, altered pupils' SATs exam answers for 11-year-olds after the exam session ended, invalidating the school's entire 2014 results. He asked pupils to change answers and made alterations himself, despite exam rules prohibiting changes outside test conditions. The Department for Education annulled all results, and Guffick admitted to unacceptable professional conduct, though he claimed he only sought to improve legibility. A panel found his actions dishonest but not fraudulent, leading to a two-year classroom ban, with the Department for Education stating his deliberate actions severely impacted the school.

Anders Lindegaard, Manchester United goalkeeper, married Swedish model Misse Beqiri (with Albanian roots) in a Mauritius beach wedding last year. The couple, dating since 2012 and with a son, share a happy personal life despite Lindegaard's limited playing time at United. He has made only 19 league appearances in five seasons, is third-choice goalkeeper behind David de Gea and Victor Valdes, and was linked to a move to FC Midtjylland in January without a transfer agreement. The passage highlights his off-pitch happiness with his wife.

The 13 glowing blue letters that once illuminated Yankee Stadium failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction, receiving only one bid of $260,000 from a Sotheby's employee. Expected to fetch $300,000 to $600,000, the letters were owned by Reggie Jackson, who bought them in 2008 after the stadium's final game. Installed in 1976, the letters were removed in 2008. Jackson stated he wanted a new owner to enjoy the "icon of the Yankees and New York City."

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers addressed Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe regarding their professional conduct after Sterling was exposed for inhaling nitrous oxide and both were pictured with shisha pipes. Rodgers spoke to them but decided not to discipline either player, emphasizing their responsibilities as professionals. He stated he wants to move past the incident. Rodgers also confirmed Steven Gerrard is available for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa after a three-match suspension but would not disclose whether Gerrard would be immediately recalled. Rodgers expressed that close losses in previous competitions, such as the title race and Capital One Cup, are part of the journey to success.

Mesut Ozil posted a photo of himself relaxing with his dog after returning to London following Germany's 2-0 Euro 2016 qualifier win against Georgia. He missed Arsenal's previous match due to illness but is set to play against Liverpool. Ozil has been in strong form since returning from injury, scoring three goals and providing four assists since January. He stated he is adjusting well to English football, preferring the frequent matches and stating he "fits perfectly" in the Premier League.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu stated the club has no plans to replace manager Luis Enrique, who signed a two-year deal last summer and is contracted until 2016, and confirmed the club is "very happy" with his performance as they remain in contention for three trophies.

Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract with Liverpool, worth approximately £100,000 per week until 2020, after having 14 months remaining on his previous deal. The 24-year-old midfielder, who has contributed 13 assists and seven goals this season, is the third senior player to extend his contract following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. Henderson, Liverpool's vice-captain, is set to replace Steven Gerrard as club captain when Gerrard departs. The deal follows Henderson's improved form under manager Brendan Rodgers.

Filipe Luis states he wants to remain at Chelsea until his contract ends despite Atletico Madrid considering re-signing him. He joined Chelsea from Atletico last July on a three-year deal but has struggled to secure the left-back position. Luis also played for Brazil in friendlies against France and Chile, and Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is demanding focus for the remaining nine Premier League games as the team aims to win the title.

Nathan Hughes' three-match ban for accidentally knocking out George North was overturned on appeal after a disciplinary panel ruled no foul play occurred, as the incident was accidental. Hughes, a Wasps No 8, had been suspended following a red card for his knee colliding with North's head during a try on March 27, leaving North unconscious and requiring a stretcher. This was North's third head injury in two months, leading to a minimum one-month rest for concussion. The ban was rescinded after fierce criticism from teammates, coaches, and former players who called it unjust, with the appeal panel noting new evidence showed no intent. Hughes missed Wasps' Champions Cup quarter-final loss to Toulon but is now free to play, though he will not feature in the immediate match against London Welsh.

Fiery red sunsets in the Pacific Northwest, including Washington, resulted from smoke carried by atmospheric winds from uncontrolled wildfires in southeastern Siberia. The fires, started by farmers burning grass and spreading rapidly due to strong winds on April 14, destroyed dozens of villages. The smoke traveled across the Pacific Ocean, and smoke particles filtered shorter wavelength colors from sunlight, allowing red and orange hues to dominate during sunsets. As the smoke dissipates, the sunsets will lose their reddish intensity.

Becky Schoenig of St. Louis had her 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway. Police recovered the car after a tip from Mick Sexton, who identified it. The thieves had spray-painted the rims red, added red detailing on the sides, and orange steering wheel accents. Instead of being upset, Schoenig thanked the thieves on Facebook, calling her car "pimpin now." She plans to professionally clean the car due to cigarette and marijuana smells and is creating a smoothie named "The Sexton on Wheels" at her restaurant to honor Sexton. A friend described her as vibrant and happy.

Manchester City players face £500,000-a-man bonus losses if they fail to qualify for the Champions League. The squad has approximately £12 million at stake. Currently in fourth place, City are four points ahead of Liverpool after a defeat to Manchester United, with the top three qualifying automatically and fourth needing a qualifying round. The team's incentivised contracts comply with financial fair play rules. Manager Manuel Pellegrini admitted their season has "disintegrated" after seven losses, including early exits in the FA Cup and Champions League.

Manchester United's Under 18s defeated City 1-0 in a 'mini-derby' with Callum Gribbin scoring the winning free-kick. The match featured 13 English players (10 Mancunian), was played at Altrincham's 6,000-capacity ground with free entry and nearly 1,000 spectators, and showcased a formation used by the senior team. United now lead the Barclays Under 18s Premier League play-offs with two wins, while City, injury-ravaged, have lost both matches. The game highlighted promising talents on both sides deserving future first-team opportunities.

Joe Hart praised Gianluigi Buffon as a 'legend of the game' following Buffon's 147th cap for Italy, while Hart himself achieved his 50th cap for England. Hart, 10 years younger than Buffon, expressed admiration for Buffon's longevity at 37 and stated he aims to continue earning more caps.

Chipotle is partnering with the Postmates app to offer delivery in 67 cities, charging a nine per cent service fee plus $5 or more delivery fees. This marks a shift from Chipotle's previous refusal of third-party delivery offers. The chain is entering the $70 billion food delivery market through this collaboration.

Bill and Denise Richard, parents of 8-year-old Martin Richard killed in the 2013 Boston Marathon bombing, urge the Justice Department to drop the death penalty for convicted bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev in exchange for life imprisonment without parole and waiver of appeal rights. They describe their family's grief, Martin's death, and their daughter Jane's severe injuries, stating the death penalty pursuit would prolong their pain through years of appeals. Tsarnaev was convicted on all 30 charges related to the bombings that killed three people and injured over 200. The Richards emphasize they speak only for themselves, advocating for ending the "anguish" and turning "the page" for their family, Boston, and the country.

A custom-built Boeing 747-8, costing £400 million over three years, has been converted into a luxury home for a billionaire. Designed for a single owner but accommodating dozens of guests, it features a dining room with an adjoining kitchen, lounge, state room, and 'aeroloft' with eight beds. The interior includes hotel-like amenities such as a conference room, master bedroom, and lounge, all within a plane normally carrying 600 passengers.

SpaceX successfully launched a Dragon cargo spacecraft to the International Space Station using a Falcon 9 rocket, but failed to land the rocket stage on a floating drone ship, as it tipped over after landing. The Dragon delivered over 4,300 pounds of supplies, including an espresso maker, and will remain docked for five weeks before returning with 3,000+ pounds of cargo. This marked SpaceX's sixth ISS mission and second launch attempt for the mission, following a weather-related scrub on Monday. The company aims to master sea landings to enable rocket reuse and reduce space access costs.

Priscilla Presley will witness the first wedding at the newly opened Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas' Westgate Hotel on April 23. The winning couple from a contest, announced the following Monday, will receive a free wedding, reception, two-night hotel suite, airfares, and concert tickets. Priscilla emphasized the event is "first-class" and "not a joke," forbidding impersonators, and she was involved in the chapel's design as part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Memphis. Couples must submit videos or photos explaining why they deserve the prize.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his side can catch Manchester City in the Premier League, as they are four points behind City in the Champions League race. After a 2-0 win over Newcastle United, with goals from Raheem Sterling (9th minute) and Joe Allen (80th minute), Henderson stated Liverpool need to keep winning to close the gap. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet both played their 47th game of the season, equalling a top-five European league record.

Roma ended a four-month home winless streak with a 1-0 Serie A victory over Napoli, securing a key win for Champions League qualification. Miralem Pjanic scored the only goal in the 25th minute from a counter-attack. Goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made crucial saves in the second half. The win moved second-placed Roma provisionally four points ahead of Lazio, ending a seven-match home winless run since November 30. Napoli extended their winless streak to five matches, remaining fifth. Security was heightened due to a prior fan incident, with Campania residents barred from tickets and 1,000 police officers deployed, but no issues occurred. Roma played without captain Francesco Totti and Gervinho.

Doncaster Rovers and Fleetwood Town drew 0-0 in League One, resulting in a goalless match that left the media team with a short highlight video on YouTube. The video was 27 seconds long, containing only 14 seconds of match action (kick-off, a goal kick, and final whistle).

Roland Giroux interacts with his blood parrot cichlid by gently cupping it in his hand and stroking it, causing the fish to relax and stay still. The fish swims away but repeatedly returns for more attention, and later swims up his arm. Giroux began this interaction after removing bullying tankmates and feeding the fish frozen blood worms by hand, which made it sociable. The fish becomes frustrated if not played with daily, and Giroux massages it for at least 15 minutes each day. The blood parrot cichlid is a hybrid bred in Taiwan around 1986.

Ben Stokes has a fiery reputation in the England cricket team, known for natural aggression that must be controlled, not quashed. A past incident where he broke his wrist punching a locker serves as a reminder to channel his intensity properly. After clashing with Marlon Samuels, England coach Peter Moores advised him, and Stokes responded positively. The team wants to nurture his natural exuberance and desire to take on opponents while ensuring his aggression remains controlled to produce runs and wickets. They aim to keep Stokes in the team as much as possible to help him reach his potential, balancing his fiery character with occasional management. The team also intends to play both Stokes and Chris Jordan, avoiding the need for two spinners.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium on June 12 at Cardiff City Stadium has sold out with 33,000 tickets. Wales, in a strong position to qualify for a major tournament for the first time since 1958, has 11 points in Group B (tied with Belgium, who lead on goal difference). A recent 3-0 victory over Israel boosted Wales' qualification hopes and caused overwhelming ticket demand. The Wales squad prefers Cardiff City Stadium over the Millennium Stadium, and UEFA rules prevented a venue change despite speculation.

England coach John Peacock has named the squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, with the Young Lions as defending champions after beating Holland on penalties last year. They qualified with a 100% record, and are in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland, opening against Italy on May 7. The squad includes talented players from Premier League clubs, such as Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, and Arsenal's Chris Willock (first call-up) and Stephy Mavididi. Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold were recalled after missing the Elite Round qualifiers. Other matches are against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13.

Manchester City are seeking to sign 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, regarded as one of the club's best youth talents, who previously rejected Barcelona's La Masia academy at age 12. The club has held discussions with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock regarding a compensation package, with Manuel Pellegrini aiming to secure the player for future development. Patoulidis has also attracted interest from Arsenal.

A 33-year-old Mexican transgender escort, Vanessa Santillan, was found strangled and beaten to death in a Fulham flat in London on March 28. Her body was discovered with head and neck injuries, pronounced dead at the scene. A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death but has been bailed and must return for further questioning. Police are appealing for information from anyone who had contact with Santillan in the hours before her death, noting she worked as an escort in London, Paris, and Miami.

Dawn, a woman who experienced seven miscarriages, had £207 stolen from funds saved for a £500 grave stone for her baby Daniel James. Her friend and housemate Jamie, a convicted burglar, was caught by a lie detector test on The Jeremy Kyle show after denying taking the money. Dawn expressed devastation and betrayal, stating the money was meant to honor her deceased child, and she burst into tears during the confrontation.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, primarily women and children with some ill or elderly individuals, following coordination with Arab tribal leaders. The freed Yazidis were received by Peshmerga forces and taken to Irbil. Official counts varied slightly (217 or 228 released). This release occurred amid ISIS's ongoing persecution of Yazidis, an ancient minority group of Kurdish descent whose pre-Islamic religion draws from Christianity, Judaism, and Zoroastrianism. ISIS's 2014 conquest of northern Iraq, particularly the town of Sinjar, caused a humanitarian crisis involving mass killings, enslavement, and rape, forcing hundreds of thousands to flee. About 500,000 Yazidis live in northern Iraq, less than 1% of the population.

Harry Kane is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards. A Copa90 animation featuring his goals and celebrations, created using stacked still photographs, has been released ahead of the awards ceremony where he competes against Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.

Jamie Carragher supports Brendan Rodgers as Liverpool manager despite a third consecutive season without a trophy and a likely finish outside the top four, with Liverpool seven points behind fourth-placed Manchester City. Carragher stated Rodgers' future shouldn't be determined by one game, acknowledged new signings haven't fully settled, and emphasized the need for correct signings to improve next season. Carragher also mentioned receiving a Beacon Award for community work through his foundation.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his plastic Nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport during security checks, despite it being a harmless toy firing sponge darts. His father criticized the security as "ludicrous" and "over-zealous," noting they delayed the family's flight. The airport defended the action under government regulations prohibiting items resembling prohibited weapons, offering to return the toy but the family purchasing a replacement after their Lanzarote holiday.

A 31-year-old man from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, identified as Rich, posted a Gumtree advertisement seeking a girlfriend or wife. His requirements included: non-drinker, non-smoker, fit, attractive, good with hands, good cook, great in bed, enjoys outdoors, and "a princess when needed." He described himself as athletic, 175cm tall, tattooed, non-drinker/smoker/drug user, owns property, makes good money, and offers benefits like a company car, phone, laptop, gym membership, and "lots of benefits." He stated "former partners need not apply" and promised "all reasonable offers will be considered." Daily Mail Australia unsuccessfully attempted to contact him.

Football Association chairman Greg Dyke seeks to increase the minimum home-grown players in Premier League squads from eight to twelve and change the definition to require three years of English training before age 18. Five former England managers—Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren—have backed the proposals, urging the English game to support them to prevent England falling behind leading nations and to improve World Cup chances. They highlight that only 36.8% of Premier League starters (81 of 220) were eligible for England selection, noting the shrinking talent pool at the top level and the need to provide opportunities for young players like Harry Kane, Ross Barkley, and Raheem Sterling.

Demelza Poldark gives birth to her daughter in the upcoming episode, with Ross Poldark (Aidan Turner) shown gazing at the newborn. The passage criticizes the unrealistic pregnancy timeline, noting Demelza goes from announcing her pregnancy to being eight months pregnant and giving birth within a single episode. Fans have highlighted this inconsistency, referencing a previous similar instance with Elizabeth's pregnancy and joking that "if you are pregnant in Poldark times expect to have it in the next 10 minutes."

Leicester City manager Nigel Pearson urges his team to focus on their own results rather than relegation rivals, as the Foxes remain three points from safety in the Premier League despite back-to-back wins including Jamie Vardy's injury-time winner against West Brom. Pearson stresses their survival chance depends on their own performance, warning against over-optimism and emphasizing they must "keep their cool" to secure a realistic chance of avoiding relegation.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara completed a 14,000-mile (22,500 km) migration from Sakhalin Island, Russia, to Baja, Mexico, setting a new record for the longest mammal migration. This surpassed the previous humpback whale record of 10,190 miles. Varvara's journey visited three major eastern gray whale breeding areas, suggesting she may be an eastern gray whale rather than the endangered western gray whale (with only 150 believed to exist), potentially indicating a lower population count and challenging prior genetic distinctions between the species.

Residents on Hokkaido's Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu discovered a 1,000-1,640ft-long, 100ft-wide section of seabed risen 30-50ft above sea level overnight. Geologists attribute the emergence to a landslide caused by melting ice and snow, with no tremors or sounds reported by locals. Authorities confirmed it is unrelated to the Nepal earthquake and not expected to expand further.

Gregory van der Wiel denies reports of leaving Paris Saint-Germain in the summer, stating he is "genuinely happy" at the club, loves the city and teammates, and wants to sign a new contract. He reiterates his commitment despite a recent conflict with manager Laurent Blanc over being dropped for the Chelsea match, adding he is ready to play whenever called upon. The passage notes PSG is linked with Dani Alves, making Van der Wiel's future uncertain.

Carlos Tevez has requested to terminate his Juventus contract to return to Boca Juniors this summer, despite his deal expiring in 2016. Boca president Daniel Angelici confirmed they are close to finalizing the transfer but emphasized Tevez must first end his Juventus contract. Tevez, the Serie A top scorer with 17 goals this season, has stated he intends to finish his career at Boca Juniors. Juventus have accepted his desire to leave and are seeking replacements, while his Argentina manager Tata Martino noted the move would not affect his international future.

Bayern Munich defeated Porto 6-1 in the Champions League, advancing to the semi-finals after overcoming Porto's two-goal first-leg lead. Manager Pep Guardiola tore his trousers during the match, revealing his underwear, and joked about buying new ones. Goals were scored by Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Müller, Xabi Alonso, and Robert Lewandowski (two goals).

Ten people, including four children, were involved in a multi-vehicle crash on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale. Three vehicles collided, leading to injuries requiring medical transport. Two patients (a 40-year-old man and a five-year-old boy) were airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital. A 27-year-old woman and a six-year-old girl were also airlifted. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for assessment. A man suffered hand lacerations, and two females had no injuries. The highway was closed with diversions south of Fernvale after Queensland Fire and Rescue freed a trapped person using hydraulic cutting gear.

Arsenal face Chelsea in a crucial Premier League match, with Mesut Ozil showcasing his new Apple Watch on Instagram, comparing it to Michael Knight's watch from Knight Rider. Jack Wilshere returned from a five-month injury absence and featured in Arsenal's FA Cup semi-final win, though club legend Ray Parlour highlighted fitness concerns as the key factor preventing Wilshere from reaching his potential.

Mark Clattenburg will referee the Manchester derby at Old Trafford despite sending off three players from United and City this season. He has only shown two red cards in the Premier League this season, both to Manchester United players (Tyler Blackett and Luke Shaw). City captain Vincent Kompany is suspended for the Wales match after being sent off in an international qualifier. United are now one point above City following their 2-1 win over Crystal Palace, making the derby crucial for second place behind Chelsea. Clattenburg, regarded as a leading Premier League referee, will be assisted by Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as fourth official.

Outspoken federal MP Bob Katter accused the Queensland Government of believing MP Billy Gordon was "a little black puppet on a string" after Gordon was accused of domestic violence and withheld his criminal history, leading to his resignation from the Queensland Labor Party. Gordon remains in parliament as an independent, causing government instability. Katter, of Lebanese descent, defended his terminology by referencing his personal experiences with racism and stated he used "black puppet" deliberately to highlight racial attitudes. His statement sparked social media criticism over his wording.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois born with cerebral palsy, uses dance videos to challenge stereotypes about disabilities and inspire others. She aims to counteract the perception that people with disabilities cannot do things, emphasizing she is "pretty much just the same as everyone else" despite doing things differently. Her motivation stems from experiences of bullying and staring, and she hopes to change how disabilities are represented in media. She also engages in motivational speaking at local schools, highlighting her ability to drive, attend college, and live independently.

Orlando City (MLS) are interested in signing Javier Hernandez following his loan spell at Real Madrid, with eight European clubs also pursuing him. Manchester United is willing to sell Hernandez for around £8 million, as he has one year left on his contract. Additionally, Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old Andreas Pereira, who rejected the initial offer, with several European clubs interested in him if he does not agree terms.

A gang of at least three people poured gasoline on a white Dodge Charger at a South Los Angeles 76 Station around 12:15am on Saturday, setting it on fire after an argument during an attempted carjacking. The driver and two passengers were unharmed, but the car's front end was destroyed. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating as arson, with suspects still at large and surveillance video being used in the investigation.

A chiropractor in Lamoni, Iowa, Charles Manuel, surrendered his state license after admitting to accepting sex as payment for services and performing exorcisms on patients. He agreed not to apply for reinstatement for at least 10 years. Despite the misconduct, he received perfect 5/5 star patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com based on three responses. The Iowa Board of Chiropractic report noted he also advised patients to stop taking prescribed medication. His practice address listed on Yelp appears to be a residential home.

A U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane was intercepted by a Russian SU-27 fighter jet over the Baltic Sea in international airspace north of Poland, with the Pentagon calling the Russian pilot's maneuvers "unsafe and unprofessional" due to aggressive close proximity and high speed. Russia claimed the U.S. plane had its transponder off and was approaching the Russian border, but the U.S. European Command denied this. The Pentagon stated it would file a diplomatic complaint. This follows a similar incident a year ago over the Sea of Okhotsk where a Russian jet flew within 100 feet of a U.S. RC-135U.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from a locked car in the parking lot of Salt Lake City's Marriott Springhill Suites on March 27, overnight. The rifle, secured in a hard case with padlocks and chains, was ripped through a broken passenger-side window using a rope and the momentum of another vehicle. Police found skid marks, rope pieces, and the broken case handle. The agent's gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools were also stolen, though some items were recovered across the street. The rifle, which has not been recovered, was reported to the National Crime Information Computer. The theft occurred just days before President Obama's scheduled Utah visit. The hotel lacks surveillance cameras.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of murdering his elderly neighbour Terrence Freebody in Canberra in July 2012 by stomping on his head, cutting his throat, and stabbing him. A forensic psychiatrist testified that Costa was likely suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse at the time, leading to a compromised mental state where he would not have understood his actions or their consequences. Costa's mental state is critical to the case, as it could lead to a not guilty verdict if proven.

Everton defeated Burnley 1-0 at Goodison Park with Ross Barkley missing a penalty he took instead of Leighton Baines, who has a 15/16 Premier League penalty success rate. Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Barkley's choice, stating players should take responsibility for big moments, and noted Barkley's effort was well-struck but saved by Burnley's goalkeeper. Kevin Mirallas later scored the winning goal.

Two passengers found dead in their stateroom on the Holland America Line cruise ship ms Ryndam in San Juan, Puerto Rico, appear to have died in a murder-suicide, according to the cruise line. The cabin was secured, authorities including the FBI were notified, and the cleaning staff discovered the deceased after knocking on the door.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, guided Curacao to the second qualifying round of CONCACAF for the 2018 World Cup. Curacao advanced with a 4-3 aggregate win over Montserrat, winning the first leg 2-1 and drawing the second leg 2-2. Charlton Vicento scored the decisive goal in the 87th minute of the second leg. Curacao will face Cuba in the next round on June 8 and 16. Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, was a 1998 World Cup semi-finalist as a player and previously worked as assistant coach under Louis van Gaal at the 2014 World Cup.

Esteban Cambiasso, who won 15 trophies during his career at Inter Milan, stated that keeping Leicester City in the Premier League would feel like winning a trophy. Leicester is seven points from safety with eight games remaining. Cambiasso signed a one-year deal with Leicester after leaving Inter, remains convinced the team can avoid relegation despite not winning since January, and believes saving the club is his current objective.

A 23-year-old mother of two children under five, Gemma, faces being banned from seeing her children by her own mother, Debbie, due to her refusal to stop drinking, partying, and suspected thefts. Debbie, who has cared for the children since they were four months old after social services threatened removal, claims Gemma stole an iPad from one child to fund her lifestyle and admitted to past thefts from her. Gemma, unemployed and with a history of underage drinking and partying since age 13, reportedly abandoned her children four months after birth. Debbie, appearing on The Jeremy Kyle Show, states she will ban Gemma from her home and the children's lives due to distrust, as Gemma prioritizes drinking and parties over motherhood, and a lie detector test confirmed she stole. The children call Debbie "mum" instead of "grandma."

Chelsea captain John Terry committed a foul on Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao during the build-up to Eden Hazard's opening goal, according to Sky Sports pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness. They agreed the challenge from behind, involving a "forearm smash" and "elbow in the back of Falcao's head," was a foul that should have stopped play, despite the goal being scored. Souness stated the foul caused Falcao to fall, Henry expressed sympathy as a fellow striker, and Redknapp called it a foul even if Falcao could have stayed on his feet.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on Interstate 30 near Dallas, Texas, on Thursday morning after a rear tire blew out. Everyone on board—including Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver—was safely evacuated. The bus was destroyed except for Scott's Bible, which survived the fire. The band's other two members were not on the bus.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University is developing space lasers to convert sunlight into energy via satellites, which would beam the power back to Earth for home heating and disaster recovery. The lasers, powered by mirrors and semiconductors on orbiting satellites, are not powerful enough to harm living creatures (e.g., not blinding a pigeon) or function as weapons, differing from sci-fi portrayals. The project aims to make solar power viable in places like Scotland, with trials planned in Portugal after initial success in Scotland. A separate Tokyo research proposal for using lasers to clear space debris is mentioned but is unrelated to Quarterman's energy project.

Stephen Munden, 54, a convicted paedophile with a 'fanatical obsession' with young girls, has gone missing from a psychiatric unit in Hampshire after vanishing on Tuesday evening. He was detained under the Mental Health Act following his conviction for sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus, which he claimed was accidental. Munden, described as 5ft 8ins tall, heavy build, with dark hair (and may have shaved his beard), suffers from autism and mild learning difficulties. Police are urgently seeking him after he left a hospital near Hook, Hampshire, and he is subject to a hospital order due to his sexual offences.

A Los Angeles judge ordered V. Stiviano to repay more than $2.6 million in gifts from Donald Sterling, including a Ferrari, two Bentleys, a Range Rover, a $1.8 million duplex, and unusual items like an Easter bunny costume and lace thong, following a lawsuit by Shelly Sterling accusing Stiviano of targeting wealthy older men. Shelly Sterling's lawyer called it a victory setting a precedent for injured spouses. This ruling followed Donald Sterling's NBA ban and loss of the Clippers due to racist remarks captured in an audio recording.

Thierry Henry criticised Arsenal's transfer window, urging them to sign a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder, and top striker to win the Premier League. He stated Arsenal need these four positions to compete, specifically arguing Olivier Giroud cannot win the title despite scoring 14 league goals, and cited Chelsea's successful signings of Courtois, Matic, Fabregas, and Costa as evidence. Henry noted Arsenal are third in the league, level on points with Manchester City but with a game in hand.

A young woman, abused as a child by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn, testified in Sydney's District Court about the severe impact on her life, stating she is scared for future relationships and had attempted suicide after speaking out. Van Ryn pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim, who did not understand the abuse was wrong at the time, revealed she suffered depression since age 14, was hospitalized for self-harm and attempted suicide, and fears how the abuse affects her future interactions with men. Van Ryn sat calmly in court without looking at her.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is returning after over a year out due to a serious knee injury, having recently played 90 minutes for the Under-21s. He stated he is "feeling better and better" and is over his injury worries.

A 23-year-old accountant, Jacob Phillips, died after falling 70ft down a cliff while running from a taxi driver to avoid paying the fare in Penarth, South Wales. He and friends had left the taxi to "use an ATM" but planned to dodge the fare. Phillips ran into the dark, leapt over a fence, and fell onto a rocky beach. The coroner recorded an accidental death, noting Phillips was disorientated and unaware of the cliff's danger. His body was found the next morning by a dog walker.

Thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer's passport delays received no compensation despite the HM Passport Office making a £42.3 million profit and managers receiving £1.8 million in bonuses (average £499, highest £3,500). Only 2,191 compensation applications were approved between April last year and January this year, totaling £203,066 (average £92.68). Ministers refused blanket refunds, stating it would "create a precedent," and the Passport Office could not disclose rejected claims due to a "system failure." Home Affairs Committee chairman Keith Vaz expressed astonishment at the low compensation rate.

A semi-detached home in Horfield, Bristol, unchanged since the 1930s is up for sale with original features including stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, a mint-green and black bathroom with original tiles, vintage kitchen cupboards, and original tins of food like Cadbury’s Marvel dried milk. The three-bedroom property, with a guide price of £200,000-£250,000, will be auctioned on April 30 and is described as a collector's paradise.

Colin Kaepernick became the 49ers' starting quarterback in 2012 after Alex Smith suffered a concussion, remained the starter for the rest of the season, and led the team to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds and Robert Teitel and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through the NBCUniversal division NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn was raised in Leytonstone, East London, and Colchester, Essex, attending Stanway School where he met Graham Coxon and formed Blur. Blur's debut album "Leisure" was released in 1991. The band drew influences from alternative rock, trip hop, hip hop, electronica, dub, reggae, and pop. Their self-titled album was released in 2001. Albarn's solo debut album "Everyday Robots," co-produced by Richard Russell, was released on 28 April 2014, featuring collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, and samples of Lord Buckley.
Mogadishu, locally known as Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia, housing many important national institutions.
Happiness in Slavery is a song by American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails from their debut extended play (EP), Broken (1992).
Andrew Kevin Walker (born August 14, 1964) is an American BAFTA-nominated screenwriter.

The 2007 film and TV series "Shooter" both feature Bob Lee Swagger (Mark Wahlberg in film, Ryan Phillippe in series), a Force Recon veteran and marksman. The film follows him being framed for murder by a rogue private military company. The TV series depicts him living in exile and returning to action upon learning of a plot to kill the president.
House (also called House, M.D.) is an American television medical drama that aired on Fox for eight seasons from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was found guilty of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder in 1971 for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate, and received additional first-degree murder convictions for the deaths of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. Recordings of songs he wrote and performed were released commercially after he was charged.

Sean Justin Penn (born August 17, 1960) is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist. He began his acting career in television (Little House on the Prairie, 1974) and film (Taps, 1981), gaining critical attention for roles in At Close Range (1986), State of Grace (1990), and Carlito's Way (1993). His breakthrough was Dead Man Walking (1995), earning his first Academy Award nomination and a Berlin Film Festival Best Actor Award. He received two more Oscar nominations for Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and I Am Sam (2001), winning Best Actor for Mystic River (2003) and Milk (2008).

Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman (27 August 1908 – 25 February 2001), often called "The Don," was an Australian cricketer widely acknowledged as the greatest batsman of all time. He remained influential for three decades after retirement as an administrator, selector, and writer.

L.A. Reid has served as the chairman and CEO of Epic Records, a division of Sony Music Entertainment, the president and CEO of Arista Records, and the chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

The Millers is a multi-camera series that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015, running 34 episodes across two seasons. CBS canceled the show on November 14, 2014, after four episodes into its second season.

Drake Bell released an independent EP titled A Reminder in 2011.

Boardwalk is a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman and directed by Verona. Janet Leigh (July 6, 1927 – October 3, 2004) was an American actress, singer, dancer, and author who wrote four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.

Simón Bolívar (1783-1830), known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader who helped establish Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama as sovereign states independent of Spanish rule.

The Bermuda Triangle, also known as the Devil's Triangle, is a loosely-defined region in the western part of the North Atlantic Ocean where a number of aircraft and ships are said to have disappeared under mysterious circumstances.

Colin Kaepernick became the 49ers' starting quarterback in 2012 after Alex Smith's concussion, leading the team to a Super Bowl appearance (loss to Baltimore Ravens). In his first full season as starter in 2013, he helped the 49ers reach the NFC Championship (loss to Seattle Seahawks).
Marnie is a 1964 American psychological thriller directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is an audio or visual form of marketing communication that employs an openly sponsored, nonpersonal message to promote or sell a product, service, or idea. It is differentiated from personal selling as the message is not directed to a particular individual and is communicated through various mass media, including old media (newspapers, magazines, television, radio, outdoor advertising, direct mail) and new media (search results, blogs, websites, text messages).
Private Lives is a 1930 comedy of manners in three acts by Noël Coward. It is also a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.

Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton (10 February 1894 – 29 December 1986), was a British Conservative politician and statesman who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 10 January 1957 to 19 October 1963.

Aristotle (384–322 BC) was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist born in Stagira, Chalkidice. At 17 or 18, he joined Plato's Academy in Athens and remained until age 37 (c. 347 BC). After Plato's death, he tutored Alexander the Great beginning in 343 BC at the request of Philip II of Macedon.

David Mordechai Packouz (born February 16, 1982) is an American former arms dealer, musician, inventor, and entrepreneur. He invented the BeatBuddy guitar pedal drum machine and is currently the CEO of music technology company Singular Sound.

Magic Johnson played point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons. Selected first overall in the 1979 NBA draft, he won a championship and NBA Finals MVP in his rookie season, then four more championships in the 1980s. After retiring following protests from players, he returned in 1996 at age 36 to play 32 games before retiring permanently. Named by Ebony magazine as one of America's most influential black businessmen in 2009, he has numerous business interests and was a Lakers part-owner for several years.

Tenacious D is an American comedy rock duo formed in Los Angeles in 1994 by Jack Black and Kyle Gass. They released three albums: Tenacious D (2001), The Pick of Destiny (2006), and Rize of the Fenix (2012). The band gained popularity in 1997 through their eponymous television series and supporting large rock acts.

James VI and I ruled Scotland from 1567 and England and Ireland from 1603 following the union of the crowns. He governed both kingdoms in personal union, advocating for a single parliament. He achieved most aims in Scotland but faced the 1605 Gunpowder Plot and repeated conflicts with the English Parliament.

Big Brother 2017, also known as Big Brother 18, is the upcoming eighteenth series of the British Big Brother reality show hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley. Bentley, born 4 October 1967, has narrated the UK version of Big Brother since its 2000 inception and continued narrating the revived series on Channel 5 after leaving Channel 4 in July 2011. His voice-over work and Geordie accent make him one of Britain's most recognised voices.

Saxony is a landlocked German federal state (10th largest, 18,413 km², 6th most populous with 4 million people) bordering Brandenburg, Saxony Anhalt, Thuringia, Bavaria, Poland, and the Czech Republic. It has over a millennium of history and is part of Germany's northernmost wine regions with Saale-Unstrut.

Mel B. Brown began her solo career with the release of "I Want You Back" featuring Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and younger sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

Mohra (Pawn) is a 1994 Indian action thriller film directed by Rajiv Rai. Starring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah in lead roles, with Paresh Rawal, Gulshan Grover, Raza Murad, and Sadashiv Amrapurkar in supporting roles, it was released on 1 July 1994. The film became the second highest-grossing Indian film of 1994 and received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. Originally, Divya Bharti was cast but was replaced by Raveena Tandon after her death. The film is also noted for its chartbuster songs.

Shane Black (born December 16, 1961) is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor known for writing the 1987 film Lethal Weapon and directing Kiss Kiss Bang Bang in 2005.
A View to a Kill (1985) is the 14th James Bond film and Roger Moore's 7th and final appearance as James Bond.

Papua is Indonesia's largest and easternmost province, comprising most of western New Guinea. It was formerly known as Irian Jaya (previously West Irian or Irian Barat) and comprised all of Indonesian New Guinea.
Augustus probably died from natural causes, though unconfirmed rumors suggested his wife Livia poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez debuted in music with the 1999 album *On the 6* and the number-one single "If You Had My Love." In 2001, she became the first woman to have a number-one album and film simultaneously with *J.Lo* and *The Wedding Planner*. Her third album *This Is Me... Then* (2002) was influenced by her relationship with Ben Affleck, while the film *Gigli* (2003) was a critical and commercial failure. She married Marc Anthony, had twins in 2008, and rebounded in 2011 with *American Idol* and the best-selling single "On the Floor."

A working animal is a domesticated animal trained by humans to perform tasks, such as guide dogs for assistance, draft horses or logging elephants for tractive force, or animals for milking or herding. Wild animals may occasionally be tamed and trained but are rarely used for work, typically only for novelty or entertainment, as they lack the trustworthiness and mild temper of true domesticated working animals.

Billboard Dad is a 1998 American direct-to-video comedy film directed by Alan Metter starring Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen. Top Latin Albums is a Billboard magazine record chart labeled as the most important music chart for Spanish language, full-length albums in the American music market. Regional Mexican Albums is a genre-specific record chart published weekly by Billboard magazine in the United States.

Vedam (Chant) is a 2010 Telugu Indian drama film directed by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi, featuring Allu Arjun, Manoj Manchu, Anushka Shetty, Manoj Bajpayee, Saranya Ponvannan, Deeksha Seth, Lekha Washington, and Siya Gautham.
Men in Black II (MIIB) is a 2002 American science fiction action comedy film starring Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Lara Flynn Boyle, Johnny Knoxville, Rosario Dawson, Tony Shalhoub and Rip Torn.

Sancho Panza is a fictional character in Don Quixote, written by Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra in 1605, who serves as Don Quixote's squire and provides humorous comments known as "sanchismos," combining broad humor, ironic Spanish proverbs, and earthy wit.
A 2002 Australian-American science fiction action comedy film starring Eddie Murphy in a dual role and directed by Ron Underwood.
Hedda Gabler by Ibsen had its world premiere on 31 January 1891 at the Residenztheater in Munich, with Ibsen present.
Brazzers is a pornographic production company based in Montreal, Canada.
Timothy Simon Roth (born 14 May 1961) is an English actor and director.

Juventus Football Club S.p.A., founded in 1897 by young Torinese students including first president Eugenio Canfari and his brother Enrico, is the second oldest active Italian football club after Genoa (1893). The club, nicknamed Juve, has worn a black and white striped home kit since 1903 and plays home matches at the 41,507-capacity Juventus Stadium.

Viola Davis played supporting and minor roles in several films and television series in the late 1990s and early 2000s, including the films Kate & Leopold (2001) and Far from Heaven (2002), and the television series Law & Order: Special Victims Unit.

Jenna Jameson (born Jenna Marie Massoli, April 9, 1974) is an American entrepreneur, webcam model, and former pornographic film actress, known as the world's most famous adult entertainment performer and "The Queen of Porn." She began acting in erotic videos in 1993 after working as a stripper and glamor model.
The New Orleans Pelicans are a National Basketball Association (NBA) team competing in the Western Conference Southwest Division.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000, originally broadcast via closed-circuit television and later via pay-per-view, produced by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later World Championship Wrestling (WCW). Specific annual events included Starrcade (1985) as the third annual, Starrcade (1987) as the fifth annual, and Starrcade (1997) as the fifteenth annual.
Jack Ryan Falahee (born February 20, 1989) is an American actor known for his role as Connor Walsh on ABC's How to Get Away with Murder and as Benjamin Stringfellow on PBS's Mercy Street.

Seohyun, born June 28, 1991, is a South Korean singer and actress who debuted with Girls' Generation in 2007. She released her solo debut EP, "Do n't Say No," on January 17, 2017, making her the third Girls' Generation member to debut as a solo artist.

The Apple II is an 8-bit home computer, one of the first highly successful mass-produced microcomputer products, designed primarily by Steve Wozniak. It was introduced in 1977 by Apple Computer (now Apple Inc.). Steve Jobs oversaw the development of the foam-molded plastic case, and Rod Holt developed the switching power supply. The Apple II series was trademarked as "Apple ] [" and later rendered as "Apple //". Stephen Gary Wozniak, nicknamed "Woz", is identified as the co-founder of Apple Inc.

A&E is an American cable and satellite television channel, formerly Arts & Entertainment Network, serving as the flagship of A&E Networks, a 50-50 joint venture between Hearst Corporation and Disney-ABC Television Group.

L.A. Reid served as chairman and CEO of Epic Records (Sony Music Entertainment), president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group. He was also the founder and CEO of Hitco Music Publishing and the co-founder of LaFace Records.

Sheryl Lee appeared in Café Society (2016) and reprised her role as Laura Palmer in the 2017 Showtime revival of Twin Peaks. Sheryl Lee Ralph played Madame Morrible in Wicked on Broadway in 2016.

"Same Old Love" is a song by Selena Gomez from her 2015 album Revival, which debuted at number one on the Billboard 200. The song was one of the first three singles from the album, all of which topped the Mainstream Top 40 chart in the United States.

Aaron Burr was elected to the New York State Assembly (1784–1785, 1798–1799), appointed New York State Attorney General (1789–1791), chosen as a U.S. Senator (1791–1797), and reached the apex of his career as vice president.

Soyuz is a series of spacecraft designed by the Korolyov Design Bureau (now RKK Energia) in the 1960s for the Soviet space programme. Commissioned to launch Soyuz spacecraft for human spaceflight, it began with 8 unmanned test flights followed by 19 manned launches. It succeeded the Voskhod spacecraft and was originally built for the Soviet manned lunar program, remaining in service today.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine broke up after tensions led to de la Rocha quitting, with de la Rocha starting a solo career and the remaining members forming Audioslave with Chris Cornell; Audioslave released three albums before disbanding in 2007. That same year, Rage Against the Machine reunited and performed at Coachella after seven years. "Renegades" is their fourth studio album, released December 5, 2000, by Epic Records.
The S&P BSE SENSEX (BSE 30 or SENSEX) is a free-float market-weighted stock market index of 30 well-established and financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam (SRV), is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia. With approximately 92.7 million people, it is the world's 14th-most-populous country and the ninth-most-populous in Asia. It borders China to the north, Laos to the northwest, Cambodia to the southwest, and Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia across the South China Sea. Since 2000, Vietnam has had one of the world's highest economic growth rates, ranking highest in the Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies in 2011. Vietnam remains one of the world's four remaining one-party socialist states officially espousing communism.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film written and directed by John Gatins in his directorial debut.

Bhagat Singh was an Indian socialist revolutionary who became a folk hero of the Indian independence movement after his execution at age 23 for two acts of dramatic violence against the British in India.
Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut with Aamir Khan's "Dangal," a 2016 Indian Hindi-language biographical sports drama film directed by Nitesh Tiwari.

James VI and I (19 June 1566 – 27 March 1625) was King of Scotland as James VI from 24 July 1567 and King of England and Ireland as James I from 24 March 1603 following the union of the crowns. Scotland and England remained separate sovereign states with their own parliaments, judiciary, and laws, ruled by James in personal union. He advocated for a single parliament for England and Scotland and faced difficulties with Parliament during his English reign.

Danielle Cormack (born 26 December 1970) is a New Zealand stage and screen actress. She was part of the original cast of the soap opera Shortland Street, and is known for roles as Ephiny in Xena: Warrior Princess, Cynthia Ross in The Cult, Shota in Legend of the Seeker, Kate Leigh in Underbelly: Razor, and Bea Smith in the Foxtel drama Wentworth (which she starred in for four years until 2016). Other works include the film Separation City and the series Rake.
Rob Sheridan (born October 11, 1979) is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer best known for his extensive work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade starred in films including Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2. Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser is a 2015 American comedy film directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett (born August 16, 1958) is an American actress.

Artpop received mixed reviews but was commercially successful, debuting at number one on the US Billboard 200 with 258,000 first-week sales, becoming Lady Gaga's second consecutive US number-one album, and selling 757,000 copies total. It was the ninth best-selling album of 2013 worldwide with 2.3 million copies sold.

2006 saw the release of John Frusciante's fifth and final album with the Chili Peppers, Stadium Arcadium, which is also the group's last album to feature him as guitarist, as he confirmed his departure in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister, implemented policies known as Thatcherism, a controversial figure lauded as one of Britain's greatest and most influential politicians despite ongoing arguments over Thatcherism.
Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan (born February 5, 1964) is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author who has written weekly columns for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker (English actor) has narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks and television series in addition to performing acting roles.

València, the capital of Spain's Valencian Community (also called the Valencian Country), is Spain's third largest city with around 800,000 inhabitants and the third largest metropolitan area with a population ranging from 1.7 to 2.5 million.
Buffy Summers was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
The series "Make It or Break It" was announced to end on April 26, 2012, with the third season as the final season, and its series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition is an interdisciplinary computational linguistics field enabling computers to recognize and translate spoken language into text, incorporating linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Applications include voice user interfaces (e.g., voice dialing, call routing), domotic control, search, data entry, document preparation, and speech-to-text processing. Recent advances are driven by widespread industry adoption of deep learning methods, with companies like Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, and others implementing deep learning in their speech recognition systems.

Richard Alf (January 26, 1952 – January 4, 2012) was an American businessman and former comic book store owner who co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International (originally the Golden State Comic Book Convention in 1970) and served as its chairman beginning in 1970. The convention was founded by Alf, Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry, and later became known as the "San Diego Comic Book Convention."
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 Fist of Fury, which starred Bruce Lee as the lead character.

Rory McIlroy shot a five under par 67 to move to 15 under par, tied with Thailand's Kiradech Aphibarnrat, following a third consecutive 67. The world number three, recovering from a July ankle injury, expressed confidence in achieving a lower round and is targeting a third Race to Dubai title in four years, leading Danny Willett by 271,214 points with three events remaining.

Sheikh Ali Salman emphasized that meaningful national dialogue requires the government to offer concrete solutions. He views Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa as a reformist within the royal family, while hardliners led by Prime Minister Khalifa bin Salman oppose dialogue, fearing concessions would encourage more demands. Salman noted a prior seven-point agreement with the Crown Prince for a constitutional monarchy, which ended when GCC troops were deployed in March 2011. He expressed hope for US Secretary of State John Kerry to pressure for human rights, criticized the UK for only using private pressure instead of public statements, and reiterated al-Wefaq's call for peaceful demonstrations despite bans. He also demanded the release of 13 opposition leaders sentenced on torture-obtained evidence, stating their exclusion would cause dialogue to fail.

Christopher Hogwood died at his home in Cambridge after a months-long illness, with a private funeral and later memorial service. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, directing it for 30 years across six continents and producing over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. His famous recording of Handel's Messiah (1980) was named one of the top 20 recordings of all time. Hogwood was a leading figure in the early-music movement, influenced by his studies with notable musicians, and held academic roles including at Cambridge, Harvard, and Cornell. Colleagues praised his generosity, role as a founder of historically informed performance, and his legacy of mentoring musicians who now lead orchestras worldwide.

Homicide victims in Scotland numbered 57 for the year to March 2016, down five from the previous year and the lowest since 1976, half the figure of nine years ago. Only one case from 2015-16 remained unresolved as of March 2016. Sharp instruments, primarily knives (51% of cases, 29 total), were the most common method. 31% of accused were under alcohol/drug influence. The 2014-15 homicide count was initially reported as 59 but later revised to 62 after reclassification. Scottish Labour cautioned against the statistics, noting previous revisions and increases in sexual crime (45-year high) and violent crime (27% rise in attempted murder and serious assault).

Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland, becoming the first team to defeat them in the Premier League this season. Sunderland scored through Victor Anichebe and Jermain Defoe's penalty, while Bournemouth failed to equalize after Steven Pienaar's red card. Manager Eddie Howe stated they created enough chances to win three games but failed to score.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott stated that stopping boats carrying migrants was necessary to prevent deaths at sea, describing Australia's policy of detaining boat arrivals and processing them offshore as effective. The New York Times criticized the policy as "brutal," "inhumane," and "dubiously legal," urging European leaders not to adopt it. Abbott also drew criticism for comparing Islamic State to Nazis, claiming IS "boasts about their evil" while Nazis "had a sufficient sense of shame," which Australian Jewish groups called "injudicious and unfortunate" due to the fundamental difference between ISIS terrorism and systematic state genocide. Abbott later maintained his comments were not about "ranking evil."

The US suspended bilateral talks with Russia over Syria, blaming Russia and the Syrian government for intensifying attacks on civilians, including bombing Aleppo and targeting hospitals.
