Russia regretted the US move, accusing it of shifting blame for the truce collapse and failing to separate jihadist groups from the moderate opposition. Aleppo has faced heavy bombardment since the ceasefire ended, with a main hospital hit for the third time in a week, hundreds dead, and 250,000 trapped. Russia denied involvement in a deadly aid convoy strike. The US withdrew personnel for a joint implementation center but both sides will continue counter-terrorism talks to avoid clashes.

Downing Street supported a Policy Exchange report proposing selling vacant high-value social homes to raise £4.5bn annually, sufficient to build 80,000-170,000 social homes. The report argues this would create the largest social housing programme since the 1970s, reduce the 1.8 million social housing waiting list by 500,000, and target expensive properties (21.8% of stock, 816,000 homes). Critics, including Labour, oppose the plan, stating it would displace low-income families from neighbourhoods, create segregation, and worsen the housing crisis. The government stated councils can already choose to sell such properties to fund more housing.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died in Swansea amid a measles epidemic with 942 cases. An inquest will be adjourned for further tests to determine if measles caused his death, as the initial examination could not establish this. Since November, 83 people have been hospitalized for measles. He developed a rash after asthma treatment, saw a GP on 17 April, and was found dead the next morning. Public Health Wales confirmed measles but required more tests for cause of death. His vaccinated daughter and family had no known exposure.
Vincent Hudson, 54, has been charged with a historical offence involving a boy under 16, reported to have occurred in 2001. He is due to appear at North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Gateshead and Guiseley drew 1-1 in a National League match. Guiseley took the lead in the 15th minute through Jake Lawlor, while Gateshead equalized in the 62nd minute via Wes York. Gateshead are unbeaten in five matches, and Guiseley have not lost in nine. The match ended 1-1 with both sides having substitutions and yellow cards.

Bristol Sport Ltd plans to replace two stands to increase stadium capacity, an alternative to a delayed new stadium at Ashton Vale. The project was approved by Bristol City Council in November. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown stated the club will sign a section 106 agreement soon, followed by a six-week judicial review period. If no judicial review occurs by March, redevelopment will begin in May.

Cuadrilla suspended fracking after a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months, to examine data from the British Geological Survey (BGS) before deciding whether to resume. The BGS stated the tremor shared a similar location and mechanism to a 1 April tremor. Fracking involves shattering shale rocks using hydraulic pressure or explosions. The BGS confirmed the latest quake occurred 2km deep near the Preese Hall site, with waveforms matching the April event, noting fluid injection during such processes can cause earthquakes. Cuadrilla's CEO emphasized taking responsibilities seriously by halting operations for consultation. The BGS is monitoring fracking as a precaution, with two small Lancashire earthquakes recorded since March.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old Liverpool bagpiper, was found guilty of one count of fraud for displaying a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner with the eternal flame and "justice" while busking in April 2015, but cleared of two other fraud counts. The Hillsborough Justice Campaign chairman confirmed Carpenter had permission to use the banner design but not to collect funds. Carpenter stated the banner was a tribute to victims, not an attempt to deceive, and he was known as a busker to the campaign. He will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3-0, with goals from Grant Ward, Luke Varney (following a keeper error), and Tom Lawrence. Ipswich rose to 14th in the Championship, while QPR fell to 15th. QPR keeper Alex Smithies' miscued clearance led to the second goal, which Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy noted was pivotal. QPR failed to score and had a late chance when Sandro hit the post.

Wells, 23, scored 373 runs at 28.69 average with a 138.66 strike rate in the T20 Blast last season. He stated the club is progressing well, with the coaching environment fostering elite performance and motivating players to join.

The Reds, fifth in National Two South, secured a 29-12 victory over third-placed Chinnor for their second consecutive win. Coach Churcher highlighted Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams leading the team, with the front row and front five making over 70 tackles. The Reds face seven teams below them in the next eight games plus league leaders Old Elthamians, and Churcher stated the side still needs improvement despite the win.

The police allege 28-year-old Bangladeshi citizen Nazrul (Nazu) raped a 74-year-old nun in Ranaghat on 14 March, following a ransacking and theft at the convent. Nazu was arrested at a Kolkata railway station after fleeing to Bangladesh. This marks the sixth arrest in the case, with police identifying eight suspects (two untraced). Five earlier arrests named Nazu as the rapist. The incident caused nationwide protests in India.
Robert Opie explains how domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports changed UK consumer buying habits, and explores shifting ownership and rankings of major UK brands.

Two elderly women were scammed by callers impersonating BT technical support. The first incident involved a 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills on 15 September, and the second involved a woman in Stranraer seven days later. Both were tricked into granting remote computer access, resulting in financial loss. Police officer PC Siobhan Pellett warned that scammers easily gain computer access, emphasized victims should never share banking details over the phone, and noted that legitimate organisations never request such information.

Duffy, 37, joined Featherstone Rovers on a one-year contract after leaving Swinton Lions, replacing Stuart Littler. He will lead Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Duffy, a former player for Leigh, Widnes and Salford, has a 16-year playing career.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew with a medic and a coastguard search and rescue helicopter responded to Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve at 12:50 GMT Sunday for a rider with head injuries who was very cold from lying unconscious on wet sand. The rider was treated on site before being flown to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

Countries agreed at a UN conference to dedicate radio spectrum for satellite-based real-time flight tracking using ADS-B, following the MH370 disappearance, to cover all airspace (currently 70% uncovered), with ICAO setting a November 2016 deadline for aircraft to transmit positions every 15 minutes or more frequently in emergencies.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five in 2002, was identified as the missing child at age 18 after an FBI tip related to college application issues. He is now living with his father in Cleveland. Bobby Hernandez, 53, was arrested for tampering with records to obtain a driver's license in 2012 and is held at Cuyahoga County Jail in Ohio with $250,000 bail. Authorities confirmed his identity with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, and his mother has been notified of his recovery.

A fire on 2 March on Duncan Street caused travel delays and reduced train services. The Environment Agency revoked Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited's environmental permit, suspending its waste acceptance, effective 7 August unless appealed. The company, operated by Asset and Land Group, was deemed "broadly compliant" with fire safety law by Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service, which visited the site nine times in 12 months. The EA took enforcement action following fire service concerns about impacts on residents, transport, and the environment. The company must still remove all waste, and the fire's cause remains undetermined.

Pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia proposed two bills linked to Ukraine. The first bill would allow Russia to annex territories without a treaty if a region's people express desire to join Russia, referencing Crimea's pro-Russian sentiment and the 2008 Georgia conflict. The second bill speeds up Russian passport issuance for Ukrainians, removing residency, tax, and citizenship renunciation requirements, targeting Russian-speaking Ukrainians amid the Ukraine crisis.

McLaren, a historically dominant F1 team with 182 wins (23.18% win rate), 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently struggling with poor results, including a fourth-row grid position. Their decline began in 2013 after losing chassis design edge, though recent car performance has improved; current issues stem from the Honda power-unit. The team's peak era included 1988 dominance with Senna and Prost (winning 15 of 16 races), followed by Honda partnership successes and a 1998 constructors' title. Past setbacks include a 2007 constructors' championship disqualification due to illegal Ferrari data and the 2009 "lie-gate" scandal. Despite two current world champions (including Alonso), McLaren's recent form is poor, though Ron Dennis insists success is imminent with improved Honda engines and the car's current competitiveness.

Thomas Baker, 44, from Everton, was shot in the head and chest at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on 27 January while getting into his car after leaving Phoenix Gym. He died in hospital. Three Liverpool men (two aged 29, one aged 32) were arrested and remain in custody. Police believe the attackers waited outside the gym for an hour. Detectives are seeking a silver VW Polo that fled the scene and people captured on CCTV near the meat market who have not yet come forward.

The passage describes digital approaches to blending Christmas spirituality with modern technology. Everyday Church Online offers virtual Sunday services streamed globally, with a Star Wars-themed Christmas sermon titled "The Hope Awakens." Guardians of Ancora is a free Bible-based game for children (8-11 years) featuring Christmas quests about Jesus' birth. Viral.de's "The Digital Story of Nativity" uses social media formats (Facebook, tweets) and has nearly six million views. The Churches Advertising Network's ad "Christmas Starts with a Baby's Giggle" (250,000 views) was rejected by cinemas for being "too religious." Next Manga's "Manga Messiah" app/e-book, available in 33 languages including Arabic for refugees, shares the nativity story in manga format. All efforts aim to make Christmas spirituality accessible through digital platforms.

An eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is examining a request to take over 250 hectares of common land. Backers, including Blaenau Gwent council, offered 320 hectares of replacement land. Experts presented conflicting accounts on whether the circuit would damage habitats. Natural Resources Wales stated the replacement land was not of equal value but was not opposing the development. Developers' ecology report claimed a "net gain" in biodiversity through habitat enhancement nearby, which the Gwent wildlife trust opposed. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will recommend a decision after the inquiry, with Welsh government ministers making the final approval.

Chechen Muslim clerics met on 3 April, condemning Novaya Gazeta's 1 April report about over 100 detentions in Chechnya for suspected homosexuality (with at least three deaths) as an insult to their faith, threatening "retribution" against the report's instigators. The newspaper stated this amounted to a call for reprisals against journalists. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report's accuracy, detailing torture of detainees, while Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations, claiming no gay people exist in Chechnya. The mufti confirmed "retribution" was part of the clerics' resolution. Novaya Gazeta's editor vowed to continue investigating human rights abuses, stating they did not intend to insult Chechens.

Investing Solutions, a letting agency set up by Samir Patel in 2002, and Fresh Start Housing, a charity he founded in 2010, operate in the same south London building. Investing Solutions receives housing benefit payments by placing single homeless men (over 35) in properties, charging benefit for each person in a shared house rather than the property, increasing the payout. The agency passes most rent to private landlords, keeping the difference as profit (e.g., £11,568 annual profit on one property). Fresh Start refers clients to Investing Solutions and private landlords. The arrangement is criticized as "a new low" by a homeless group, citing poor housing conditions. Investing Solutions is one of the UK's largest housing benefit recipients, with Wandsworth Council paying over £2.1m in two years. The charity claims it housed 788 homeless people since 2010, but cannot disclose how many were placed via Investing Solutions.

Great Britain lost to the Netherlands in a Eurobasket qualifying warm-up, with Netherlands winning after leading 71-60 in the fourth quarter despite GB's late comeback. Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and Ben Gordon 13 for GB, while Worthy De Jong led Netherlands with 18. Coach Joe Prunty emphasized the need for intensity in qualifiers, stating GB "lost a little of our fire" and must "complete on every play." GB begin qualifiers in Hungary midweek.

Conor McGregor submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) for 8oz gloves in his upcoming 154lb fight against Floyd Mayweather, as NAC rules require 10oz gloves at that weight. The NAC will debate the waiver publicly on 16 August. The NAC executive director, Bob Bennett, stated that while 10oz gloves are standard for 154lb bouts, 8oz gloves may be approved with a waiver if justified for fighter safety. Bennett cited McGregor's UFC experience (using 4oz gloves), his win over Nate Diaz (who is rated an outstanding boxer), and McGregor's physical advantages over Mayweather (younger, taller, longer, granite chin) as reasons to approve the fight. The NAC also confirmed McGregor is cleared to compete after reviewing videos of his progress.

Fleet Street, historically the heart of British journalism since the first daily newspaper, the Daily Courant, was published there in 1702, saw its peak with nearly all national papers operating within a half-mile radius. The Sunday Post's closure of its London office marks the end of an era, as the last two journalists, Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, leave after decades working there. The decline began with Rupert Murdoch moving papers to Wapping in 1986, ending union disputes and leading to most national papers relocating by 1988 due to cheaper computerised printing. Fleet Street's transformation includes former newspaper buildings becoming businesses like Sainsbury's headquarters and Pizza Express, replaced by sandwich bars. Journalists recall its vibrant past with typewriters, pubs, and alcohol-fueled culture, contrasting with its current state. Robin Esser notes Fleet Street's historical importance when newspapers delivered 85% of public information, as television and social media later replaced its dominance. The departure of the last journalists signifies the end of this iconic era.

J.K. Rowling received abusive comments on Twitter regarding her £1m donation to the No campaign in the Scottish independence referendum and her 2008 £1m donation to the Labour party. She stated her "personal line [had] been crossed," refused to "hush up" abusive behavior to protect political parties, blocked users she believed were SNP supporters, and engaged positively with some SNP supporters. The SNP won 56 of 59 seats in Scotland, becoming the UK's third largest party.

Children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action for the same crime compared to better-off children, and poverty increases the likelihood of violence for both boys and girls. A University of Edinburgh study found a history of police trouble was the strongest predictor of not being in education, employment, or training by age 18, and poorer youth were five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision. Extreme poverty increased the risk of being both a victim and perpetrator of crime. Boys were three times more likely than girls to engage in violence, and girls from poorer backgrounds were twice as likely as those from affluent households to be involved in violent crime. Despite Scotland's reported crime rate at a 41-year low, the study found crime remains highly concentrated in the most deprived communities, with half of high-crime areas in the top 20% for chronic health problems and a third in the top 20% for unemployment. Researchers argued this concentration persists despite overall crime reduction, raising questions about whether inequality is being adequately tackled. The Scottish government cited the crime reduction and a £296m investment to address poverty as evidence of progress.

Karl Haugh, 25, was stabbed in a laneway in the Marian estate, Kilkee, in the early hours of Sunday, sustaining a stab wound to the back. He died at Limerick University Hospital at 06:00. Robbie Walsh was charged with assault causing serious harm, remanded in custody until 14 August, and will face trial. Two other men arrested were released without charge. Police recovered a bloodied knife blade and golf clubs at the scene, and alleged a fight involving three men occurred after Walsh and two others entered the estate seeking Haugh.

Sinn Féin MLA Phil Flanagan admitted his tweet accusing Tom Elliott of harassing and shooting people as a UDR member was "untrue and wholly without foundation," requiring a public apology. The tweet, posted in May 2014 and deleted within an hour, referenced Elliott's 10-year UDR service (1982-1992) and his role as MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone. The High Court heard Elliott was alerted to the tweet by campaigners and DUP members. Stormont's insurance firm refused to cover Flanagan for compensation costs, which he is challenging separately. Elliott stated he was "vindicated" but disappointed the case took 19 months to resolve. Compensation amount remains pending.

Hawick Knitwear, employing over 230 staff, has increased weekly sweater production from 7,500 to 9,500 to meet surging demand for its new branded range launched in January and its established private label business. The company, bought by managing director Benny Hartop in November last year, sells across multiple European countries and global markets including the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. Hartop stated the production rise responds to increased orders from home and abroad, and expressed optimism about the future, crediting dedicated staff.

Sylvia Blackburn, 72 and a lollipop lady for 20 years, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by Brian Wright's car while crossing Bedford Road outside Kempston school. Wright, who denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, claimed he was blinded by the setting sun and did not stop for a red light. The victim, who was wearing appropriate clothing and escorting a child, is now in residential care. The trial continues, with Wright expressing remorse.

NATO's "Dynamic Mongoose" exercise focuses on anti-submarine warfare training in response to increased Russian submarine activity in North Atlantic waters. It highlights Britain's significant defense gap: the UK no longer possesses maritime patrol aircraft, a capability formerly provided by the Nimrod, leaving it reliant on NATO allies for surveillance. Russia is expanding its submarine fleet (around 60 submarines, including advanced "quietest" models) and investing heavily in submarine technology, making it a "quietest and most challenging adversary." The exercise demonstrates NATO's concern over Russia's growing military strength and the vulnerability of nations like Britain, which cannot independently detect submarines, potentially allowing Russian subs to track UK nuclear deterrents.

UN officials warn of potential genocide and ethnic cleansing in South Sudan, where ethnic violence has displaced 340,000 people to Uganda—more than Syria's 200,000 refugees in 2016—with 2,500 new refugees arriving daily. The conflict, rooted in a dispute between Dinka President Salva Kiir and Nuer former Vice-President Riek Machar, has seen targeted killings, rape, and ethnic persecution of Equatorians and Nuer. Uganda initially managed the influx well but now struggles as the Bidi Bidi refugee settlement, housing over 250,000 people, expands rapidly. UNHCR officials describe it as a "massacre of civilians" and urge international pressure on South Sudanese leaders to stop the violence.

McKenzie, 38, will fight Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight championship on 12 November at York Hall. He turned professional in 2013 after quitting football in 2011, with a record of eight wins and one draw from nine fights. He is the son of former British and European champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, former three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The new Bridgwater Community Hospital is part of a £330m coalition investment for NHS facilities in England. It will replace the outdated 1813-built current hospital with 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray, and space for mobile scanners. The £33m project's funding comes from the coalition investment, with the remainder covered by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The current building is described as cramped, outdated, and having poor temperature control and high maintenance costs. The new hospital aims to open by autumn 2014 on land at Bowers Lane, pending planning permission.

A man was fatally shot in the chest outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, Sheffield, while in or near his black Mercedes. Police arrived at 13:35 GMT, sealed the area, and the victim died at Northern General Hospital after being taken there. He was a family member living nearby, and the shooting occurred during a family celebration, with relatives attempting to help after hearing the shot. This incident marks the first shooting in Upperthorpe recently, as other shootings in Sheffield have occurred in the north (Shiregreen, Southey Green, High Green) in recent weeks.

Three hacker groups operate in the Ukraine conflict: Ukrainian Cyber Troops (led by Yevhen Dokukin), Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops claim to hack Russian servers, share data with Ukrainian security services, use DDoS attacks as "artillery," disrupt separatist funding via payment systems, and hijack CCTV and printers for pro-Ukraine messages. Cyber Berkut, anti-Western and named after riot police, targets Ukrainian government websites with anti-Western messages, claims to leak military documents, and disrupts elections. Anonymous International publishes Kremlin leaks, focusing on Russian domestic affairs. All groups present as independent of government-sponsored entities, though Ukrainian officials deny using hacked data for military targeting.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick became visibly emotional during farewells by veteran MSPs Duncan McNeil (Labour) and Alex Salmond (former SNP leader and first minister) as they stepped down ahead of the 5 May election. Salmond reiterated Scotland's "diversity, not division" and welcomed the Scotland Bill's power transfers but criticised unionist pledges. He joked about the Cheltenham races and UK budget, concluding with a tribute to serving the parliament and Scotland. McNeil warned Holyrood must improve accountability and scrutiny by learning from Westminster's committee system, expressing sadness that Holyrood now needed to "do a bit of learning from them". Annabel Goldie (Conservative) joked about missing Finance Secretary John Swinney's "faux indignation".

Sarah Rochira, Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is reviewing the quality of life and care for older people in residential care. She will gather experiences from pensioners, families, and friends to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies, focusing on physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Rochira aims to highlight both good care and the impact of poor care, emphasizing resident and family voices. Care Forum Wales supports the review's aims but criticizes the absence of care home experts on the advisory panel, stating it misses partnership opportunities.

Harbro Group reported a £800,000 pre-tax profit increase to £3.5m for the year to June 2016, despite turnover falling £1m to just over £100m. International sales grew in Europe and new markets. The company manufactures animal feeds for beef, sheep, dairy, pig, and poultry sectors and operates 19 Country Store shops across Scotland selling farming and rural products. The company stated the agricultural outlook is difficult to predict, with challenging times experienced recently, but expressed confidence in being well-positioned for Brexit-related business challenges.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted. A man in his 80s was hospitalized. Police are treating the death as murder and seek to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin (also known as Ian John Baker), described as white, 6ft tall, with greying collar-length hair and of average build, believed to have been wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or trousers, and a dark blue/light blue/white checked shirt. Officers urge the public to contact police or Crimestoppers with information and are conducting additional patrols.

David Lipton of the IMF warned of a weakening global economic baseline and a delicate juncture, citing China's sharp export decline (down 25% year-on-year) as a key factor. The IMF plans to downgrade its global growth forecast from 3.4% in its April update, impacting businesses reliant on China's growth story.

The council made the Cowes crossing free until 2 July due to a problematic new ferry that broke down, ran aground, and was suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency over "training issues," causing car damage. Businesses reported losing nearly six months of trade, with compensation under discussion. The council leader called the start "frustrating and disappointing," while a transport councillor stated it was a "prototype" with "teething problems" resolved through electrical fixes, ramp extensions, and seamanship improvements.

A fatal crash on the southbound carriageway near Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott occurred at 07:30 GMT on Thursday, resulting in the death of a 32-year-old man pronounced at the scene. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening for investigation.

Matching Models in London, an agency advertising as "an international temp agency for beautiful and talented people," faced condemnation for job ads specifying physical attributes. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) called its personal assistant ad ("a classic look, brown long hair with b-c cup") "appalling, unlawful and demeaning to women," with chief executive Rebecca Hilsenrath demanding clarification. The Fawcett Society described the ads as "straight out of the 1970s." The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defended the practice, stating "looks are important" and citing a client requiring a "Jackie O" look for a Christian Dior outfit. Another ad sought a "sexy female driver" for £40,000–£50,000 annually. Employment lawyer James Lynas stated such ads are "clearly unlawful," as phrases like "beautiful and attractive" are discriminatory against older women, and male applicants could sue for sex discrimination. The agency's website claimed it is "almost politically incorrect" to request attractive workers, but the EHRC countered that "first impressions count" should focus on skills, not appearance. Under the 2010 Equality Act, specifying physical traits like cup size or hair colour is unlawful unless essential to the job, which the agency failed to demonstrate. Jansen cited other clients' preferences, including hiring blonde, blue-eyed, Greek women and hiring models with tattoos for MTV.

A shooting occurred at a hostel attached to Pragati Residential School in Bangalore. The alleged gunman, Mahesh (an office assistant at the school), shot 18-year-old Gautami in the head on Tuesday evening and injured another student, Sirisha, who is out of danger. Mahesh was arrested on Wednesday after a manhunt and remanded until 12 April. School shootings in India are very rare, as noted in the passage.

GLAAD's analysis of shows from June 2016 to May 2017 found 278 regular/recurring LGBT characters, with transgender characters rising from 7 to 16. Over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters died or were killed off, including Poussey Washington and Bea Smith. The report noted a record high percentage of Black characters on broadcast TV, driven by shows like Empire and How to Get Away with Murder. GLAAD president Sarah Kate Ellis stated progress was "heartening" but emphasized "numbers are only part of the story."

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced his resignation ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be opposed. This follows a BBC report that £10.25m of public money loaned to Northampton Town FC for stadium redevelopment and land development has gone missing, with a police investigation into alleged financial irregularities. The football stand remains half-built. His party's local executive council planned to deselect him, and Mackintosh stated it was time for his constituents to have a new representative, denying any wrongdoing.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old Dallas police officer, shot and killed 15-year-old Jordan Edwards in Balch Springs in April while firing into a car of teenagers leaving a party. Police initially claimed the car reversed aggressively toward him, but video showed it driving forward. Oliver was fired for policy violations, faces murder charges (5-99 years prison) and four counts of aggravated assault, and would be the first Dallas County police officer convicted of murder since 1973 if convicted. He is free on bail; no trial date has been set.

Melania Trump plans to keep her 10-year-old son Barron in New York to finish the school year before moving to Washington, a decision drawing criticism on social media but supported by some as responsible parenting. This is not unprecedented, as only two other First Ladies (Martha Washington and Anna Harrison) did not reside in the White House during their husbands' presidencies. Historically, other first ladies like Grover Cleveland's wife lived elsewhere during their husbands' terms, and the Obamas moved early to avoid school disruption. The passage notes the First Lady's role is ceremonial but has evolved to include advocacy, with Melania indicating her priority is Barron and interest in tackling cyber-bullying, contrasting with predecessors like Michelle Obama who took on prominent causes.

A 72-year-old man died in Inverness on 27 October. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner is investigating the initial police response to his call, with a report to be submitted to the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service.

A yellow wind warning was issued with gusts up to 75mph (120kmph) possible, particularly west of mountains, and an unusual easterly direction could worsen impacts. Travel disruption on roads and at sea is likely across Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion and Powys. A tree fell in Menai Bridge on Anglesey overnight, closing Telford Road, which will remain closed most of Monday for clean-up.

Giants led 2-1 after Forney's powerplay goal, Panthers tied 2-2 via Bohmback. Giants extended to 4-2 with Radja and Desmarais, but Nottingham's Ling made it 4-3. The teams meet again Saturday. Nottingham lead the league with 28 points, Sheffield Steelers 27, Belfast 25.

World champion Lewis Hamilton started from last after a broken front wing and five pit stops, facing a 36-point deficit to Nico Rosberg with 18 races remaining. Sebastian Vettel finished second for Ferrari despite colliding with teammate Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap, damaging both cars; Raikkonen recovered to fifth. Rosberg won the race after Daniel Ricciardo's puncture and Mercedes' strategic decisions. Hamilton's car suffered significant aerodynamic performance loss due to front wing damage, hindering his recovery.

Thomas Hitzlsperger became the first prominent German footballer to publicly reveal his homosexuality in an interview with Die Zeit, stating he aimed to advance discussion on a topic "simply ignored" in German football. His announcement received widespread support from teammates, football administrators, and public figures, including former German FA president Theo Zwanziger and current captain Philipp Lahm (though Lahm had previously discouraged gay players from coming out in 2011). The move was described as a watershed moment in Germany, where homophobia in football had persisted, with support from figures like Gary Lineker, John Amaechi, and German Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesperson. It followed the 2007 outing of second-tier player Marcus Urban, the last German footballer to come out publicly.

Midfielder Sidwell, 34, made 32 Championship appearances to help Brighton achieve promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years. With his contract expiring at season's end, he aims to sign a new deal to stay and help the team remain in the top flight. Brighton, leading second-placed Newcastle by four points, seek the league title in their final two matches. Sidwell, who previously played in the Premier League with Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham, and Stoke, joined Brighton on a one-year deal in June 2016 after a 2015-16 loan from Stoke. He believes his strong performance this season, exceeding expectations, earns him the opportunity to play in the Premier League again.

Blackpool took the lead through Jamille Matt after 12 minutes, but Colchester equalized from a corner. The match ended 1-1 with Colchester reduced to 10 men after Sean Murray received a straight red card in injury time.

The 29-year-old Reid made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season during their relegation from League One. He has previously played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston. Reid could make his debut for Colchester United in the EFL Cup first-round tie against Aston Villa. Colchester started the season with a 3-1 defeat at Accrington.

PC Keith Palmer's murder prompted the UK Police Memorial Trust to seek £1.5m for a permanent memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire, to honour over 1,400 officers and staff who died on duty over 250 years. The government committed £1m towards the £4m project, which includes a brass screen with leaf shapes for families, and is expected to be completed by 2019.

Manchester United remain 15 points clear at the top of the Premier League with eight games left after a 1-0 win at Sunderland. They have 25 wins from 30 matches and 50 of a possible 54 points in their last 18 games, aiming to surpass Chelsea's 95-point record. Manager Ferguson stated they focus only on the next game, the derby against Manchester City, and will make changes for the FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea due to injuries to Rafael, Anderson, David De Gea, and others, with Wayne Rooney, Danny Welbeck, and Tom Cleverley not starting against Sunderland.

Google paid £10m in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011. Eric Schmidt stated the company followed legal tax requirements, asserting taxes are not optional and that tax law changes should be a UK government political decision. He advocated for international tax reform and argued corporate taxes should be levied where economic activity occurs. Meanwhile, Margaret Hodge proposed a committee to oversee major firms' tax arrangements, and EU leaders agreed to automatic tax information exchange to tackle avoidance.

NHS Improvement requires the NHS to reduce agency staff spending from £3.6bn to £2.6bn by year-end, with a 55% cap on shift rates (capped at £76/hr for surgeons, £35/hr for junior doctors) saving £600m so far. Despite progress, trusts remain 10% short of targets, and some hospitals pay double the capped rates. NHS Improvement will publish league tables of agency spending performance and track top-earning agency staff, stating the NHS cannot afford current agency costs.

Longford Town Centre, once envisioned as a "cathedral of commerce," now symbolizes Ireland's economic crash following the Celtic Tiger era. Local trader Matt O'Brien reports a 30% decline in business during the boom but notes recent improvement through new ventures like childrenswear and dress-hire. Fianna Fáil criticizes the government for neglecting the Midlands, citing the IDA's failure to attract foreign investment to Longford for four years. The government points to Center Parcs' planned 200m euro tourism development (1,000 jobs) in Ballymahon, pending planning permission, which Fine Gael TD James Bannon believes will boost tourism. Traders, however, argue more is needed, including free street parking to attract shoppers, as recovery is beginning but insufficient.

The cricket competition ends on 29 May with eight teams playing each other twice, top four qualifying for play-offs. Leading run-scorers: Warner (294), Kohli (267), De Villiers (249). Most sixes: Warner (12), De Villiers (12), Kohli (8). Highest innings scores: De Kock (108), Warner (90*), Gambhir (90*). Top wicket-takers: McClenaghan (9), Kumar (8), Rahman (7). Four England players participate: Eoin Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad), Jos Buttler (Mumbai Indians), Sam Billings (Delhi Daredevils), Kevin Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants).

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported a 200 million increase in plastic carrier bags since 2013. Many non-recyclable bags cause environmental harm by ending up in landfills and rivers. From October, people in England must pay 5p for plastic bags to encourage reuse. Supermarkets in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, where bag charges already exist, have seen a decrease in bag usage, and campaigners hope the England charge will reduce waste.

A wind event caused a school roof to be ripped off in Rhosgadfan, Gwynedd, and led to power cuts for hundreds of homes across Wales. Transport disruptions included train delays, speed restrictions on bridges (A55 Britannia Bridge and M48 Severn Bridge), and Irish Ferries cancelling six sailings between Holyhead and Dublin. Arriva Trains Wales warned of delays, and the National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle. Winds eased by Friday evening, with bridge restrictions lifted, but a Boxing Day event (Rhyl's Dip) was postponed to Tuesday due to blustery weather.

Jordan expressed excitement about a new film project, reuniting with Creed director Ryan Coogler. He mentioned looking forward to working with Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman, who is starring as Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War. The film, Black Panther, is scheduled for release in February 2018.

Founded in 1875, Alexandra Palace's theatre will host performances, cinema, comedy, and live music after refurbishment. Part of a £26.6m east wing restoration project funded by Heritage Lottery Fund (£18.8m), Haringey Council (£6.8m), and a £1m target by Alexandra Palace Charitable Trust, it aims to reopen in 2018. The unused theatre retains original decor and machinery, having previously hosted opera, musicals, plays, and early cinema.

A 30-year-old former Manchester City player earned 61 England senior caps since his 2009 debut, featuring in two World Cups and two European Championships but playing only three minutes at Euro 2016. He also holds the record for most capped England Under-21 player (46 caps from 2004) and scored his only international goal in a 5-0 World Cup qualifier win over Moldova in 2014.

Marcy Smith and her family escaped a house fire in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, with the help of her son David, who woke them when he saw flames. The house was destroyed, and their dog and cats did not survive. The fire started from rubbish burned in the wood stove, something Marcy had done "a thousand times," and the fire alarm did not activate. The family fled in pyjamas, but the community donated clothes, shoes, and a bike. Mrs. Smith stated David's quick action saved them and expressed pride in him for being the reason they survived.

Sullivan and Gold own over 85% of West Ham United after buying a majority stake in 2010 for £105m. A £200m takeover offer from an energy drinks giant was reported, and the club has also been linked with Qatari and Chinese groups. Sullivan indicated a minority share sale might occur to clear debts, but ownership would pass to their children.

The passage describes a fan-voted awards ceremony in Los Angeles, distinct from the Oscars, serving as a promotional platform for summer blockbusters. The Fault in Our Stars won best movie, with Shailene Woodley also winning best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for American Sniper, Channing Tatum won best comedic performance for 22 Jump Street, and Meryl Streep won best villain for Into the Woods. Other winners included Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, and Rose Byrne. Kevin Hart accepted the comedic genius award with his children, and Robert Downey Jr. received the Generation Award with Avengers co-stars. Clips from upcoming films Pitch Perfect 2, Trainwreck, and Ultron were shown.

Smith, 21, was loaned from Aberdeen to St Mirren in July, scoring five goals this season. He made his Aberdeen debut in 2012, scoring four goals in 89 appearances. St Mirren manager Jack Ross described him as a "really good player" and "a good fit" who "gives us another option in the attacking area." St Mirren are the Championship bottom side hosting Falkirk.

Northumberland County Council will use Jetpatcher machines to fill 145 potholes daily over four months now that weather is warm enough, and extra staff will repair drainage systems damaged by heavy rain and clear gutter debris.

Workers on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) during shutdown work in December 2016, without proper personal protective equipment. EnQuest stated the exposure level was less than 1% of reportable limits and reported it to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE), taking additional precautionary steps. The workers, including rigging supervisor Steve Innes, expressed cancer fears and ongoing blood tests, criticizing EnQuest's duty of care. Wood Group confirmed health and safety is a priority, downmanning staff for medical assessments, and supporting a joint investigation. The HSE confirmed the incident was not reportable under RIDDOR regulations.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) returned a Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari bronze sculpture to India after the dealer, Art of the Past, admitted selling stolen Indian antiquities. ACM purchased the artwork for $650,000 in 2007. The Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) requested its return following the dealer's confession to trafficking looted antiquities, including this sculpture allegedly stolen from a Tamil Nadu Shiva temple. ACM noted the dealer's admission of criminal possession of 150 stolen objects, though there is no conclusive proof of the theft. ACM bought 30 objects from the dealer, but only this one is suspected stolen. ACM plans to seek legal compensation for the fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca at a depth of 15.5km, with its epicentre in Garfagnana, at 15:48 (14:48 GMT). It was felt in Milan, Florence, Bologna, and Modena, causing power cuts and phone line outages in Garfagnana, and prompting school evacuations. No injuries or damage were reported. Italy is prone to earthquakes, recalling the 2009 L'Aquila quake (300 deaths) and a 2012 conviction of six scientists and an official for providing "inaccurate, incomplete and contradictory" earthquake risk information before that event.

Austin Grant from Sheffield, a 62-year-old grandfather, expressed joy after seeing results from fruit cultivation in South Yorkshire despite initial doubts about the climate, with the fruit still unripe.

Rockstar delayed GTA V's release from 27 January to 24 March, citing the need for "extra weeks of testing and polish" to ensure the game is "as good as can be." They confirmed online heists will arrive on consoles before the PC release. PC specifications were published, including 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution, and support for triple monitor configurations.

76-year-old artist Simpson won the John Moores Painting Prize £25,000 for 'Squint (19)', depicting medieval church leper squints. After multiple shortlists including 1991, he stated the prize money would fund art materials. The biennial prize, established 1957, has previous winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig.

Two pro-government Turkish newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, were attacked by masked assailants early Thursday in Istanbul. Both buildings suffered shattered windows from gunfire, with numerous bullet casings found at the scenes. No casualties were reported, firefighters extinguished the fire, and police cordoned off the area. The attacks occurred almost simultaneously, with Yeni Akit offices 20km from Yeni Safak. No group claimed responsibility. Both papers support President Erdogan's AK Party, and this follows a similar September attack on pro-government newspaper Hurriyet.

A 24-year-old player, previously under contract with the Stags, joins the Mariners on a free transfer on 1 January after scoring three goals in 23 appearances on loan at Crawley. He becomes Marcus Bignot's first signing for the Mariners.

Arsène Wenger, whose Arsenal contract expires in summer, dismissed speculation about managing England, stating he focuses on his current role. He praised Gareth Southgate, the interim England manager, for his experience and ability to prove himself through decisions, noting Southgate has upcoming fixtures against Scotland and Spain to secure the permanent position. Wenger also confirmed Arsenal will offer Hector Bellerin a new contract, rejecting transfer speculation, and stated Aaron Ramsey will miss one or two more games due to a hamstring injury.

A local man fell from a cherry picker at Fruehauf on Houghton Road at 13:45 GMT Thursday; Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are conducting a joint investigation with the company cooperating fully.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement to resolve a dispute over seafarers' pay on freight vessels serving the Northern Isles. The RMT union had claimed some workers were paid less than £4 an hour. The agreement, effective early next month, will return contracted services to operator Serco Northlink from Seatruck, ending the row. Serco had offered to bridge the pay gap and backdate payments, but Seatruck declined. The new charter ensures all crew will be paid at least the minimum wage. Serco Northlink operates the route under a £243m six-year contract awarded in 2012.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on 14 May following an incident at Rockley Park on 7 May. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted intervening in an argument between Dickie and his mother, causing a confrontation after they had been drinking at a bar. Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault and both he and his mother Samantha, 57, admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying to police about the events. They will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, a British songwriter who died at 66 in London after battling cancer, wrote hits including "Rock With You" and "Baby Be Mine" for Michael Jackson's best-selling album Thriller (32 million US copies), and "Boogie Nights" for his band Heatwave. Nicknamed "The Invisible Man" for his low profile, he also won a Grammy for "Birdland" and was Oscar-nominated for The Color Purple soundtrack. Tributes were paid by Nile Rodgers, LaToya Jackson, and Mark Ronson.

Researchers from Swansea University, Exeter, Reading, and Brazilian universities discovered over 450 ancient geoglyphs in Acre state, western Brazilian Amazon, possibly 2,000 years old. Hidden for centuries under bamboo rainforest, they were revealed by modern deforestation. The earthworks, unlikely to be villages or defensive sites due to few artefacts and layout, are thought to have been sporadically used as ritual gathering places, though their exact purpose remains unclear. Analysis of soil samples (phytoliths, charcoal, carbon isotopes) showed they were built in taller vegetation, not visible above the forest canopy, differing from sites like Maya pyramids or Stonehenge. The research challenges the assumption of pristine pre-European Amazon forests, indicating humans cultivated diverse plant species over 6,000 years through agroforestry focused on economically valuable trees (like palms), creating a "prehistoric supermarket" that may still influence Acre's remaining forest biodiversity.

Australian tennis player Nick Kyrgios, ranked 12th (career-high), defeated world number 29 Sam Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to advance to the second round at the Shanghai Masters. Kyrgios cited fatigue from his recent Japan Open victory and travel to the Qi Zhong Stadium (an hour from Shanghai city centre) as reasons for his subdued performance, mentioning poor sleep and a difficult commute. The passage notes he was fined $1,500 at last year's Shanghai Masters for a foul-mouthed outburst calling the tournament a "circus."

Scientists and charities urge the Welsh government to expand HPV vaccination to include boys to prevent head and neck cancers, as HPV causes 5% of global cancer burden. Current vaccination targets girls aged 12-13 for cervical cancer prevention (85% coverage), but head and neck cancer cases are rising, affecting younger non-smoking men (average age 55). Charities and researchers argue vaccinating boys now would stem cancer cases and show commitment to public health. The Welsh government states it will await recommendations from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before considering changes to the HPV programme.

Jak Trueman, 15, battled gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, documenting his journey on social media via "Jak's Journey," which gained over 28,000 likes. He briefly attended a school prom for 10 minutes before leaving due to illness, apologizing for his short stay. His mother announced his death on Facebook, expressing devastation. Jak had received a Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy at the prom. After doctors confirmed his cancer had spread in January and treatment ended, he urged donations to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research. His story, including visits from footballers and hospital stays, touched many, with a charity football match planned for Sunday.

Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0 with a late goal by El Said assisted by Salah in the 89th minute, securing a chance to play Ghana for Group D top spot while Uganda were eliminated from their first tournament since 1978 after a disallowed goal for offside.

Lancashire County Council has earmarked land at the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College's Westbank campus for a new railway station. The sites were chosen following a Network Rail study. Skelmersdale, designated a new town in 1961 and lacking its own station since 1956, could gain two direct trains to Liverpool per hour under plans with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council. The council will now acquire the land, citing the site's size, highway access, and connectivity as advantages.
Plants were discovered in an elaborate grow house during a Saturday morning warehouse search near Ashbourne, leading to the arrest of a man in his late 40s.

A 28-year-old unidentified Kurdish-German woman was found with serious injuries on a pavement in Hamelin after being dragged by the neck through streets. She underwent emergency surgery and was flown to a specialist clinic. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old Kurdish-German man from Bad Muender, turned himself in. Police stated the motive for the attack is unclear and are seeking witnesses.

Women ask for pay rises as often as men but are 25% less likely to receive them, according to a study of 4,600 workers. The research debunked theories that women avoid requesting pay rises due to reluctance to upset bosses or conform to stereotypes, finding no gender difference in asking rates when comparing like-for-like workers. It also noted equal pay rise success rates for women and men under 40, suggesting changing negotiation behavior.

Oxford City Council has conducted ground investigations for new burial sites but found no suitable land within Oxford due to factors like site size, ground conditions, water table, or land covenants. Two remaining cemeteries (Wolvercote and Botley) will be full by 2018 and 2021. After these are exhausted, only family plot reopenings, reserved plots, and ashes interment will be possible. The council continues searching but has run out of suitable land, with the last burial space increase occurring in 1932.

Visitors to the Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) in Stornoway (19-22 July) can use an app to access online information, videos, and band interviews via signs and posters. The festival features acts including The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. Director Caroline Maclennan stated the augmented reality app enhances local enjoyment and allows global audiences to experience the festival's atmosphere.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day and was pronounced dead following treatment. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed he suffered a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage," an incident described as rare and occurring in horses with no underlying health issues. Despite previous symptoms of post-race ataxia (overheating and wobbling) in past races, he showed no such symptoms on the day of the incident. Many Clouds had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014, and was described by his trainer as the "horse of a lifetime."

A 15-year-old girl met David Ayrton (now Davina, 34) in a Portsmouth garage in autumn 2004. The defendant denied raping the teenager while two friends slept, with the victim stating she had consumed only a can and a half of Foster's and clearly recalled the events. Judge Ian Pearson remanded Davina in custody for sentencing on 4 March, stating she would likely be held in a male prison due to risks of self-harm and failing to attend court, noting she has learning difficulties and attempted suicide last summer.

The Serbs lost 6-4 6-4 to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio. This loss followed Djokovic's singles defeat by Juan Martin del Potro. Djokovic, world number one and 12-time Grand Slam winner, had previously lost to Sam Querrey at Wimbledon in July before winning a Masters title in Toronto ahead of the Olympics.

Over 20 competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US will participate in a chainsaw carving competition in Carrbridge, Cairngorms. Only chainsaws may be used to carve logs into animal and human shapes. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, returns to defend the title and the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, 27, suffered a serious foot injury in a September World Cup warm-up against Italy and has not played since. He is close to returning, aiming to be fit for the Six Nations starting 7 February, having requested and received permission to move his expected return date up by a couple of weeks. He has renewed his dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down offers from elsewhere to stay with his home region, where he debuted in 2007, stating he wants to be in the best position to play for Wales.

US border agents intercepted two men carrying 58lb (26kg) of MDMA near Sumas, Washington, on Tuesday morning. One man, Nathan Hall, fled after firing at agents, was later arrested in Canada. Jeffrey Laviolette was detained immediately. A woman, Kali Henifin, and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, were arrested for planning to transport the drugs; Lambert was to be paid $11,000. The backpacks contained ecstasy and a fake California driver's license with Hall's photo. The area is a known smuggling route for drugs and firearms.

Childline counselled over 4,500 children for online abuse in the past year, up from 2,400 in 2011-12, with victims as young as seven experiencing torment and fear. Childline's president warned cyberbullying follows children home, urging adults, parents, and schools to intervene as bullying worsens without action. The report coincides with Anti-Bullying Week.

Israel's government postponed a vote on 492 new settlement homes in Jerusalem at Prime Minister Netanyahu's office request to avoid straining US relations ahead of Secretary of State Kerry's speech. This followed the US abstention on a UN resolution condemning Israeli settlements as illegal and a major obstacle to peace, which Israel rejected, particularly over East Jerusalem. Netanyahu also recalled ambassadors from the US and 14 UN Security Council countries, cut aid to Senegal, and canceled a Ukrainian prime minister's visit in response to the resolution.

Queen Elizabeth II celebrated her 90th birthday with events including a visit to Windsor's Royal Mail office marking the postal service's 500th anniversary, a ceremony opening a new bandstand in Alexandra Gardens, and unveiling a plaque for The Queen's Walkway. Prince William described her as a "guiding example" of a monarch, emphasizing her service and commitment, while addressing recent criticism about his own engagement with royal duties. Ten commemorative stamps were released, featuring four generations of the Royal Family, with six additional stamps honouring her family life and official role. The celebrations included lighting beacons across the UK and globally, and a lunch with US President Obama. A republican group criticized the BBC for excessive coverage.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2-0 in the EFL Cup, with Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew scoring before halftime. Cheltenham, a League Two side, made no changes from their previous league match and failed to test West Ham goalkeeper Adrian. The result ended League Two's representation in the EFL Cup. West Ham made seven substitutions following recent Premier League losses. The two teams' previous meeting four years ago was a 2-1 win for West Ham at Upton Park.

Hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl, 36, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion after Andreas Werner, 46, failed to spot the motorcyclist while turning his VW Transporter right. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates' Court, receiving a £1,000 fine and a two-year UK driving ban. The victim's family accepted it was a momentary lapse and saw no value in jail, with Werner described as remorseful by his defence.

Imran Khawaja, 27, from Southall, London, is a British jihadist who joined the Islamic State-affiliated group Rayat al Tawheed in Syria, using the alias Abu Daigham al-Britani. He was active online, creating propaganda videos, appeals for donations, and "through the keyhole" tours of fighters' quarters. He was involved in gruesome content, including a photo showing him holding a bag containing a severed head. Khawaja returned to the UK in June 2023, faking his death online to conceal his return. He was arrested at Dover with the help of his cousin, Tahir Bhatti, who admitted assisting an offender. Khawaja faces a possible life imprisonment for his role in Syria, having admitted four offences. He was held in a high-risk terrorism unit at Belmarsh prison. The most serious charge, soliciting to murder, was dropped.

Jackson, 22, scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season as they finished eighth. He has joined Barnsley as their third signing for next season, having rejected a Wrexham contract offer. Barnsley caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom praised Jackson's pace and ability to beat defenders, stating he will fit the team's style.

Bottles washed ashore at Poldhu Cove and nearby Cornish coves including Gunwalloe, Polurrian, Church Cove, and Marazion are being cleared by National Trust volunteers due to risks to wildlife. The bottles, sealed but some leaked, are suspected to originate from a container lost from the MV Blue Ocean near Land's End in May during stormy weather, though the Maritime and Coastguard Agency states no evidence confirms this link. The National Trust and Cornwall Wildlife Trust express concern over detergent entering the marine environment, noting most bottles are full. Cornwall Council advises the public to keep children and dogs away from the bottles and not attempt recovery.

An incident occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at 14:00, with several people receiving minor injuries. The road was closed with diversions via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road, and Police Scotland stated inquiries were ongoing.

Dervite, 28, made 14 appearances last season to help Bolton finish second in League One and secure promotion. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014, making 83 appearances in all competitions. Manager Phil Parkinson noted Dervite was a "forgotten man" who made an "excellent contribution" towards the end of the campaign. Dervite is the fourth player to sign a new contract with Bolton following promotion, joining David Wheater, Gary Madine and Jem Karacan.

Lib Dem Lord Oates accused Labour of conceding everything, while Labour's Baroness Smith called Lib Dems' actions giving "false hope." The two parties had previously cooperated to defeat the government on EU citizen rights and Brexit parliamentary approval, but this alliance collapsed when MPs rejected the amendments. Labour accused Lib Dems of "grandstanding" for campaign leaflets, while Lib Dems accused Labour of "waving through the government's plans" and supporting hard Brexit. Despite a history of cooperation on issues like education and housing, a Labour source predicted "residual tensions" and no future joint events, with Lib Dems stating they would continue working across the House on agreed issues.

Defense is a low priority for UK political parties and voters, ranking below economy, NHS, and immigration. Military cuts have reduced the regular Army to 82,000, the Navy to 19 warships, and the RAF to seven front-line squadrons, creating capability gaps. UK defense spending is projected to fall to 1.5-1.7% of GDP (below NATO's 2% target), with £25bn needed over five years to maintain 2%, but no major party plans to protect defense spending. Key disputes include Trident nuclear renewal (Conservatives/UKIP want full replacement, Labour proposes three submarines, SNP/Greens seek abolition) and the risk of a "hollow force" due to insufficient personnel for new carriers and equipment.

Barcelona denied wrongdoing regarding Neymar's transfer, stating they paid £48.6m initially (57m euros) for the 22-year-old striker, with total costs reaching £106.8m including fees, wages, and agents. They made an additional tax payment of €13,550,830.56 to address potential interpretations of tax obligations, while denying tax-related crime. A Spanish judge found sufficient evidence to continue investigations into the transfer, and former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid unrelated money misappropriation accusations. Neymar has scored seven league goals in 18 appearances and three in seven Champions League matches this season.

Michael Luciw, 27, died in a motorway crash when a van he was in was hit by a Mazda driven the wrong way by Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died. Luciw's family and colleague Andy Harrington, who sustained serious injuries, called for mandatory driving tests for older drivers, citing slower reactions with age. Age UK stated it is vital for older people to drive safely for as long as possible to maintain independence. Current UK rules require drivers over 70 to self-assess every three years for licence renewal without a medical or driving test, and the DVLA stated evidence does not show older drivers cause more serious accidents.

Many women questioned the safety of transvaginal mesh implants after suffering debilitating side effects. Two patients quit an independent review group in protest over a "watered-down" report. Professor Alison Britton will examine the review process and lessons learned. The report concluded mesh procedures should not be offered routinely for pelvic organ prolapse, recommending a range of treatments with informed choices and mandatory adverse event reporting. The government confirmed recommendations would continue despite calls for a ban, stating it lacks power to ban procedures (the UK regulator has that authority). Review chair Tracey Gillies apologized for failing to achieve consensus, admitting her task was "almost mission impossible." Two patients resigned, claiming parts of the report were removed. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have received mesh/tape implants, with more than 400 currently taking legal action against health boards and manufacturers.

Laura Muir, 23, broke Eilidh McColgan's 25-year-old British 5000m record by 14 seconds with a time of 14:49.12 in Glasgow. McColgan initially questioned if the race met UK Athletics criteria for record ratification, citing it was not a "genuine race" as Muir was the only competitor for the full distance and drug testing concerns. British Athletics confirmed the time would be ratified as official, noting no drug testing was required for non-doping-controlled events. McColgan praised Muir's potential, stating she could run sub-14:30 and was world-class, comparing Muir's race to her own record-breaking run 25 years ago where she lapped Paula Radcliffe. Muir also holds the British 1500m record and reached the 2016 Olympic 1500m final.

Jung won the equestrian event aboard Sam, a late replacement after Fischertakinou contracted an infection. France's Astier Nicolas took silver and American Phillip Dutton won bronze. GB's William Fox-Pitt finished 12th, competing just 10 months after a fall left him in an induced coma; he led after dressage but dropped to 21st due to cross-country time penalties, despite a faultless show-jumping performance. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth.

Andy Murray defeated Italy's Fognini 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5 in a four-set match lasting two hours and 39 minutes to reach the last 16 for the 11th time. Fognini had five set points to force a fifth set but Murray won five consecutive games to secure victory. Murray will face Benoit Paire in the fourth round. Fellow Briton Johanna Konta also advanced to the second week with a win. Murray described the match as tense, particularly in the fading light, and noted he felt he didn't move as well as in earlier matches but is pleased to progress.

Paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar, Dungiven, on 6 October 2014. Police found people present after alcohol was served until 04:49 BST. The judge ordered the bar closed for three months and fined Colleen O'Neill £3,000 for two counts of allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours (as license holder), and James Thomas £1,000 for one count. The judge described O'Neill's record as "appalling," stated the case was "as bad as I have come across," and expressed concern he could not impose a custodial sentence.

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionist Party, stated "Domination doesn't work, partnership does" in his manifesto launch speech. The party seeks an election referendum on the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal, but focus shifted to Nesbitt following his comments. He denied regrets about his remarks, stating he "wouldn't withdraw a word" and preferred forming a government with the SDLP over Sinn Féin. Nesbitt expressed confidence in his position after door-knocking in unionist areas, framing the election as a referendum on "incompetence, arrogance, cronyism and the strong whiff of corruption" in Stormont. The manifesto, titled 'Real Partnership', includes pledges on waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers to 7,500, prioritising the York Street interchange, supporting the LGBT community, and guaranteeing no group is worse off due to Brexit.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden confirmed a motion for the assembly to approve pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences, aligning Northern Ireland with England and Wales' 'Turing's Law'. The motion will allow posthumous pardons and enable living gay and bisexual men to apply for pardons, securing executive agreement to ensure equal treatment with England and Wales.

Laura Muir, 23, finished second behind Faith Kipyegon in 4:19.12, breaking Yvonne Murray's 1994 Scottish record (4:22.60) and moving to second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd (4:17.57). She now holds the Scottish 1500m and mile records. Muir, who finished fifth at last year's World Championships, aims to secure an Olympic spot at the British trials in June. She recently won an 800m in France and will race in Stockholm next.
The passage presents pictures of 26 Scottish beaches ranked as Scotland's "most excellent" for water quality.

Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC stated the Russian state likely sponsored Alexander Litvinenko's 2006 London murder via polonium-210 poisoning, rejecting personal motives for suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi. Litvinenko, a defector who criticized the FSB and Putin, died after drinking poisoned tea and was poisoned twice. Horwell concluded Russian state involvement was the only credible explanation, though Putin was not implicated. Extradition attempts failed, with suspects remaining in Russia, and public radiation risks from the polonium remain unknown.

Steve Smith, 26, is appointed captain of Australia's one-day and Twenty20 teams in place of injured Aaron Finch, with David Warner, 28, as vice-captain. This follows Michael Clarke's retirement after the Ashes defeat. Smith, who previously captained in three Tests against India, has played 32 Tests scoring 2,952 runs at 54.66. National selector Rod Marsh praised Smith as the right choice and noted Warner's maturity and development into a senior team figure despite past disciplinary issues. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test.

Mr. Farron, leader of the Liberal Democrats, stated he is "passionate about LGBT-plus rights" and that defending equal marriage would be "at the top of my agenda," including extending marital rights for transgender people due to the "spousal veto" issue. He refused to answer whether he believes homosexual sex is a sin, saying "my firm belief is we are all sinners." While he voted against the 2007 Equality Bill due to concerns about "protection of individual liberties," he clarified he is "a liberal and I absolutely support equality" and "in favour of equal access under law for all people whatever their sexuality."

French-based Sanofi closed its Fawdon drug manufacturing site in 2015, resulting in 450 job losses. Accord Healthcare will use the plant for pharmaceutical production, aiming to rehire many former Sanofi staff. Accord's investment is expected to have an "extremely positive" impact on the area, strengthening Newcastle's reputation in the science and healthcare sector. Accord develops, manufactures, and distributes over 130 pharmaceutical products to about 60 countries globally.

Richard Ellis is leaving at the end of his contract, while Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland are departing under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Ellis was the council's former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive; Monaghan was head of the chief executive's office, and Sutherland was head of human resources and customer services. SNP group leader Stephen Flynn stated the departures indicate the council's inability to retain senior staff and expects further departures. Council chief executive Angela Scott thanked the trio for their "dedication and professionalism."

Militants armed with guns and grenades entered Sardar Daud hospital after detonating explosives at the gate, opening fire on staff and patients. Commandos killed all four attackers after several hours. IS claimed the attack; the Taliban denied involvement. Over 50 people were wounded, and President Ghani condemned the assault as "trampling all human values." The attack began at 09:00 local time, with one attacker described as wearing a white coat holding a Kalashnikov. This marks IS's first direct attack on security forces in Kabul, shifting from previous targeting of civilians and Shia gatherings. IS has claimed multiple attacks in Afghanistan since 2015, including a Kabul rally bombing (80 killed), Ashura attacks (30 killed), a mosque attack (30+ killed), and a Supreme Court attack (22 killed). The Taliban also carried out recent suicide attacks in Kabul.

English rider Martin crashed at this year's TT and faced mechanical issues with his Fireblade bike. He clarified on Facebook that he is not quitting racing but has no plans for further road racing on Hondas this year. He missed the North West 200 after his teammate's practice crash and will not compete in the Ulster Grand Prix, stating the bike was non-competitive. Martin described the TT as a "bloody disaster," felt reduced to a test rider, and stated there is "no unfinished business," planning to race "classics and oddball stuff" instead.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 governor posts in Nigeria's elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999. The PDP, which lost the presidential election to APC's Muhammadu Buhari, won eight governorships mostly in the southeast and held Rivers State (oil hub), but lost key northern states including Katsina, Kaduna, and Adamawa (affected by Boko Haram). The APC failed to win any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, a concern for Buhari. The PDP's decline was attributed to voter desire for change, corruption allegations, defections to APC, and failure to address the northern insurgency. Elections saw 66 violent incidents, mostly in southern states, but were more peaceful than previous years. The PDP will become a regional party, while the APC controls most northern states and Lagos.

Mighty, a US environmental group, accuses Singapore-based Olam and its stakeholder Temasek of enabling unsustainable palm oil practices contributing to Southeast Asian haze through third-party sourcing. Olam sources 99% of palm oil from third parties, claims <1% of global market, and states it enforces a "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" policy. Olam and Temasek deny the allegations, with Temasek stating it does not direct Olam's operations. Mighty alleges Olam created a "secretive market" for rogue suppliers and that Temasek's investment links Singapore to haze. The report also claims Olam bulldozed Gabon rainforests for palm oil plantations, which Olam denies, stating its Gabon operations are "responsible and transparent." Both companies reject the accusations, while Mighty maintains the palm oil industry has a "troubled track record" regarding environmental practices.
A restaurant began serving puppy platters on 27 August 2016 after a new law allowed dogs to eat at restaurants outdoors. The offering was described as "a right dog's dinner."

Forward Fernando Forestieri (knee) is doubtful after only playing from the bench in the last two games. Derby County striker David Nugent (groin) could return after missing Monday's draw. Midfielder Jacob Butterfield is hoping for a recall following his late goal against Huddersfield.

Pakistan's telecom regulator lifted the YouTube ban after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority confirmed internet providers were directed to restore access, with the PTA stating Google provides a direct process for requesting removal of offending content. YouTube denied authorities could filter content and clarified government requests for removal would not be automatic, requiring adherence to community guidelines and a review process. The ban, imposed in 2012 following protests over the film "Innocence of Muslims," had been lifted as Google introduced local YouTube versions for Pakistan, Nepal, and Sri Lanka. Activists sought transparency about the agreement terms, while the government noted blasphemy laws remain in place.

Domenico Scala, head of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee and Swiss-Italian, faces a dispute over his potential conflict of interest as Gianni Infantino, a presidential candidate, shares his nationality. Musa Bility, Liberia's FA boss, demands Scala withdraw by Thursday, citing Article 7.4 of the Electoral Regulations requiring committee members with conflicts to step down, as Scala did in the 2015 election when Sepp Blatter (Swiss) was the incumbent. Scala's spokesman argues there is no conflict now as there is no incumbent president, and the 2015 withdrawal was voluntary. Bility threatens to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw, emphasizing the need for fairness in the upcoming election on 26 February. Five candidates are running: Infantino, Prince Ali, Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman, and Tokyo Sexwale. Bility, ineligible to run himself, has pledged his vote to Prince Ali.

Daniel Timbers (29) and Barry Joy (56) were killed in a flashover explosion at Harford Attachments in Spar Road shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday while working in a paint-spraying area. The explosion resulted from a build-up of toxic fumes combined with an ignition source, causing a fire-ball effect. Their bodies were removed on Tuesday afternoon, and a forensic search is ongoing, with the Health and Safety Executive gathering evidence.

Tunisia avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after apologizing to CAF for complaints lodged during the 2015 tournament. Morocco entered the 2017 qualifying draw following a Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturn of their ban, imposed after they withdrew as 2015 hosts due to Ebola fears. Cas later reduced Morocco's fine from $1 million to $50,000. Tunisia's dispute arose from a contested penalty in their 2015 quarter-final loss to Equatorial Guinea, which they contested without accusing CAF or the referee of corruption. Both nations resolved their issues with CAF after meetings, allowing Tunisia to participate in 2017 and Morocco to qualify. Tunisia will face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, while Morocco faces Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F.

Chelsea won 3-1 against Manchester City at Etihad Stadium in a match ending in a mass fracas. Sergio Aguero received a four-match ban for violent conduct (his second this season), and Fernandinho received a three-match ban. Cesc Fabregas will face no further action.
