Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's involvement, and both clubs must respond to the charge by 18:00 GMT on 8 December.

Wales has high cancer mortality rates compared to other developed countries. A pilot programme in Cwm Cynon and Castell-nedd focuses on patients with no clear symptoms but suspected cancer, who face long diagnosis delays as they do not fit standard referral pathways. Currently, only 35% of high-risk symptomatic patients receive diagnosis in Cwm Taf. The pilot aims for 40 GPs to refer such patients to a diagnostic centre within seven days, targeting six patients weekly for same-day testing. Similar clinics will open in Castell-nedd Port Talbot. The initiative, developed after a visit to Denmark's system, seeks earlier diagnosis to improve outcomes. If successful, the six-month pilot will be expanded across health boards.

England won by a large margin at Old Trafford to level the series against Pakistan, scoring 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared for their second biggest win over Pakistan. Joe Root was man of the match with 254 and 71 not out, plus four catches and a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root's "extraordinary" and "most controlled" innings. Pakistan struggled, batting only 63 and 70 overs, with their spirit described as "broken" by Geoffrey Boycott; only captain Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passed 50 in the first two Tests. Misbah called it a "big disappointment," citing poor shot selection and low confidence, while Pakistan prepare for a tour game before the next Test.

Warren Gatland leads the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand with Rob Howley named as interim coach. Forwards coach McBryde assumes head coach responsibilities for the third time, having previously led Wales tours in 2009 and 2013. The Welsh Rugby Union is appointing assistant coaches for the summer tour and expects to confirm the full management team next week. WRU chairman Gareth Davies states Welsh coaches' involvement will benefit Welsh rugby long-term.

Hull City defeated Southampton 2-1, ending a six-game losing streak. Charlie Austin scored a sixth-minute penalty for Southampton, but Hull responded with two quick goals: Robert Snodgrass scored from a cross and assisted Michael Dawson's header. Hull goalkeeper David Marshall made crucial saves, including a last-minute goalline clearance by Sam Clucas. The win, Hull's first since 20 August, leaves them in the bottom three. Hull lost starting strikers Abel Hernandez and Will Keane to first-half injuries, but Snodgrass, returning from an ankle injury, sparked the comeback. Southampton manager Claude Puel cited lack of concentration after a Europa League match as a factor.

A motorcyclist died in a crash at 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton near Woodhall Spa, Lincolnshire. The motorcyclist lived locally but no further details were released. The tractor driver involved was unharmed. Lincolnshire Police appealed for witnesses and closed the B1191 in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

President Ivanov canceled an investigation into abuse of power claims revealed by covert recordings, stating he aimed to "put an end to the agony" ahead of June elections. This move was condemned by the opposition leader Zoran Zaev, who called it illegal and organized protests, and by EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn, who stated it violated the rule of law and jeopardized Macedonia's EU membership. The crisis stemmed from covert recordings (released since February 2015) allegedly showing ministers plotting vote-rigging, covering up a murder, and wiretapping 20,000 people including politicians and journalists. Zaev claimed the recordings revealed high-level corruption, mismanagement, and cover-ups, which the government denied, accusing him of destabilizing the nation.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will manage Swansea's next match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's sacking. Swansea aim to appoint a new manager quickly, with Paul Clement as the preferred choice. Curtis believes the club needs someone to prevent relegation, noting the Championship's increased strength and difficulty returning to the Premier League, especially compared to clubs like Newcastle. Swansea, promoted in 2011 after avoiding bankruptcy and near-relegation in 2003, has lost its identity ("Swansea Way") since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014, according to Curtis, who cites frequent management changes and inadequate player replacements. He asserts the current squad is capable of staying up and ensures new signings learn the club's history through the documentary "Jack to a King," emphasizing the importance of avoiding relegation for both the club and the local area.

Dagenham & Redbridge were relegated to the National League after a 3-2 loss to Leyton Orient, with Armand Gnanduillet scoring the winning goal. The defeat ended their League One survival hopes. Dagenham, managed by John Still, had the worst goal difference in League Two and struggled offensively, with Jamie Cureton scoring only nine goals this season compared to 20 in the 2014-15 campaign. Leyton Orient's victory kept their play-off hopes alive, leaving them two points from the play-off spots. Still confirmed his commitment to promotion from the National League next season.

Steven Gerrard, 36, will return to Liverpool as a youth coach in February, marking his first role since retiring as a player. Jurgen Klopp described the appointment as "wonderful news," noting Gerrard aims to become a manager and is preparing through his Uefa A coaching licence. Gerrard, who debuted for Liverpool in 1998, retired after a 19-year career following his departure to LA Galaxy in 2015, having won the Champions League, Uefa Cup, FA Cup, and League Cup three times. He previously considered the MK Dons managerial role but felt it was "too soon."
Morton defeated Alloa with goals from McManus (twice), Forbes, and Johnstone, after Alloa's McAusland scored before halftime.

Ofsted found children taught in squalid conditions at three closed Birmingham schools, with illegal school operators facing up to 51 weeks in jail. Ministers are consulting on stricter regulation for places teaching over 6-8 hours weekly. Ofsted visited 18 unregulated schools (mainly in Muslim communities in the Midlands), closing three in Birmingham; Sir Michael Wilshaw warned these cases are the "tip of the iceberg" and children risk abuse or radicalisation. Places teaching over 20 hours weekly must register, but some "flexi schools" exploit home education laws to operate illegally. The government funded six inspectors to investigate illegal schools, and the education secretary plans prosecutions, stressing regulations apply to all religious groups.

Lilliard Gin is based at Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, part of proposals for the Scottish Borders' first whisky distillery since 1837. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes describes it as a small-scale operation fitting in a cowshed, using local Borders botanicals to capture the region's "terroir." The gin's name honours Lilliard, a legendary heroine of the 1545 Battle of Ancrum Moor near the distillery, reflecting the landscape and the female production team. It complements the on-site Scottish Borders Brewery.

Harry Whitlam died in August 2013 after Gary Green reversed a vehicle into him on private farm land at Swithens Farm, Rothwell. Green was over twice the legal drink driving limit (equivalent to 13 pints of beer) and was jailed for 16 months and two weeks. Prosecuted under health and safety legislation (not road traffic law) due to the location, Green admitted failing to ensure others' safety. Harry's mother stated the family was "changed forever," emphasizing the tragedy of drunk driving and the enduring loss of her son. The Health and Safety Executive described the case as "extremely tragic" and Green's behaviour as "reckless."

Luis Suarez's four-month FIFA ban for biting Giorgio Chiellini has been reduced by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS), allowing him to train with Barcelona, play in friendly matches, and attend promotional activities. He remains banned from competitive matches, including the remaining eight games of his nine-match ban, with his competitive debut likely in the El Clasico against Real Madrid on 26 October. Suarez is available for Uruguay's friendlies against Japan, South Korea, and Saudi Arabia. CAS confirmed FIFA's sanctions generally but ruled preventing training was "excessive," while FIFA's union Fifpro expressed disappointment. Suarez has a history of similar incidents, including previous bans for biting and racial abuse.

Richard Blake-Smith and Anna beat Lithuanian competitors Vytautas Kirkliauskas and Neringa Kirliauskiene in a 380-metre race involving hurdles over haystacks, a steep slope, and dodging water pistols. They trained for a week on their local athletics track. The race allowed all combinations of competitors (men carrying women, men carrying men, and one woman carrying a woman), not requiring marriage. Rich and Anna will compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

The paper car tax disc system will end in October 2014, replaced by an electronic payment system using monthly direct debit. Stephen Hammond stated job roles at the DVLA may change due to reduced refunds and the withdrawal of tax discs, but any reductions in staff numbers will be managed through redeployment to other business areas, avoiding redundancies. DVLA employees were reassured by this approach, as confirmed by Swansea East AM Mike Hedges.

Hungary refuses to change its asylum, NGO, and higher education laws despite EU objections, claiming they fall under national competence. The EU opposes these laws, particularly the higher education law that could close Central European University (CEU), founded by George Soros. Hungary has secured Poland's backing to veto any EU move to strip its voting rights, as EU rules require unanimous approval for such actions. The government insists it will not backtrack on the laws, while EU institutions warn of potential action.

Emma Watson stars as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, Josh Gad as LeFou, and Kevin Kline as Maurice in Disney's 2017 live-action Beauty and the Beast film, directed by Bill Condon, with filming beginning in May at Shepperton Studios and a US release on March 17, 2017.

Journalist Adrian Gill died after a cancer diagnosis, described as "a giant among journalists" and "the heart and soul" of the Sunday Times by editor Martin Ivens. Gill, who had dyslexia and dictated his copy, was known for his "dazzling and fearless" writing and controversial style, including remarks about the Welsh, Rhyl, and the Isle of Man. His final column about his diagnosis was published in the Sunday Times.

Mongolian rapper Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar (known as Amraa), performing in Ulan Bator, was assaulted after wearing a red deel (Mongolian robe) embroidered with a swastika. The swastika is a traditional Mongolian symbol predating Hitler, not a Nazi hate symbol. Sukhbaatar's father stated he spent 10 days in a coma with serious head injuries from being hit with a metal object. The Russian embassy called local press reports "distorted" and confirmed an investigation. A Russian diplomatic officer, the alleged attacker, was not arrested as the injuries were deemed not serious, not due to diplomatic immunity. Sukhbaatar's lawyer, father, and band member denied reports he shouted "Heil Hitler." The swastika is also used by Mongolia's far-right groups.

Plane Stupid campaigners protested against airport expansion on the northern runway at 03:30 BST on Monday, resulting in charges of aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area; they will appear in court on 19 August, and the Metropolitan Police stated security at the airport would be reviewed.

Nick Selman scored a century (101 off 144 balls), his second first-class hundred, to dominate Glamorgan's innings after returning to form following low scores. Seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took regular wickets in cloudy conditions. Gloucestershire struggled in their innings, with Aneurin Donald's 36 the next best score. Glamorgan secured a consolation bonus point. Michael Hogan led Glamorgan in Jacques Rudolph's absence due to a neck problem. The day ended with the match evenly balanced.

Craig Hughes, 33, of Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after making online threats to the Hope Line Crisis Centre. He admitted planning to make a false police report to lure officers to the Dee Estuary, where he intended to shoot them while drunk. Hughes, on bail for firearms offences (later cleared), had a 2009 firearm conviction. He faces sentencing next week after admitting two charges at Mold Crown Court.

Surrey scored 255-7, with Davies and Ben Foakes sharing a 130-run partnership. Yorkshire chased but collapsed after Stuart Meaker took three wickets in nine balls, including Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance. Yorkshire were all out for 236, losing to Surrey. Surrey's win prevented Yorkshire from reaching Lord's for the first time since 2002. Surrey skipper Gareth Batty praised Davies and Foakes, while Yorkshire captain Alex Lees said his team "haven't been good enough" in crucial moments.
A 56ft converted trawler 6 miles west of South Stack reported a pump failure unable to handle water ingress at 07:00 BST. The RNLI lifeboat crew placed a pump and towed the vessel to Holyhead.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old Scottish middle distance runner, will miss the Commonwealth Games due to university exams conflicting with the event in April. She is completing her veterinary medicine studies, returning to university next week to finish her final year. Muir recently achieved fourth and sixth place finishes in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, setting a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 in the 5,000m. She expressed disappointment at missing the Commonwealth Games but prioritized her degree, stating she has "two, even three more Olympics" left. She is targeting the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential competition.

Liverpool are significantly behind title contention this season, aiming only for a top-four finish to secure Champions League qualification. Their decline stems from losing Luis Suarez (sold) and Daniel Sturridge (injured), leaving ineffective strikers (Balotelli, Lambert, Borini) who lack goal-scoring ability and work-rate compared to last season. They have drastically reduced first-half goals (4 in 10 games vs. 59 last season) and lack intensity, with midfield runners rarely supporting the striker. Defensively, despite spending on Sakho and Lovren, they remain inconsistent and lack a leader, though defensive stats are unchanged. Set-piece goals have dropped sharply. Savage predicts a loss against Chelsea, who are "on a different planet," and highlights Steven Gerrard's mental battle to maintain his career after his infamous slip against Chelsea last season, noting his continued importance to Liverpool despite his age and recent struggles.

A £45m educational facility at Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock will house primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council seeks permission from the McIlvanney family to name the campus after William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock and was passionate about education. McIlvanney, who became a full-time writer in 1975 after teaching English, gained recognition with his first novel *Remedy Is None* and earned the title "Godfather of Tartan Noir" for works including the *Laidlaw* trilogy, *Docherty*, and *The Big Man*. He was also a poet, journalist, broadcaster, and influential contributor to Scottish political and sporting life. McIlvanney died on 5 December at his Glasgow home.

An area near Gourock's swimming pool was evacuated, with residents within 500m advised to stay indoors near walls. An exclusion zone remained on the river and sea (half a mile) after a British sea mine from the 1940s/1950s was discovered. The mine's deterioration meant it was moved for safe disposal, causing ferry disruptions. Authorities stressed the evacuation was precautionary with no immediate danger.

UK Sport has cut funding for several sports including badminton, archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby, with cycling losing over £4m. Total funding for 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports is £345m, £2m less than Rio. Badminton, which won bronze in Rio, had its funding removed despite meeting its medal target, causing strong criticism from officials. UK Sport prioritised funding to protect medal potential, setting Team GB targets of 51-85 Olympic and 115-162 Paralympic medals for Tokyo. New sports for Tokyo include baseball/softball, karate, skateboarding, and Para-badminton, with £9m still to be allocated.

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth's East Cliff conservation area will be demolished to build a six-storey, 90-room hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks (122 units). Councillors voted 7-3 in favour, prioritising tourism and improved elderly living, despite objections from English Heritage, 49 residents, and the Ancient Monuments Society. English Heritage stated the development would cause "severe harm" to the conservation area, while the council argued the old hotels were no longer functional. The East Cliff Project LLP applied for the development, which received 246 supporting letters.

Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, a soldier with the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was punched and beaten unconscious outside Brecon bar The Cellar while returning to barracks after training. CCTV showed the attack, after which Jake Vallely, 24, dragged Boyd's body away. Vallely, who had been on a seven-hour drinking binge and boasted being "the hardest man in Brecon," will be sentenced on 8 December for manslaughter. Aaeron Evans was cleared of involvement as he was not present during the violence. Boyd's family described him as an "all-rounder" with a "promising career" cut short, stating Vallely created a "void" they will "never be filled" and that the community's support made them "the strongest people in Brecon." Police called the attack "despicable" and urged avoiding violence.

Voters were turned away from all 155 Barnet polling stations on election day due to missing names on the poll list, causing widespread disenfranchisement. Chief executive Andrew Travers left by mutual agreement following the error. An independent investigation into the issue has been launched, with a review concluding by May-end. The council apologized, offered emergency proxy votes, and Deputy chief executive John Hooton will temporarily take over. Travers blamed electoral registration lists, and the investigation will also examine arrangements for the EU Referendum.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1. Josh Gillies scored first for Gateshead with a free-kick, Sean Newton equalized for Wrexham before half-time, and Ryan Bowman scored the winning header in the second half. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his team's improved second-half performance, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment with his side's second-half decline.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 measures social and economic welfare for those over 60 in 96 countries, with Norway ranking first and Afghanistan and Mozambique ranking last.

The OneWeb satellite network will initially deploy at least 600 spacecraft, potentially expanding to over 2,000, to provide global broadband coverage including to every school. Airbus is manufacturing satellites using high-volume, low-cost assembly lines inspired by automotive production, targeting three satellites per shift for under $1 million each. The first 10 satellites are scheduled for launch in April 2020, with launches continuing to reach 300 satellites by late 2020, 600 by 2021, and over 800 by mid-decade using Soyuz rockets. OneWeb has secured $1.7bn in equity and aims for debris mitigation by de-orbiting satellites within two years, with backup systems for failed de-orbiting. The project is registered in the UK's Channel Islands, with the UK Space Agency as the licensing authority.

Scottish Finance Minister John Swinney stated UK government spending cuts would reduce Scotland's discretionary budget by 12.5% by 2019-20 compared to 2010-11, with 4.2% of that reduction occurring by 2019-20. He asserted schools, hospitals, and police would not face cuts, citing recent improvements in these areas. The UK government countered that Scottish funding would increase by £390m next year.

Changing Places toilets provide essential enhanced facilities for people with severe disabilities requiring two carers or hoists, featuring 12 square metres of space compared to standard accessible toilets' 3.3 square metres. With 893 currently installed in the UK, they are not yet mandatory in building regulations despite recommendations since 2009. Campaigners, including Lorna Fillingham and Mike LeSurf, argue that over 250,000 people need these facilities as standard accessible toilets fail to meet their needs, causing isolation and stress. Advocates push for compulsory inclusion in larger buildings like shopping centres and stadiums, noting that current recommendations are often ignored by designers. Businesses like Arsenal FC have successfully implemented them, reporting positive public reactions.

Italian consumer organisations filed a formal complaint with the European Commission against McDonald's, accusing it of forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees, preventing them from switching to competitors through long contracts, and leasing premises at above-market rates. McDonald's stated it shares risks and rewards with franchisees, calling the approach successful. The SEIU and European unions support the antitrust complaint, arguing McDonald's abuse of market position harms franchisees, consumers, and workers. The European Commission will study the submission, which claims franchisees' higher costs lead to poorer consumer choice and higher prices. Franchisees own 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe, and McDonald's earned $9.27bn in franchised restaurant revenues worldwide in 2014.

A 13-year-old from Donaghadee, County Down, Joshua Martin, was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve, leading to the discovery of a large primary cancer and five smaller growths during an appendix operation. His family received global support through a social media campaign starting with the #prayforjosh hashtag on Facebook and Instagram, initiated by Bangor Elim Church where his father works. The campaign went viral, with 948 shares and over 79,000 views, prompting a mystery donor to erect a large billboard with the hashtag in Holywood. The support, including widespread use of the hashtag on Twitter by his classmates, has drawn worldwide attention to Joshua's recovery.

The UK government announced the closure of Brecon Barracks, a historic military site since 1805, which MP Chris Davies condemned as "abhorrent" and disrespectful to its military history. Davies launched a petition, citing high local unemployment and potential harm to military tourism, though civilian and military jobs at Brecon are not at risk. Other closures include Cawdor Barracks (2024) and a Sennybridge storage depot (2025), while a specialist light infantry centre will open at St Athan. Labour's Nia Griffith supported restructuring but warned of livelihood impacts.

The passage discusses the UK fishing industry's position in Brexit negotiations. Fishing regions voted heavily to leave the EU, and the House of Lords report warns these communities risk marginalisation despite the industry contributing only 0.5% of GDP and employing 12,000 people. While the industry argues Brexit offers control over UK waters and potential to become a leading fish-exporter, the report highlights risks: shared fish stocks with EU states require continued market access to the EU (which may involve allowing EU boats in UK waters), and leaving the EU could create four separate fisheries management regimes (England, Wales, NI, Scotland). The industry expresses optimism following a recent EU quota agreement, seeing Brexit as an opportunity for fairer catches and sustainable management, though the report stresses the need to retain scientific quota setting and international cooperation.

Edward Snowden, a 29-year-old former CIA technical worker, revealed himself as the source of leaks about US surveillance programs. The NSA accessed vast amounts of data including chat logs, phone records, social media, and internet searches via a program called Prism, which allegedly provided "backdoor" access to servers of nine major tech companies (Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, Facebook, etc.), though these companies denied involvement. The US government confirmed requesting millions of Verizon phone records. Officials like NSA Director Keith Alexander claimed the surveillance protects national security, while critics like Snowden and experts argued it violates privacy. The US Patriot Act allows access to European data stored in the US, raising international concerns, with the EU seeking more details. Privacy International stated the program allows the US government to access global data with no recourse, and Snowden stated he leaked the information due to concerns about "horrifying" surveillance practices.

OpenAI, backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, aims to advance AI for "positive human impact" without financial constraints. It states AI should benefit humanity broadly and safely, while acknowledging risks like AI being an "existential threat" per Musk and Hawking's warnings about AI outpacing human evolution. The venture expects only a tiny fraction of its $1bn funding to be spent in the next few years.

L/Bdr Parkinson, seriously injured in a 2006 Afghanistan bomb attack, carried the Olympic torch on 26 June despite his brain injury affecting speech but not personality or humour. He walks with crutches, spends 12 hours daily on gym and rehab, and raises funds for military charities as patron of the Pilgrim Bandits. His Facebook profile, limited to 5,000 friends, received thousands of requests, with his page getting 19,000 hits on one update, overwhelming his mother who described the support as "phenomenal" and "buoyed up" him. Facebook suggested he create a public page instead of a personal profile. He was one of 8,000 people carrying the Olympic flame during its 8,000-mile journey to the London Games opening on 27 July.

The 2011 US poverty rate was 15%, affecting 46.2 million people, remaining flat after three prior years of increases. Real median household income decreased by 1.5%. Income inequality, measured by the Gini index, rose by 1.6%, the first annual increase since 1993. The poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. The percentage of Americans without health insurance fell to 15.7% from 16.3%. Poverty reached a record high of 15.1% in 2010.

Jos Buttler, 25, signed a new deal with Lancashire until 2019 after moving from Somerset in 2013. As a short-format specialist, he scored England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball ton. Cricket director Ashley Giles praised him as one of the game's most talented players, highlighting his role in Lancashire's T20 Blast final win and his positive influence in the dressing room. Buttler, currently playing in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians, will return for Lancashire's T20 Blast home game against Durham.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates (HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall) are moored in Portsmouth Harbour. Bidders had until 23 January to express interest, with no preservation proposals submitted. Bidders are finalizing bids, viewings are scheduled for late February and March, and a final decision is expected in spring. The government's Disposal Services Authority aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess industry capacity, while MP Penny Mordaunt prefers one to be converted into a reef for tourism. The Type 22 frigates were designed as anti-submarine ships but evolved into versatile combatants with significant weapons systems and command capabilities. The Ministry of Defence states it will consider all options for the best financial return for taxpayers.

Racial and political tensions since 1987 have driven repeated instability in Fiji, including a 1987 coup by indigenous Fijians, a 2000 coup led by George Speight holding the Indian prime minister hostage, and a 2006 military takeover. These events harmed the economy, particularly tourism, and led to Fiji's 2009 suspension from the Commonwealth. After agreeing to elections in 2012, Fiji regained Commonwealth membership in 2014. Indigenous Fijians now form a small majority after thousands of Indo-Fijians fled due to coups, with minimal social mixing between the groups. Fiji's economy relies on sugar, tourism, mining, and services but faces persistent deficits and high aid dependence.

Syria missed the deadline to hand over its chemical weapons stockpile, with Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad attributing the delay to attacks on shipments by "terrorist groups" during transport. Syria possesses 1,300 tonnes of chemical weapons, with only 30 tonnes (4%) having left the country as of the report. Russia set a 1 March deadline for transferring weapons to the coast, and the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons acknowledged delays due to security concerns. Mekdad stressed Syria's commitment to fulfilling its obligations under UN and OPCW agreements. The passage also notes Syria's denial of rebel control over Aleppo's central prison and its criticism of US condemnation of barrel bomb attacks in Aleppo.

The Booker Prize shortlist for 2014 features six authors: Bharati Mukherjee (The Lives of Others), Howard Jacobson (J), Ali Smith (How To Be Both), Joshua Ferris (To Rise Again at a Decent Hour), Karen Joy Fowler (We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves), and Richard Flanagan (The Narrow Road to the Deep North). This is the first year the prize is open to all English-language authors regardless of nationality. Mukherjee's book is the 5/2 favorite to win, with Fowler's novel being the best-selling at over 55,000 copies since March. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall.

PJS, a celebrity with young children and a public figure spouse, is appealing an Appeal Court ruling lifting a media ban on his identification in England and Wales. The Supreme Court will hear arguments about granting his appeal to maintain the ban. The case involves alleged extramarital activities since 2009, including a three-way encounter in January, with the Sun On Sunday seeking to publish the story. The Appeal Court previously lifted the ban, stating the allegations were too widespread for confidentiality, and an interim injunction remains until the Supreme Court's next hearing.

Fosse Park near M1 junction 21 opened in 1989 and was bought for £345.5m. New owners plan improvements to parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of units, addressing the park's "tired" condition and aiming to enhance the city gateway view.

Disney's "Beauty and the Beast" faced controversy in Malaysia over a gay moment involving LeFou, leading to a content review and approval with a minor edit by the Malaysian Censorship Board despite homosexuality being illegal in the Muslim-majority country. The film was held for release, with cinemas offering refunds for advance tickets, and the tourism minister called the ban "ridiculous." The director described the moment as "exclusively gay," and critics labeled the review "stupid and laughable."

Landlords in Southampton letting properties to more than three unrelated people must obtain an HMO licence costing £1,000, facing fines up to £20,000 for non-compliance. The council estimates 1,500 unlicensed HMOs exist, with tenants reporting concerns about eviction and poor maintenance. Licensing applies to specific areas (Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling under Designation 1; Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, Bassett under Designation 2), while nationally mandatory licensing typically covers three-storey properties with five or more unrelated occupants. Council enforcement has resulted in one firm and 13 individuals being prosecuted.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny (Fine Gael) and Micheál Martin (Fianna Fáil) aim to avoid a second election. Fianna Fáil will facilitate a minority government but not support a programme for government. Water charges are the main sticking point, with Fianna Fáil demanding immediate removal and Fine Gael supporting their retention. Following the election, Fine Gael has 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and Labour 7, with no party able to form a majority government and TDs failing to elect a taoiseach.

The Sorrento ferry caught fire on a car deck 27km from Mallorca while traveling to Valencia, leading to a full evacuation. At least three people were injured, one seriously, and passengers were rescued by another ship and transferred to the Puglia ferry. The ship may sink in its current position, and rescued passengers were en route back to Palma de Mallorca. The fire's cause was unclear.

The Electoral Commission reported 38 MPs highlighted cases of potential double voting, a criminal offence, with duplicate applications estimated at 30-70% in different areas. A record 46.8 million people were registered to vote in the 8 June election (500,000 more than 2015), with 68.7% turnout, the highest since 1997. Over 4.9 million applications were submitted online between December 2016 and 22 May, but the net increase in registrations was only 1.4 million, indicating significant duplicates. Electoral registers are unlinked across councils, preventing cross-checking and causing administrative burdens. The Commission recommends better system integration, clearer online verification, and a pre-election choice for those registered in multiple constituencies. Labour warned against restricting registration for young voters and students, stressing that while double voting in general elections is illegal, some legally register in multiple places for local elections.

Lawrence Phillips, 40, died by suicide early Wednesday. A former University of Nebraska star and NFL player for the St. Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers until 1999, he had a history of legal troubles. After his NFL career, he was convicted of assaulting teenagers by driving into them and assaulting a former girlfriend, leading to a 30+ year prison sentence. While serving time, he was placed in solitary confinement after being accused of killing his cellmate, Damion Soward. A judge found sufficient evidence to try him for Soward's death. His former Nebraska coach, Tom Osborne, described him as intelligent with good qualities but unable to overcome anger issues.

Private Derby XXX, a ram serving as the Mercian Regiment's mascot, was promoted to lance corporal in Chester after eight years, awarded by Brigadier Andrew Williams for "good behaviour." He is the 30th in a lineage dating to 1858, when the first Private Derby joined the 95th Regiment of Foot. Derby XXX joined the regiment in February 2014, holds an army number, receives pay for rations, takes holidays during mating season on Chatsworth Estate, and has participated in events including switching on Ashbourne's Christmas lights and meeting Prince William at a 1914 Christmas Truce memorial unveiling.

Liverpool secured a 4-3 comeback victory against Borussia Dortmund in the Europa League, overcoming a 3-0 deficit to reach the semi-finals and move closer to Champions League qualification. The win, sealed by Dejan Lovren's injury-time header, drew comparisons to Liverpool's 2005 Champions League final comeback. Manager Jurgen Klopp transformed doubters into believers through the match, invoking the 2005 Istanbul victory and emphasizing relentless effort. The match featured intense atmosphere at Anfield, including a Hillsborough memorial and extended rendition of "You'll Never Walk Alone." Klopp's philosophy of never giving up was embodied in the comeback, with goals from Divock Origi, Philippe Coutinho, and Mamadou Sakho. The victory solidified Klopp's identity at Liverpool, though defensive vulnerabilities remain.

The EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee met in London, with UK government minister Mr Davis committing to regular monthly updates for Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland via a "two-way information flow" to share analysis and allow devolved administrations to voice views. Mr Russell (Scottish government) welcomed the process but stressed the UK government must provide greater clarity on strategic intentions, particularly regarding EU market access, stating single market membership is "essential for Scotland's economic prosperity." The UK government hopes to overturn a High Court judgment on triggering Article 50 via the Supreme Court, while the Scottish government will oppose this appeal.

A University of Nottingham study monitors 13 cloned sheep, including four (Daisy, Debbie, Denise, Diane) cloned from the same adult ewe as Dolly the sheep, to investigate if cloning causes premature aging. The sheep, now 9-10 years old, undergo rigorous health checks focusing on osteoarthritis, cardiovascular disease, and diabetes—co-morbidities linked to aging. This research addresses concerns raised when Dolly died at 6.5 years from a lung virus and arthritis, which suggested possible accelerated aging. Current results indicate the cloned sheep are in good health, with no evidence of premature aging, potentially resolving key questions about cloning safety.

Shutter Speed won a race, beating Vintage Folly by a length and three quarters, and will go to Chantilly for the French Oaks instead of the Epsom Oaks. Enable and Coronet are top contenders for the Epsom Oaks. Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes. Trainer John Gosden is concerned about ground conditions for his colt Cracksman in the Dante Stakes and will walk the course before deciding whether he runs. Gosden stated Shutter Speed is "top drawer" and will be better on better ground, and he has a month to prepare her for Chantilly. The Dante Stakes is 16 days before the Derby.

The pound fluctuated against major currencies, initially slipping then recovering before falling again, with the dollar at $1.4226 (down 0.2%), euro at €1.2605 (down 0.6%), and yen at 151 (down 1%). The volatility index reached 2008 crisis levels amid falling Remain vote chances (down to 68.5% from 80%), with polls showing Leave ahead and analysts warning of heightened sterling volatility. Asian stock markets fell sharply (Nikkei down 3.5%, Hong Kong down 2.5%), while the FTSE 100 ended down 1.1%. The Leave campaign claimed the pound had strengthened since March, though the text describes recent declines.

The Iron are sixth in the National League, one point and one place outside the play-off spots. They lost to Barrow, who extended their unbeaten league run to nine games. Manager Cowley acknowledged the challenge following a long journey and early goal concession but remained positive, stating their achievements have been "nothing short of remarkable" and emphasizing they are a part-time team embracing their "toughest challenge to date." Braintree's losing run extended to three games.

Starting April 2015, Northern Ireland councils will gain full responsibility for planning decisions, replacing the Planning Service. Currently, councils advise but the Planning Service makes final decisions on developments like new houses or extensions. Supporters, such as Michael Corr of PLACE, view this as a democratic opportunity for councils to shape community development. Critics, including Friends of the Earth, warn of risks of discrimination in planning decisions, similar to 1960s housing allocation protests, and potential conflicts of interest due to close developer-politician relationships. They stress the need for strict transparency and a code of conduct to ensure fairness. Some local politicians oppose the change, citing concerns about donor security and the irrelevance of the £7,500 donation disclosure limit.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot twice in the shoulder and once in the left back leg (requiring amputation), surviving "incredibly lucky." Found injured on 14 March by owner Sarah Nisbett, the cat is learning to hop. Nisbett stated the gun was powerful enough to penetrate the leg and expressed concern about children in the housing estate being at risk from crossfire. The Scottish SPCA urged finding the responsible person and highlighted the need for urgent airgun licensing to prevent further harm. Last year, 87% of respondents opposed Scottish government's air weapon licensing consultation, calling it "draconian" or "heavy-handed," though the proposed scheme required legitimate reasons for ownership. The SPCA reiterated that a licensing regime would help trace irresponsible users.

Liverpool signed Belgian striker Christian Benteke from Aston Villa for £25m, making him the club's second most expensive signing. The transfer, triggered by a release clause, is part of Liverpool's seventh summer signing following Raheem Sterling's £49m sale. Benteke, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa, joins to address Liverpool's goal-scoring struggles last season (only eight league goals from strikers). Manager Brendan Rodgers aims to revive the attack with Benteke, who previously helped Villa stay in the Premier League and reach the FA Cup final after recovering from a World Cup injury.

The study commissioned by Tablets for Schools found no clear evidence of academic improvement from tablet use in schools. It surveyed 671 schools, showing tablets are used in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools, with 9% having one device per pupil. While researchers cannot link tablets directly to improved results, head teachers report positive impacts including increased motivation for disengaged pupils and greater family involvement when devices are taken home. Tablet usage is rising rapidly, expected to nearly double from 430,000 to 900,000 devices between 2014 and 2016, and a separate literacy study noted touchscreens particularly aided boys and poorer pupils in reading. The study also revealed 25% of secondary pupils in tablet schools described themselves as internet "addicts," with two-thirds taking devices to bed for social media or videos.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs spanning the 1880s to the 1990s, capturing children's lives and illustrating social history in Liverpool. It shows changing childhood experiences, including special occasions and child labor, while balancing both positive and challenging aspects of childhood as curated by Kay Jones.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has left Barrow by mutual consent to join National League rivals, having previously played for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy; he may face his old club on 18 February. Striker Keating, 21, joined on recommendation from Micky Adams after spells at Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, subject to international clearance. Manager Kevin Nicholson described Anderson as a leader-type and Keating as young, raw but incredibly hungry. Torquay United (the Gulls) are four points above the relegation zone but have won only one of their last six games.

Bolivia's new law permits 12-year-olds to work with parental consent, justified as reflecting the country's poverty, while setting a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide. Over 500,000 children already work in Bolivia, often in hazardous conditions. The law, signed by Vice-President Garcia Linera in President Morales' absence, aims to address poverty but conflicts with the International Labour Organisation's recommendation of a minimum working age of 14 for developing countries. The ILO is studying whether the law breaches international child labour regulations.

Rosie O'Donnell, 50, experienced a heart attack she described as a "widow maker" after developing chest aches, nausea, and fever following helping a woman in her car. She researched women's heart attack symptoms online, took aspirin, and saw a cardiologist the next day, who inserted a stent for a 99% blocked artery. O'Donnell did not call 911 but warned readers to know symptoms and heed their instincts. She recently hosted "The Rosie Show" on OWN, which was canceled in March due to low ratings.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a boy from Harrow, was stabbed in an alleyway on Belvedere Way, Kenton, at around 00:30 GMT on Saturday evening during a party. He was pronounced dead about an hour later. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and treated in hospital, remaining in stable condition. Police stated the party was well-run with appropriate adults present, and Che was not involved in an initial altercation with youths denied entry but was targeted later. A 21-year-old man was arrested on suspicion of murder, two boys aged 15 and 16 were arrested and bailed until mid-December on suspicion of murder, and a 14-year-old was held on suspicion of possessing an offensive weapon.

Denmark reorganized cancer diagnosis after poor survival rates, implementing three routes: fast-track for "alarm" symptoms with strict time targets; diagnosis centres for undiagnosed cases (covering over 25% of cancer cases) with a 30-day investigation rule; and "yes-no" centres for minor symptoms (detecting 1% serious cases quickly). This reduced waiting times, improved survival rates without overloading the system, and Wales is studying the model for potential adoption.

Following the UK government's decision to disband the OFT, Powys council will replace it to regulate estate agents, receiving £170,000 annually to issue warnings and banning orders for dishonest agents or breaches of estate agent laws. Local authorities will handle complaints but refer cases involving breaches of the Estate Agents Act to Powys.

NHS Employers approved a plan to reshape the 1.3 million-strong NHS workforce after a Nuffield Trust review found examples of nurses filling in for doctors and pharmacists for GPs. The review highlighted that reshaping staff roles makes sense due to changing care needs focused on long-term conditions like diabetes and heart disease, rather than curing illnesses. With doctors making up only about one in 10 of the workforce, more needs to come from other health staff, but funding is required. Unions warned against using the reshaping as a quick fix for NHS staffing shortages, stressing that it should not compromise doctor training quality or be funded by cutting support for existing staff. NHS Employers and the Nuffield Trust see opportunities in improving patient care and staff roles, while the British Medical Association and Unison emphasized the need for proper funding and cautioned against substituting doctor expertise.

Avon and Somerset Police closed Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place after a 03:00 GMT crash, causing rush hour disruption to commuters and bus services until the closure lifted at 14:00 GMT. Investigations into the collision are ongoing. First Bus reported partial service resumption but stated full normal operations would take hours, with hopes for a full service by the evening commute, thanking the public and staff for support.

NRW estimated the Swansea tidal lagoon would cause 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout to die annually during migration, based on "best available evidence." TLP disputed these figures, claiming they lacked "clear scientific basis" and that NRW refused to share its methodology, calling the estimates "unrealistic and grossly misleading." TLP cited its own expert modelling showing a worst-case fish mortality of 2%. The £1.3bn project is a test bed for larger lagoons in Cardiff, Newport, and Colwyn Bay. The UK government is reviewing the scheme's viability. Wales' Environment Secretary supports the project but seeks urgent clarity on the UK government's position. NRW strongly disagreed with TLP's criticism, stating it shared methodology with independent and technical experts and has "utmost confidence" in its evidence.

Northern Ireland's agri-food industry, supporting nearly 100,000 jobs, will establish a new industry-led marketing body developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board. DETI Minister Arlene Foster announced the move, stating it will provide strategic leadership for marketing activities and improve coordination, similar to Scotland Food and Drink. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the announcement as positive for export-led growth but noted potential implications for other organisations.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a tree-planting event at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley to plant 40,000 native trees, commemorating the estimated 40,000 people from Ireland who died in WW1. This project, part of a four-year UK-wide initiative aiming to plant "millions" of trees, uses the pledge "We will stand for those who fell." The public is invited to participate, with saplings provided, and the wood will feature wildflowers including poppies, creating a living tribute for future generations to walk, relax, and reflect. The location is seven miles outside Derry city.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for her book "Someone Else's Skin," a thriller addressing domestic violence and honour crime featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome. Ann Cleeves, festival chair, praised it as "so finely written and tightly written" with strong atmosphere and plotting. Sara Paretsky received the outstanding contribution honour for her 23-year career creating the female detective VI Warshawski, described as a "game changer" who "really changed the way that readers thought about female writers" and co-founded Sisters In Crime.

Santner, a left-arm batsman and spinner who debuted in Test cricket in 2015, broke his finger in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016, causing significant impact on the team's season. Director of cricket Steve Rhodes stated there was "unfinished business" with Santner, as his absence was a major blow to qualifying hopes. Santner will rejoin Worcestershire after June's ICC Trophy in England, expressing frustration over the injury but optimism to "make up for lost time." Worcestershire also signed Australia's John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring, 47, was unlawfully killed in 2008 in Kiev when a speeding car with stolen licence plates struck him while he attempted to hail a taxi on a dual carriageway. The coroner, Dr Elizabeth Earland, recorded an unlawful killing verdict, citing circumstantial but overwhelming evidence, including the car not braking or stopping, Barry's lowered guard due to inebriation, and the wife Ganna Ziuzina's suspicious actions: claiming his assets days after his death, selling his car, moving funds, having an affair, and being a lap dancer (not a teacher as claimed). Ziuzina, 19 years younger, was not present at the inquest. Ukrainian police closed the inquiry but relaunched it as a murder case in 2011; it remains active but not actively pursued.

Charlie Fearns, a boy from Merseyside ill since age three, requires urgent experimental T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital after three relapses and failed UK treatments left him with "no option" for further care. His parents, Sophie and Rob Fearns, were "heartbroken" by the first transplant failure and "overwhelmed" by an anonymous donor who paid for the treatment, resolving their financial struggle and allowing treatment to begin soon.

Apple introduced two-factor authentication for iCloud to prevent unauthorized access to user data, following reports that third-party software like Elcomsoft's forensic tool had been used to steal celebrity photos from iCloud. The security measure requires a four-digit code sent to a trusted device or phone after entering a username and password on a new device, blocking access without it. It remains an opt-in feature, though experts recommend making it default. A 14-character recovery key allows account access if a trusted device is lost, but experts warn it is easily forgotten or stolen. Apple's changes prevent Elcomsoft's software from accessing backups, as confirmed by the software's developer. Apple plans to more aggressively encourage users to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

Dan Groves stated the finer details of a potential deal where Wright could buy 20% of Billericay are pending, with The Sun reporting Wright will become a club director. Billericay are eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points from a play-off place. Wright, a 30-year-old former I'm A Celebrity contestant, played non-league football for clubs including Lewes and Crawley Town. The club was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who confirmed investing £10,000 weekly, and they signed Paul Konchesky in March.

Mr Ashley must respond by 21 March to a letter from MP Iain Wright, chair of the Business, Innovation and Skills select committee, regarding a BBC investigation into his Derbyshire company's warehouse working practices. The committee requested a public meeting at Shirebrook, which Mr Ashley has not accepted despite offered dates. The committee warned failure to attend could lead to contempt proceedings. Sports Direct has not commented on the BBC's request, though it previously pledged to review worker rights under Mr Ashley's oversight.

The report "Putin. War," initiated by murdered opposition politician Boris Nemtsov and completed by colleague Ilya Yashin, compiles facts from 2014 Crimea annexation and eastern Ukraine conflict to accuse President Putin of waging war for personal gain. It claims Russian regular troops and equipment, not just "volunteers," secured key rebel victories in Donetsk and Luhansk, with soldiers admitting Russian generals directed operations. Evidence includes soldier testimonies, documented military units, weaponry photos, and a cost of 53bn roubles. Russian salaries for fighters reach $2,000-3,000 monthly. Despite existing media coverage, the report faces distribution challenges due to publisher reluctance and limited public interest, as many Russians accept Moscow's support for separatists. The opposition views the conflict as Putin's tactic to boost failing popularity, similar to Nemtsov's earlier unheeded reports.

Craig Nelson (also Craig Preston), 34, from Wath-Upon-Dearn, died from head injuries after being found at Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. South Yorkshire Police arrested a 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman in Sheffield, who remain in custody.

Carwyn Jones, Welsh First Minister, complained he did not see the Article 50 letter before publication and was not invited to contribute to its drafting, calling it unacceptable and reflecting a lack of respect for devolved administrations. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns defended the UK government, stating discussions about the letter's contents had occurred over months and Wales was mentioned in the letter. Prime Minister May's letter stated the UK government expected a significant increase in decision-making power for devolved administrations, but did not specify which powers (e.g., farming, economic aid) or confirm if funding would follow. Jones fears no funding will accompany powers after 2020, while Cairns avoided answering questions on funding. The specific powers to be devolved remain unclear.

Two cars were damaged in Newry's Nursery Drive and Parkhead area on Friday night. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed being "appalled by mindless attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community." The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page stated police were "carrying out duties" when attacked and appealed to parents to know where their children are and what they are doing.

Mr Charney, founder and former CEO of American Apparel, was ousted last year due to employee complaints and accusations of misuse of company funds. The company's board stated it does not expect him to return, citing evidence of illicit emails to female employees and racially derogatory taunts, which violated company policies. The board asserted no company would hire him as CEO due to excessive risk. Mr Charney's lawyer denied the allegations, calling the company's actions a privacy invasion to extort him. American Apparel recently secured a restraining order preventing him from making negative press statements or attempting to remove board members.

GB's basketball team will face Greece at London's Copper Box Arena, broadcast on BBC iPlayer and BBC Sport, with Greece missing three players from their 92-64 win in Patras earlier this month. This game is GB's only home match before EuroBasket 2017, following a Poland warm-up tournament.

The passage recounts a BBC journalist's experience covering the 2007 iPhone launch, initially unable to obtain the device but later securing it from Apple's Phil Schiller for a news segment. The journalist faced criticism for highlighting the product, later reflecting that the iPhone's transformative impact—comparable to the Model T Ford's effect on car ownership—was underestimated at the time. It describes how the iPhone, despite predecessors having basic phone cameras and internet capabilities, revolutionized technology by making advanced features accessible through an attractive interface, enabling widespread smartphone use. The journalist contrasts poor 2007 photography with high-quality 2017 smartphone images, demonstrating how the iPhone changed photography and mobile activities. The passage concludes that the iPhone launched the mobile connected era, starting on a January morning in San Francisco.

Multiple cats in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, died after ingesting antifreeze, with seven-month-old Meereen being the most recent victim. Three other cats died in the last seven days and one two weeks ago. The RSPCA confirmed the poisonings, is unsure if deliberate or accidental, and urged safe storage of chemicals like antifreeze, especially during car maintenance season.

Syriza government agrees to austerity and liberalisation measures despite previously opposing them, as Greece's tourism booms with 25 million expected arrivals. No street protests occur despite announced VAT increases, pension cuts, and planned reforms. The government seeks €86bn in new credit for a third bailout, following a near-economic collapse in July that shifted Syriza's stance. Greece faces severe economic squeeze from monetary and fiscal austerity, with banking restrictions and credit shortages threatening Christmas sales, requiring debt forgiveness for genuine recovery.

Ross Kemp will return as Grant Mitchell for EastEnders' Peggy Mitchell's final episodes, marking a brief comeback after his last appearance in 2006. Barbara Windsor's character, Peggy, returns after leaving in 2010 to announce her cancer has returned, leading to her death in spring episodes. Kemp will reunite the Mitchell brothers with their mother for her final scenes. Grant Mitchell, a long-standing EastEnders character since 1990, is described as an "EastEnders legend" returning to Walford to say goodbye to his mother and reunite with his brother and former loves.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked Alice Ruggles in October. Her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, immediately identified Dhillon as the perpetrator when police informed them of her death. The mother expressed guilt for reassuring Alice two days prior that the stalking was "ok" and telling her to ignore Dhillon, and for dismissing her daughter Emma's warning that Dhillon would kill Alice. The parents established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about stalking dangers, aiming to remember Alice for her vibrant personality. Dhillon, 26, denied murder but was found guilty and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years.

EDF approved £18bn funding for the Hinkley Point C nuclear plant in Somerset, with contracts scheduled for Friday. However, the UK government launched a further review following Business Secretary Greg Clark's statement to "consider carefully" before backing it, causing EDF executives to be taken off guard. Critics highlight concerns over environmental damage, escalating costs, foreign ownership (one third of costs from Chinese investors), and EDF's financial strain despite Chinese investment and a £3.4bn share issuance. The project, expected to supply 7% of UK electricity, has faced delays since its 2013 approval, with recent EDF board resignations citing financial risks. Stakeholders urge swift government decision to avoid energy supply risks and higher costs.

The new divorce application form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person a spouse committed adultery with, though the Ministry of Justice states there is "no obligation" to provide this. Family lawyers, including Margaret Heathcote and Georgina Hamblin, warn that naming a third party increases conflict, is unnecessary, and may lead to delays and extra costs, as the named person becomes part of the court case. Guidance on the form states it is "not normally necessary" to name the third party, but lawyers report many clients still choose to do so, despite judges viewing this negatively. Adultery was the reason for 12,148 divorces in England and Wales in 2015, out of over 100,000 total.

There is conflict in Wales between environmental policy favoring native trees and public access versus commercial forestry for timber. Confor reports 16,000 hectares of commercial forest lost since 2001, needing replanting. The forestry industry contributes over £450m annually to Wales. The Welsh government seeks balance through its Glastir scheme and Woodlands for Wales strategy, aiming for quality woodlands that support industry and environment. Confor states only 90 hectares were planted last year versus the required 20,000 hectares annually to meet ministerial targets, with sawmills eager to expand if timber supply increases.

A boy was badly injured after being struck on Bank Street in Coatbridge near Langloan Primary School at 16:40. He was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is serious.

Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to Arctic Convoy veterans, including 91-year-old Charles Lewis, who felt "honoured and delighted." The Foreign Office initially blocked the recognition as it violated rules on foreign medals for acts over five years old. The Russian Embassy stated the convoys supplied the Soviet Union to defeat Germany on the Eastern Front. The Arctic Convoys, traveling from Britain to northern Russia during WWII under constant German attack, severe cold, storms, and ice, resulted in 104 merchant and 16 military vessels lost by May 1945, with over 3,000 Allied seamen killed. The Russian Embassy planned the medal award in 2012, but the Foreign Office blocked it until an exception was made in 2013, allowing President Putin to present the first medals. The Ushakov medal recognises sailors displaying courage defending Russia.

HM Inspectorate of Probation found significant delays in offenders starting unpaid work ("community payback") and excessive leniency when they failed to attend, with one offender completing only 16 hours over 17 months. The report, based on 100 cases and 86 offender interviews, highlighted poor enforcement, organisational challenges with offenders having chaotic lifestyles, and that unpaid work was often viewed merely as punishment. Community payback sentences range from 40 to 300 hours for offences like shoplifting and theft, with 70,000 offenders ordered to complete such work in 2014. The report included 15 recommendations, urging better enforcement, tailored work objectives, and focusing on rehabilitation. The Ministry of Justice accepted all recommendations and stated it is acting to ensure offenders attend and face consequences for non-compliance.

The passage details accusations against comedian Ben Stiller (referred to as "Brand" in the text) of hypocrisy for campaigning for economic revolution to aid the poor while living in a luxury London home. Stiller faced questions about his property from a journalist, which he dismissed as "snide," and later used the hashtag #TheSunLogic to respond to The Sun's headline. He acknowledges his wealth but argues that systemic change is essential, stating individual wealth sharing without broader reform is "futile," and that the focus on his personal circumstances distracts from addressing economic disparity.

Dr. J. Craig Venter accelerated human genome mapping through a competitive approach, leading to criticism but speeding up the process. He later founded the J Craig Venter Institute to create the first synthetic life form, Synthia, published in Science. Born in 1946, his early life as a surfer and service as a medic in Vietnam during the Tet offensive instilled a sense of urgency. After leaving the NIH in 1992 due to criticism and funding issues, he established private research institutes, including Celera Genomics, which completed the human genome in three years. His breakthrough involved sequencing RNA instead of DNA, enabling faster gene identification. He also led oceanic research via his yacht Sorcerer II to sequence marine microbes. Venter views synthetic microbes as potential catalysts for an industrial revolution, capable of reducing oil dependence and capturing carbon dioxide.

A survey of 1,000 parents in England found 80% of children who eat school lunches tried new foods at school not eaten at home, with half of parents reporting children requested school foods to be cooked at home. Carrots, sweetcorn and peas were the most popular vegetables; aubergine, chickpeas and spinach were least popular. The School Food Trust commissioned the research after a Mumsnet survey suggested parents gave packed lunches due to children's perceived fussiness.

Morata, 23, played for Spain at Euro 2016 after joining Juventus in 2014 from Real Madrid, with a buy-back option for Real up to €30m. He scored 27 goals in two years for Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias, and featured in two Champions League finals (sub in 2014, scored in 2015). He came through Real Madrid's youth system, making his debut at 18 and scoring 10 goals for La Liga.

Wilson, 30, rejoined Championship side Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013, making 51 appearances in his second spell at the club after four seasons prior. He previously played for Preston North End and Notts County and has been without a team since being released in May.

Tesco is selling its loss-making US food chain Fresh & Easy to Yucaipa, a Los Angeles private equity firm run by Ron Burkle, after it lost money since 2007. The deal involves 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees transferring to Yucaipa, with 50 stores closing. Tesco will loan Yucaipa £80m (part of a £150m disposal cost), and retains an option to buy a stake if Yucaipa becomes profitable. Tesco described the sale as an "orderly and efficient exit from the US market."
The athlete experienced racial abuse but overcame it, as explained to BBC Sport. After briefly considering representing France, he is now targeting a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

Glaciers in the French Alps covered 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s, reducing to 275 sq km by the late 2000s, a 26% loss over 40 years. The research, led by Marie Gardent and colleagues, used map archives, satellite imagery, and manual verification to assess glaciers across the Alps. Retreat is not uniform: southern sectors (e.g., Belledonne Massif, where glaciers nearly disappeared; Ecrins Massif, with three times more retreat than Mont Blanc) lost ice faster than northern regions (including La Mer de Glace, now 30 sq km). The northern Alps retain more ice due to higher elevation, more precipitation, and cloud cover. The findings align with broader Alpine glacier retreat across multiple nations.

Scotland's women's team has won all five qualifiers, needing victory against Iceland to secure a spot in the finals. Evans expresses the devastation of missing out after previous play-off losses for Euro 2013 and the World Cup, calling it more heartbreak than humiliation. Iceland, ranked 20th, are unbeaten and the outcome of the Falkirk match and the return fixture will likely decide the group. Scotland is in pole position to qualify automatically without a play-off. Evans highlights the squad's international experience, with 12 of 20 players abroad, and states that playing in top leagues like Germany's benefits the national team through exposure to different cultures and higher competition.

Stuart Campbell, blogger behind Wings Over Scotland, was arrested in west England following a harassment complaint from a south London woman alleging online harassment over two years. He was released on bail pending further inquiries until mid-September, stating the allegations concerned non-threatening tweets he posted and accusing the media of spreading innuendo. The Metropolitan Police confirmed an investigation into the online harassment allegation made by a woman in her 30s.

People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (Peta) wants the Skegness Jolly Fisherman mascot replaced with a fish-themed version called "Skegness - A Happy Plaice" to rebrand the resort as progressive and animal-friendly, arguing the current mascot evokes images of animal cruelty. The original Jolly Fisherman poster, commissioned in 1908 for 12 guineas by the Great Northern Railway with the slogan "Skegness is so bracing," is synonymous with the resort. Skegness mayor Carl Macey stated all suggestions are welcome but believes there is little support for removing Jolly, as he is loved by all ages and seen as happy and friendly, not representing animal cruelty. The mayor said the resort would not "fix it if it isn't broken."

Scotland scored six tries against Georgia, leading 38-11. Georgia opened scoring through Vasil Lobzhanidze, but Scotland responded with Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg before halftime. Scotland dominated possession (91% at 30 minutes), adding further tries through Hamish Watson and Hogg. Georgia scored a second try via Lobzhanidze after a scrum advantage. Scotland's coach noted strong first-half control and possession management.

Widnes Vikings defeated Castleford Tigers 38-12. Widnes led 14-6 at halftime with tries from Leuluai, Ah Van and Bridge. Castleford's Flynn scored early in the second half, but Widnes extended their lead with tries from Ah Van, White (2) and Mellor, making it 38-12. Castleford scored three tries in four minutes late on, but Widnes held on. Widnes moved to seventh place, above Wakefield, while Castleford remained sixth, one point above Widnes.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti detainee held since 2002 after being arrested in Pakistan on suspicion of al-Qaeda links (which he denies), was released after a US review panel concluded he was not a continuing significant threat. He boarded a Kuwaiti government plane, facing at least a year at a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait as part of the release terms. His release reduces Guantanamo's inmate count to 148, making him the first detainee freed since May when five Taliban detainees were exchanged for Sgt Bowe Bergdahl. The US facility opened in 2002 following the 9/11 attacks, and President Obama has repeatedly promised to shut it down.

The song 'PPAP' (Pen-Pineapple-Apple-Pen) by fictional DJ Piko-Taro, portrayed by Japanese entertainer Kazuhiko Kosaka, went viral internationally. Its lyrics and simple dance routine, featuring repetitive phrases about fusing a pen with an apple and pineapple, drove its popularity. The original YouTube video garnered over 4 million views, while a 9GAG Facebook version exceeded 44 million views. Reactions were mixed: some users found it "highly amused" but "extremely confused," others called it "irritating" and "driving them up the wall." The song has inspired numerous covers, including by Japanese stars and a heavy metal tribute, but it has not trended significantly in Japan despite global attention. It is compared to Psy's viral success.

Thousands attended an early morning service at Hyde Park Corner and a parade of up to 400 people before a wreath-laying at the Cenotaph for Anzac Day. Anzac Day commemorates the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces in World War One (the Gallipoli landings). The first Anzac Day commemoration in the UK was held in 1916 at Westminster Abbey by King George V. Services have since become important for expatriate and visiting Australians and New Zealanders. The Gallipoli campaign was a bloody eight-month Allied operation attempting to force the Ottoman Empire out of the war.

Clarkson, 30, has joined St Mirren for a second spell and is set to make his debut against Alloa in the Championship. He scored nine goals at Dundee last season and has featured mainly as a substitute this term. Clarkson stated he is fit and ready, having maintained match fitness through U20s games. Capped twice for Scotland with one goal, he has nearly 400 senior appearances, previously playing for Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. St Mirren are eighth in the Championship, seven points clear of bottom side Alloa, and Clarkson emphasized the importance of winning games to build confidence and climb the table.

Bernard Matthews was sold to Ranjit Boparan, with guarantees that existing pension agreements will continue. The new owner plans to restore profitability through increased investment, cost savings, and utilising spare capacity for chicken processing.

The council made the Cowes crossing free until 2 July to address ferry problems and allow feedback. The chain ferry, launched late on 14 May, has broken down, run aground, and been suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to "training issues," with cars damaged during boarding. Shopkeeper Angie Booth stated businesses are bearing the brunt of almost six months of lost trade. Transport councillor Ian Ward said compensation for businesses was under discussion, called it a "prototype" with expected teething problems, and noted electrical issues were fixed. The council authorised ramp extensions to prevent vehicle scraping and stated grounding issues were resolved through seamanship improvements. An auditor review of the project was ordered.

The UK fishing industry, contributing 0.5% of GDP and employing 12,000 people, campaigned for Brexit to regain control of UK waters and become a leading fish exporter. The House of Lords report warns this sector risks marginalization in Brexit negotiations despite its small economic size. Key concerns include shared fish stocks with EU states, the need for continued EU market access (which may require allowing EU boats in UK waters), and the potential for four separate fisheries regimes across UK nations. However, the industry expresses optimism following new EU quotas, believing Brexit will enable fairer quota access, sustainable management, and full UK control of 200-mile waters.

Timothy Geaney admitted taking or permitting images of young boys in erotic poses (without sexual activity) between April 2004 and February 2014. He received a community payback order, was placed on the sex offenders register, and ordered to attend a sex offender programme. Following a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing, he was removed from the teaching register as his conduct was deemed "fundamentally incompatible" with teaching, "condoning an industry that violates children," and showing a pattern of behaviour over ten years with no remedial action, indicating a strong likelihood of recurrence. He was barred from re-registering for two years.

A fire on 2 March on Duncan Street reduced train services and caused travel delays, with firefighters present for several days. The Environment Agency suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste after the fire, citing the company's "broadly compliant" status with fire safety law. The company, run by Asset and Land Group, has until 7 August to appeal. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service had visited the site nine times in 12 months and raised concerns about potential impacts on residents, transport, and the environment, leading to joint visits with the EA and enforcement action. The EA revoked the company's environmental permit, effective 7 August unless appealed, requiring waste removal. The fire cause remains undetermined.

Syria missed the deadline to hand over its chemical weapons stockpile, with Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stating shipments were attacked by "terrorist groups" during transport to the coast. Syria possesses 1,300 tonnes of chemical weapons, but only 30 tonnes (4%) have left the country. The US and Russia have set a March 1 deadline for weapons to reach the coast for removal, with destruction required by June. Al-Mekdad stressed Syria's commitment to agreements and criticized US condemnation of barrel bomb attacks in Aleppo, which the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reports killed 246 people (including 73 children) in five days. Syria denied rebel seizure of Aleppo's central prison, while activist groups claim rebels control it, holding at least 3,000 detainees. The OPCW admits security concerns have slowed the chemical weapons destruction process.

England defeated Pakistan by a large margin at Old Trafford, declaring twice for 589-8 and 173-1 to secure their second biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was man of the match with 254 and 71* in the innings, plus four catches and a wicket. Pakistan were bowled out for 234 and 198, with their batting failing to reach 400 despite the pitch offering little assistance. Commentators described England's performance as a dominant "hammering," with Pakistan's spirit broken and captain Misbah admitting poor shot selection cost them.

Sarah Rochira, Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is reviewing the quality of life and care for older people in residential care. She is gathering experiences from pensioners, families, and friends to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies, focusing on physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. The review aims to highlight both good care and the impact of poor care, ensuring accountability and improvements in residential care quality across Wales.

Paul Sheerin, 39, replaces Neil Cooper as Aberdeen's player-manager after serving as Arbroath's player-manager since 2010. Arbroath were relegated to Scottish League Two after the 2013-14 season. Sheerin, who won a Scotland U-21 cap in the mid-1990s, guided Arbroath to their first national trophy (2011 Scottish Third Division title and promotion) and previously played for several Scottish clubs and Östersunds in Sweden.

After Bob Bradley's sacking, Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will manage Swansea's next match against Bournemouth. Swansea aims to appoint a new manager quickly, with Paul Clement as the first choice, to avoid relegation. Curtis states that if relegated, returning to the Premier League would be difficult due to the Championship's strength and Swansea's inability to retain top players like larger clubs.
