Swansea, promoted in 2011 after avoiding bankruptcy and near-relegation in 2003, has lost its "Swansea Way" since Michael Laudrup left in 2014, with constant management changes and diluted identity. Curtis believes the current squad is capable of staying up and ensures new signings watch the documentary "Jack to a King" to understand the club's history and importance of avoiding relegation.

Dr. J. Craig Venter accelerated human genome mapping through a competitive race, drawing criticism from the scientific community. He developed a faster gene sequencing method by focusing on RNA, leaving the NIH in 1992 to found The Institute for Genomic Research and later Celera Genomics, which completed the human genome in three years. Venter then established the J Craig Venter Institute, leading to the creation of Synthia, the first synthetic life form, published in Science. His background includes serving in Vietnam, which instilled a sense of urgency, and later oceanic genetic research via his yacht Sorcerer II. Venter asserts synthetic microbes could drive a new industrial revolution, aiding environmental solutions.

The Sutton Trust report states England's apprenticeships are predominantly low-quality and short, with only 200,000 of 520,000 annual starts at level three (A-level equivalent). It compares poorly to Germany, where 51% of employers offer apprenticeships versus 20% in England, and Germany has 570,000 new young apprenticeships versus England's 61,000. England's system has 18,000 qualifications versus Germany's 330. Over half of apprenticeships since 2010 have been below level three, with three-quarters aimed at those over 25. The report urges expanding apprenticeships to 300,000 yearly starts, prioritizing level three (minimum three years), and reforming the "patchwork" system to boost economic competitiveness and youth job prospects.

British cyclist Sarah Storey won a cycling event in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing over two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska. The 37-year-old, Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals (11 gold, 8 silver, 3 bronze) across six Paralympics in cycling and swimming, aims for a 17th title in Saturday's road race and further Paralympic success at the 2016 Rio Games. She won four golds at the 2012 London Paralympics, has 21 world titles, and switched from swimming to cycling in 2005 after winning six medals in swimming at the 1992 Paralympics.

Hereford United were expelled from the Football Conference Premier after missing a final deadline of 12 June to pay £148,000 owed to football creditors, despite three deadline extensions. This resulted in Chester FC, who were previously relegated, taking their place in the Conference Premier following a dramatic final-day match outcome. The club faced £225,000 in total debts, including over £70,000 to HMRC, and despite a fan-backed £1 offer to buy the club, the new owner Tommy Agombar failed to secure the necessary payments. Average attendance had fallen significantly from 3,270 in League Two (2007-08) to 1,758 in the 2013-14 season.

Former Manchester City player, 30, earned 61 England caps since his senior debut in 2009. He was in squads for two World Cups and two European Championships but played only three minutes at Euro 2016. He holds the record for most capped England Under-21 player (46 caps from 2004). His only international goal came in England's 5-0 win over Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood died at his home in Cambridge after a months-long illness, with a private funeral and later memorial service. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, directing it for 30 years across six continents and overseeing over 200 CDs, including the first complete Mozart symphony cycle on period instruments. His notable recordings include Handel's Messiah (1980), named by BBC Music Magazine as one of the top 20 recordings of all time. Hogwood studied keyboard at Cambridge and worked with leading orchestras, was a founder of the Early Music Consort of London, and held roles including artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society. He was also a tutor at Harvard and professor at Cambridge and Cornell. Colleagues praised him as a founder of the early-music movement, a generous ambassador for historically informed performance, and a key influence on future musicians.

A boy from Northern Ireland with special educational needs was removed from mainstream school in June due to not coping, but his family remains without a special school placement as all local special schools are full. His mother, who gave up her job to care for him, stated he feels isolated as his siblings attend school. An extra classroom assistant has been added at a local special school, offering a potential placement in weeks, but the mother fears the system's over-subscription will affect other families. The Education Authority declined to comment on the specific case for privacy reasons but stated they are reviewing special school needs across Northern Ireland to ensure placements near children's homes, with changes planned from 2016.

Newport County Football Club holds a lease for Rodney Parade until 2023, with priority fixtures if they remain in the Football League. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is seeking a takeover of Newport Gwent Dragons to use the venue for rugby, but County's chairman states their contract must be honoured. Both County and Newport Squash Club are protected under current agreements, though the WRU plans to install an artificial surface against Football League rules. County are two points clear of League Two relegation with two games remaining, and losing Football League status would be "devastating" for fans and the city. The WRU takeover is set for a shareholder vote on 9 May.

Sierra Leone was declared free of Ebola after the virus killed nearly 4,000 people over 18 months. The passage recounts a former child soldier kidnapped by RUF rebels at age 15 during Sierra Leone's civil war (ending 2002), who later escaped, found hope through Lifeline Nehemiah's Richard Cole, and became an Ebola responder. During the 2014 Ebola crisis, he led efforts including educating over 10,000 people in local languages, supporting 11,000 people with food, and establishing an Ebola treatment unit with community help. He emphasizes rebuilding through youth investment and regrets past actions, stating the future is "great." The passage notes Sierra Leone's Ebola deaths totaled 3,955.

About 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters and photographs faced auction to pay Waterford Wedgwood plc's pension debt after the firm collapsed in 2009. A public fundraising campaign met its target in one month, preventing the sale. The collection will remain on display at the Barlaston museum in Staffordshire, be gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum, and then loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. This resolved the pension debt issue inherited by the Wedgwood Museum after it went into administration in 2010.

Dan Groves stated details of a potential 20% stake deal for Wright are pending, with Wright set to become a club director. Billericay sits eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points from play-off spots. Wright, a 2011 I'm A Celebrity runner-up, played non-league for clubs including Lewes and Crawley Town. The club was recently taken over by Glenn Tamplin, who invests £10,000 weekly, and signed Paul Konchesky in March.

Mark Carney announced he would extend his term as Governor of the Bank of England for one additional year until 2019, rather than until 2021 or stepping down as originally planned in 2018. He stated this was an entirely personal decision driven by family circumstances, specifically his daughters' school exams in 2018, and emphasized the role requires "total attention and devotion." He clarified no political considerations influenced his choice, and the extension allows him to step down as the Article 50 Brexit process concludes.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1. Blackpool took the lead when Jamille Matt scored from three yards after Nathan Delfouneso's chip. Colchester equalized from a corner as Kurtis Guthrie prodded in from close range. Blackpool missed a chance to win 15 minutes from time when Tom Aldred headed wide. Colchester finished with 10 men after Sean Murray received a straight red card for a bad tackle in injury time.

The Healthy Me programme, developed by Action Mental Health, helps P6 and P7 children in Northern Ireland cope with the stress of transitioning to secondary school. It includes interactive workshops teaching emotional wellbeing, seeking help, and identifying support, while also providing teachers with basic training. Launched at Carrick Primary School after a five-school pilot, the programme addresses anxiety around the transfer test and the shift from a close-knit primary school environment to secondary school. The charity aims to roll it out across Northern Ireland, supported by evidence that emotional readiness is crucial for learning. The chief inspector of schools highlights strengthening young people's resilience as a key challenge for the education system.

The Fawley power station chimney, commissioned in 1971 and closing in 2013 after powering one million homes, will become the tallest attraction south of London's Shard as the centrepiece of a £1bn "merchant city" development. Developers Fawley Waterside plan a petal-shaped glass structure, marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth on the 300-acre site, sold to them in 2016. The 198-metre chimney, already built, requires minimal investment compared to new structures like Brighton's i360. Building could start in 2018 following a planning application.

Ben Latham won bronze in the men's scratch race at the Hong Kong championships, securing GB's second medal after Elinor Barker's women's scratch silver. Adrian Teklinski (Poland) won gold, Lucass Liss (Germany) silver. GB's men's team pursuit lost bronze to Italy. Joe Truman was eliminated in the men's keirin semi-finals. GB's women's team pursuit finished fifth. Elinor Barker's team (with new riders) also finished fifth but Barker noted their potential. Olympic bronze medallist Katy Marchant was eliminated in the women's sprint first round.

Ross Kemp will return as Grant Mitchell for Barbara Mitchell's final EastEnders episodes, reuniting the Mitchell brothers with their mother for the last time as she faces a return of her cancer, leading to her death in spring episodes. Kemp described it as a "brief return" he "could not turn down," with the executive producer calling Grant an "EastEnders legend" returning to say goodbye.

Sadio Mane scored twice in 138 seconds as Liverpool defeated Tottenham at Anfield. Tottenham manager Mauricio Pochettino criticized his team's lack of desire and poor performance, stating they were not ready to fight for the Premier League title. He noted Spurs have won only twice away since 24 September, including losses to Chelsea and Manchester United, and won just once in 17 away games against top-six sides. Former midfielder Danny Murphy commented on Spurs' defensive issues and lack of pace away from home, suggesting they should stick to their successful back three formation.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 governorships in Nigeria's elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999. The PDP lost key northern states, including Katsina and Kaduna, and control of Adamawa, while retaining eight governorships mostly in the southeast and Rivers State (oil hub). APC leader Muhammadu Buhari won the presidential election and will be inaugurated on 29 May. The PDP, now relegated to a regional party, failed to secure a national vote spread, performing only in the southeast and Niger Delta. The APC also failed to win any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, a concern for Buhari due to potential oil revenue disruption. Elections were marred by some violence but generally more peaceful than previous years.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) runs in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, from 19 to 22 July. Visitors can use an app to access online information, videos, and band interviews via augmented reality from signs and posters. Featured acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. Festival director Caroline Maclennan stated the app enhances visitor enjoyment and allows global audiences to experience the festival's atmosphere.

Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, rated inadequate by Ofsted, will have funding agreements terminated. Park View Educational Trust may be removed from running the schools. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, also rated inadequate, were warned to address concerns or lose funding. Education minister Lord Nash cited failures in promoting spiritual, moral, social and cultural development, less favourable treatment of non-Muslims, segregation of boys and girls, and an inadequate curriculum. Schools must address these issues by 4 July. The watchdog published 21 reports on schools allegedly targeted in a hardline Muslim takeover, with five schools rated inadequate. Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw noted a "culture of fear and intimidation" and an "organised campaign" to impose a narrow, faith-based ideology. Park View's report cited inadequate student safety, including unvetted external speakers and allowing a guest with extremist views at Islamic-themed assemblies. Parents criticised Ofsted reports as biased.

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, 38, was sentenced to five years in jail in September for allegedly plotting to topple Iran's government, with charges undisclosed. Her husband, Richard Ratcliffe, criticizes the UK government for inaction and states her appeal hearing is being held secretly in Tehran on Wednesday. Zaghari-Ratcliffe spent time in solitary confinement since her April arrest at Tehran Airport, with her two-year-old daughter Gabriella remaining in Iran under grandparents' care after the government confiscated her passport. Richard reports his wife experienced suicidal thoughts and a hunger strike, but has more resilience since leaving solitary confinement. He believes she is a diplomatic bargaining chip and the appeal outcome—quashing, reducing, or increasing her sentence—is unpredictable. Gabriella has become fluent in Farsi, losing English, and interactions require translation or physical play via Skype. Amnesty International calls her a "prisoner of conscience" for peacefully exercising freedom of expression, hoping the appeal leads to her immediate release.

Vincent Barker (Vinnie) died in July 2012 following a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The prosecution alleges eye specialist Honey Rose failed to detect his swollen optic discs during the test, leading to undiagnosed fluid buildup in his brain causing death, which was preventable had she referred him for further investigation. The prosecution stated her conduct was so far below the expected standard it was "criminal," and Ms. Rose denies a charge of gross negligence manslaughter. The trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty at Dundee Sheriff Court of coercing a woman into sexual activity with a man he arranged via an adult website, filming the encounters, and sending explicit content to the victim's sister on Christmas Day 2014. He was convicted of intentionally causing the woman's sister and father to view sexual images and behaving abusively. Weatherhogg, a first offender assessed as posing a moderate risk of re-offending, was placed on the sex offenders register. The case was remitted to the High Court for sentencing, with the judge stating the sentence must reflect society's abhorrence of his conduct. The victim described feeling "blackmailed."

Ireland scored 165-5 with Stuart Thompson (56) and Gary Wilson (41 no) contributing, but Afghanistan won by 6 runs with 171-4, as Samiullah Shenwari (56) and Mohammad Shahzad (47) secured victory. The teams meet again in the second T20 on Friday at the same venue.

Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar, with total costs reaching £106.8m including signing-on fees, wages, agents, and a supplementary tax payment of €13.55m. The club denied tax-related crime, stating the payment covered potential contract interpretations, while a Spanish judge ruled there was sufficient evidence to continue investigations into the transfer. Sandro Rosell resigned as president amid unrelated money misappropriation accusations.

The bodies of David Miller (24) and Hannah Witheridge (23) were found on a beach in Koh Tao on 15 September. Thai police are holding two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun (both 21), who allegedly confessed to the killings. The suspects face charges of conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery, with a possible death penalty. UK Metropolitan Police officers completed their investigation in Thailand, will return to the UK to compile a report and update the families, and thanked Thai authorities. Thai police denied reports the suspects withdrew confessions. Post-mortems showed Miller died from drowning and a head blow, Witheridge from head wounds. DNA from the suspects matched evidence on Witheridge. The UK Foreign Office expressed concerns about DNA verification and mistreatment allegations.

VR is used across sectors for awareness, retail, healthcare, and education. The National Autistic Society created a VR film showing sensory overload in shopping centres to improve public understanding of autism. Alzheimer's Research UK released "A Walk Through Dementia" to demonstrate daily challenges for those with dementia. Retailers like Ikea use VR for virtual kitchen design apps, where users could customize spaces and throw virtual meatballs, leading to high engagement. Healthcare employs VR for live surgical broadcasts, phobia treatment (e.g., spider phobia), and PTSD therapy. Google's Expeditions enables virtual field trips for students, while VR language apps and engagement-tracking tools are being trialled in classrooms. Challenges include cost barriers for schools.

The Su-24 jet's "black box" was opened in Moscow with journalists and diplomats present, though flight data appears missing, potentially resolving the dispute over the jet's location when shot down. The incident, involving Turkish F-16s on 24 November, killed the pilot (by ground militants) and a Russian marine, while the navigator was rescued. Russia claims the jet was in Syrian airspace and demands an apology, accusing Turkey of US subservience and "creeping Islamisation." Relations plunged into crisis, prompting Russian sanctions including a package holiday ban. An analysis of the black box data is expected next week.

Scotland has won all five qualifying matches and faces Iceland in a crucial game that would secure their place in the finals without needing a play-off. Player Rachel Evans expressed the team's determination to avoid repeating past play-off heartbreaks for Euro 2013 and the World Cup, emphasizing the emotional significance of reaching a major tournament. Iceland, ranked higher and unbeaten, is a strong opponent, but Scotland is in pole position to top their group. Evans highlighted the benefits of Scottish players competing in top leagues abroad, noting it improves the national team's development.

The Commission on Local Tax Reform, established by the Scottish government and Cosla, found no "magic bullet" to fix council tax's built-in problems, which have worsened due to lack of modification. Property tax, used by most OECD countries and considered stable and hard to avoid, causes taxpayer confusion over whether it is a wealth tax or service charge and is perceived as unfair for not linking to income. A local income tax is seen as fairer but creates revenue fluctuations for authorities and limits local rate variation. The commission will hold public consultations before reporting in autumn, as the Scottish government considers the current council tax "unfair" and seeks fairer alternatives.

Apple implemented two-factor authentication to prevent unauthorized access to iCloud, requiring a four-digit code sent to a trusted device or phone after login, blocking access without it. This addresses a vulnerability exploited by Elcomsoft's software, which previously allowed hackers to download backups using stolen passwords. The feature remains opt-in, though experts recommend making it default, and concerns exist about recovery keys being lost or stolen. Apple plans to encourage stronger security adoption, including two-factor authentication, through awareness efforts.

UKIP spent £2,956,737 (68p per vote) to win the election, the Conservatives spent £2,980,815 (79p per vote), the Lib Dems spent £1,580,575 (£1.45 per vote) and lost all but one MEP, Labour spent £1,027,339 (26p per vote) and came second, the Greens spent £534,249 (43p per vote) and came fourth, and the SNP spent £267,372. The six highest-spending parties totalled £9,347,087, with all but Labour spending more than in 2009.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has left Barrow by mutual consent to join National League rivals, potentially facing his former club on 18 February. Striker Keating, 21, signed after being recommended by Micky Adams, previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, with his move pending international clearance. Manager Kevin Nicholson described Anderson as a leader-type and Keating as young, raw but hungry. The Gulls are four points above the relegation zone and have won only one of their last six games.

The 10-year-old Irish-bred horse Many Clouds collapsed after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day and was pronounced dead following treatment by veterinary staff. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed he suffered a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage". Tony Welsh, acting chief veterinary officer for the BHA, stated such incidents are rare and can occur in horses with no underlying health issues. Many Clouds had a history of post-race ataxia (overheating and wobbling) but had never collapsed before and showed no such symptoms on the day of the race. He had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. The BHA report concluded he died from a haemorrhage rarely seen on the racetrack, despite his prior overheating issues.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick became visibly emotional as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond bid farewell to the Scottish Parliament ahead of the 5 May election. Salmond reiterated Scotland's "not divided, but diverse" nature and the need for greater Scottish governance, welcomed transferred powers under the Scotland Bill but criticized unionist pledges not fulfilled, and joked about the UK budget and Cheltenham races before concluding his speech. McNeil warned Holyrood must improve its committee system and accountability by learning from Westminster, expressing sadness that Scotland now needed to "do a bit of learning from them." Annabel Goldie, also stepping down, joked about missing Finance Secretary John Swinney's "faux indignation."

Emma Watson stars as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, Josh Gad as LeFou, and Kevin Kline as Maurice in the 2017 live-action Beauty and the Beast film directed by Bill Condon, releasing March 17, 2017, with filming beginning May at Shepperton Studios.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will announce its decisions at a meeting with victims' relatives at 11:00 BST regarding charges related to the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster, which killed 96 football fans. New inquests concluded the fans were unlawfully killed. Files concerning 23 suspects were referred to the CPS: 15 from Operation Resolve (investigating the disaster's causes) and 8 from an IPCC probe into police conduct. Relatives, including Margaret Aspinall (chairwoman of the Hillsborough Family Support Group), have awaited the outcome after a "long, long struggle," seeking accountability with "nothing more and nothing less."

Residents near Chelmsford Prison reported "numerous incidents" of packages being thrown over the wall, with one witness observing four instances in two weeks. A former inmate stated the prison is "notorious" for being flooded with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice acknowledged staff work "extremely hard" to stop contraband but admitted "more must be done," with the Justice Secretary reviewing solutions. The Ministry denied evidence of drones being used to deliver contraband to the site. New laws now allow up to two years' imprisonment for smuggling packages over prison walls.

Sylvia Blackburn, 72, a lollipop lady for 20 years, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by Brian Wright's VW Golf outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston. Wright, who denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, claimed he was blinded by the setting sun and failed to stop for a red light while she was crossing the road with a woman and her six-year-old daughter. Blackburn, who was wearing appropriate clothing, is now in residential care. Wright expressed remorse, stating he understood she was "much-loved" and apologized to her family. The trial continues.

Muir, a 24-year-old Scottish middle-distance runner and veterinary medicine student, will miss the 2022 Commonwealth Games in Australia's Gold Coast due to conflicting university exam schedules (May) and the event (April). She expressed disappointment but prioritized completing her final year degree. Muir mentioned the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target and stated she has "two, even three more Olympics" ahead. She recently achieved a new outdoor 5000m personal best of 14:52.07 at the World Athletics Championships, finishing sixth in that event.

Trevor Deely, 22, disappeared after being last seen walking home from a Christmas party in Dublin in December 2000. Gardaí began a search at a three-acre woodland site in Chapelizod beside the R112 and River Liffey on Saturday, involving excavations expected to take weeks. A review of his disappearance included enhanced CCTV footage showing him talking to a man in black outside his workplace on Baggot Street on the night he went missing. Detectives believe the man followed him later on Haddington Road. The unidentified man in the CCTV footage has not been found, and Gardaí have renewed their appeal for him to come forward.

Juan Martin del Potro, ranked 165th after missing over two years due to injury, defeated Stan Wawrinka 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3 in a Wimbledon match. The former US Open champion, who underwent three wrist operations and has not played a Grand Slam since the 2014 Australian Open, fought back from losing the first set to win. Del Potro expressed feeling "alive" again after his injury struggles. He will next face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. Nick Kyrgios, also in Andy Murray's half of the draw, came from two sets down to beat Dustin Brown in a rain-affected match.

Tunisia avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after apologizing to Caf for complaints about a disputed penalty in their 2015 quarter-final loss to Equatorial Guinea, which they claimed resulted from an unfit referee. Morocco was reinstated for the 2017 qualifying draw after the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned Caf's ban and reduced their fine following their refusal to host the 2015 Nations Cup due to Ebola fears. Both nations are now participating in the 2017 tournament.

McLaren, a team with 182 grands prix wins (23.18% win rate), 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently struggling, finishing as low as the fourth row of the grid due to Honda power-unit issues despite a competitive car. This follows a historical cycle of triumph and decline, including dominant eras with Honda (1988, winning 15 of 16 races) and Mercedes (1998-99), and past controversies like the 2007 constructors' title dispute (fined $100m) and the 2009 "lie-gate" scandal. Ron Dennis, who rebuilt the team after a 1970s slump, returned in 2013 to address current struggles but has yet to restore success. Leadership believes the car is competitive and Honda's engine will improve, aiming to end Mercedes' dominance and win "championships, plural" soon.

Paramedics attended a sudden death at Joe's Bar, Dungiven, on 6 October 2014 at 06:00 BST. Police found people at the bar after alcohol was served until 04:49 BST. Colleen O'Neill (license holder) and James Thomas were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. The judge ordered the bar closed for three months, cited O'Neill's "appalling record," and fined her £3,000 and Thomas £1,000, noting the premises were run improperly into the morning.

stephen curry scored 45 points with eight three-pointers to break his own nba record of 272 three-pointers in a season, leading the golden state warriors to an 116-105 victory over the portland trail blazers. klay thompson added 26 points. the blazers, led by lamarcus aldridge's 27 points, secured the northwest division title. meanwhile, the chicago bulls overcame a 19-point halftime deficit to defeat the miami heat 89-78, with pau gasol recording 16 points and 15 rebounds. the heat were outscored 57-27 after halftime, with dwyane wade scoring nine points on 4-of-20 shooting.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were misled into believing YouTube free-kick specialist Bas van Velzen was a competition winner offering a masterclass. Instead, van Velzen demonstrated exceptional dead-ball skills, scoring top-corner free-kicks that impressed the players. Van Velzen, a YouTube sensation known for his free-kick videos, described the experience as "every fan's dream" and enjoyed surprising the players, including revealing Balotelli's infamous "I'm not very good at free-kicks" slogan.

Women with BRCA1 gene mutations diagnosed with breast cancer who undergo oophorectomy have a 62% reduced risk of dying from breast cancer, with a 73% reduction if the procedure is performed within two years of diagnosis. The study of 676 breast cancer patients with BRCA mutations found a 65% reduction in death from all causes associated with oophorectomy. The 20-year survival rate for the group was 77.4%, and the protective effect lasted 15 years. Oophorectomy did not significantly reduce breast cancer death risk for BRCA2 carriers.

A married couple, Derek Lowe (38) and Tina Lowe (33), were killed when an Amtrak train struck them on Easter Sunday morning at approximately 10 AM in Durham, North Carolina. The accident occurred on Norfolk-Southern property as the northbound Carolinian train (No. 80) traveled from Charlotte to New York City. Both were pronounced dead at the scene. The train, carrying 166 passengers, experienced a two-hour, 45-minute delay before continuing its route; none of the passengers were injured, though one man received treatment for illness during the delay. Authorities indicated the couple may have lived in a homeless camp.

Carlos Toro, 66, a former mid-level Medellin cartel member who became a DEA undercover informant for 27 years after fleeing Colombia in the 1980s, faces deportation despite being promised U.S. citizenship in exchange for his service. He provided critical information leading to the prosecution of figures like Carlos Lehder Rivas and Manuel Noriega. After retiring due to declining health, his temporary visa expired, and the DEA refused to help him secure citizenship. Toro fears immediate death if deported to Colombia, is living in the U.S. illegally, cannot access social security, and remains in limbo while seeking a green card or passport. His handler called the situation "government bureaucracy at its worst."

The US internet address regulator ICANN is investigating Canadian company Vox Populi Registry Ltd. for using the '.sucks' domain to charge celebrities like Kevin Spacey and major companies such as YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, and Yahoo exorbitant fees to remove their names. Vox Populi initially charged $2,499 annually for the domains, with resellers selling them for around $2,000 yearly, targeting trademark holders before public release. ICANN, which initially approved the '.sucks' domain, reversed course after industry groups called it a 'shakedown scheme' and 'predatory' practice, threatening to open the domains to the public later. ICANN sent a letter to US and Canadian regulators to determine if Vox Populi's actions are illegal, noting that if found unlawful, it could breach Vox Populi's contract.

A baby boy's body, found in a Sainsbury's bag floating in a Norfolk pond in 1988, remained unidentified for 27 years. Police exhumed the body in 2015 for DNA testing, which led to the mother's identification. She was arrested on suspicion of infanticide but charges were dropped after she explained the baby was stillborn and she concealed the pregnancy. She stated she placed the stillborn baby in the pond on June 5, 1988. Police confirmed no foul play and ruled out third-party involvement. The mother remains on bail pending a decision on charges related to failing to register the birth and preventing a lawful burial. The baby was reburied in June 2015 as "Peter" at St Peter's Church, Norfolk, with a new headstone funded by a stillbirth support group.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, was ordered to pay compensation after unlawfully imprisoning passenger Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries requiring lifelong 24-hour care after jumping from a moving taxi travelling over 20mph. Hicks, aged 23 in 2010, was driven against his will for nearly a mile by Young, who mistakenly believed Hicks would not pay the fare. The High Court ruled Young's actions created a significant risk to life, leading to Hicks' injuries, epilepsy, and permanent disabilities. Compensation will be approximately 50% of the family's requested amount, plus £250 for unlawful imprisonment.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas Wednesday night as storms produced reports of twisters, including one 6 miles northwest of Goddard near Wichita that moved northeast without hitting the city. Additional tornado reports came from southwestern Kansas near Aetna and a possible tornado in Potosi, Missouri, causing wind damage, flooding, fallen trees, and roof damage. Nighttime tornadoes were highlighted as particularly dangerous, with more storms expected Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and southern Great Lakes region.

Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida face off in a middleweight clash in New Jersey. Rockhold aims to dominate as the "bull" by cutting off Machida's movement and forcing him into Rockhold's style, citing advantages on the feet and ground. Machida believes his technique can win. Both recently won: Rockhold defeated Michael Bisping, Machida beat CB Dollaway. The winner earns a title shot.

A light general aviation aircraft landed without deployed landing gear at Aero Acres Residential Airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, skidding on its belly along the runway. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, 85, with nearly 50 years of flying experience, re-engaged engines after impact, took off again, and flew 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale where he landed safely. The incident caused propeller damage and runway scratches, described as a distinctive sound. The cause is likely human error (forgetting to deploy landing gear), with the FAA investigating. The pilot was accompanied by his dog, Buddy.

Manuel Pellegrini admits disappointment in Yaya Toure's performance this season but vows to back him until the end of the season. Toure, under criticism for Manchester City's poor Premier League defence, has two years left on his contract. City will listen to offers for Toure in the summer as they plan to overhaul an ageing squad. Pellegrini states Toure does not need a rest and remains a key player. City, with only 18 points from the last 39, face West Ham without captain Vincent Kompany. Joe Hart says players must take responsibility for their performances, though Pellegrini retains dressing room backing.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive convicted in 1999 for Cosa Nostra membership and sentenced to seven years, will remain in the UK after his Italian sentence expired under law. Italian law states a sentence is extinguished once more than double the penalty period passes, which occurred in October 2014. His European Arrest Warrant will be withdrawn, and his conviction is deemed "too old" to enforce. His solicitor confirmed the Italian court of appeal agreed to extinguish the conviction, allowing him to stay in England with his family. The Crown Prosecution Service confirmed the Italian Supreme Court must still hear the case, but the warrant will be withdrawn.

Mr. Mole, AP McCoy's mount in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown, is a 7-2 co-favourite alongside Tiara and Sprinter Sacre. McCoy will ride Mr. Mole in his final Grade One race, with six other runners including Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter's daughter Marcia was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. Marcia's body was found 33 days after her disappearance in a garage 150 yards from home, with signs of sexual assault, strangulation, vomit, and missing cookie money. Barrett was convicted of second-degree murder in 2009 after DNA evidence linked him to the crime, receiving a 44-year sentence. Ritter, advised against viewing the body or crime scene photos by her then-husband, declined to see them for decades, including after Barrett's conviction. In 2015, she viewed the photos on an investigator's laptop, describing her daughter's swollen, blackened face and hair pulled out, expressing regret and stating she wanted revenge. The case was Nashville's most notorious unsolved murder for 33 years until Barrett's arrest in 2006.

Rory McIlroy believes it is "unthinkable" he will not win The Masters to complete the career Grand Slam, aiming to become only the sixth player to win all four majors. He considers his 2011 Masters collapse (leading by four shots but shooting an 80 in the final round) as "the most important day of my career," as it taught him valuable lessons that helped him win subsequent majors. McIlroy, the world number one with three major titles (2011 US Open, 2012 US PGA, 2014 Open and US PGA), has one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances and seeks his first green jacket to achieve the Grand Slam. He views Augusta National as a "sanctuary" to focus on golf amid the hype.

Four rainbows appeared over New York after heavy rain. In rural China, exotic dancers at wakes face a crackdown on vice. Robert Downey Jr. grew agitated during a UK interview about his private life. A lip-plumping trend using a jar (#kyliejennerchallenge) emerged. A 102-year-old woman's bomb-themed promposal was rejected by a school accused of racism. Ewan McGregor will play Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast." Johnny Depp appears unrecognizable in "Black Mass" trailer. A pregnancy announcement referenced "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air." A military dad photobombed his son's photo. All trends occurred this week.

Hundreds of children were hospitalized last year in England due to fetal alcohol syndrome, with 272 admitted as disabled by the condition, according to health data. Experts warn the actual number affected could be much higher, as research suggests at least one in 100 UK babies (around 7,500 annually) suffer learning, behavioral, or physical problems from prenatal alcohol exposure. The National Organization for Fetal Alcohol Syndrome states it is an "enormous problem" and "vastly under-diagnosed." While government advice recommends limiting alcohol to two units twice weekly during pregnancy, experts like Elizabeth Mitchell advocate for complete abstinence.

A 31-year-old ex-juvenile offender, Shaun Andrew McKerry (nicknamed "Boomerang Boy" or "Homing Pigeon Boy" for returning home after crimes), was jailed for six years after attempting to rob a Shildon post office and stores on March 15. During the robbery, he waved an axe at a staff member, but was tackled by the shopkeeper, Sab Dhillon, and disarmed when Dhillon's wife, Sam, hit him twice with a baseball bat. McKerry, who started shoplifting at 12 and had 80 arrests by age 15, previously pleaded guilty to attempted robbery at Durham Crown Court. His nicknames originated from being arrested 80 times in 1995 and 45 times in 36 weeks during 1998.

Four Royal Navy sailors—Joshua Finbow (23), Craig Stoner (24), Simon Radford (31), and Darren Smalley (35)—were charged with gang rape following an alleged sexual assault at a Canadian barracks on April 10 after a hockey game. They appeared in court in Dartmouth, Nova Scotia, and were granted bail with unusual conditions: they must stay in Nova Scotia, live on the Stadacona naval base, surrender passports, continue working for the Royal Navy, and not contact the victim or six witnesses. Bail was set at over £2,000 each, and they must return to court on May 27. The charges include sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, punishable by up to 14 years in prison. The British high commission confirmed the allegations are serious but unproven, and the sailors are cooperating with the Canadian investigation.

A mother, Valerie Jackson, faces repeated public misunderstanding and abuse reports due to her four-year-old son RJ's rare Netherton's syndrome, an incredibly rare congenital skin disease affecting only about 70 people worldwide. RJ's skin appears red, scaly, and inflamed, requiring frequent moisturizing creams. A stranger reported Valerie to police for child abuse after mistaking the condition for burns, leading to armed police surrounding her while shopping. She also endures street taunts, bullying, and denial of entry to play centers due to her son's appearance. The condition, a severe form of ichthyosis, causes painful, sensitive skin with no cure, though symptoms may improve over time. Valerie discovered the diagnosis through an online support group after initial misdiagnosis.

Transport for London is removing Protein World's "Are You Beach Body Ready?" posters from the London Underground after a three-week campaign period, following significant backlash. The ads, featuring model Renee Somerfield in a bikini, drew over 50,000 signatures on a petition, more than 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority, and criticism from feminists and body image campaigners who argued the campaign promoted an unrealistic and unhealthy body image. Bloggers defaced some posters, and the company faced threats, including a bomb threat. Protein World defended the campaign as unphotoshopped and targeted at health-conscious individuals, stating they would consider customer reactions for future ads but would not change their approach. The Advertising Standards Authority is assessing the complaints to determine if further action is needed.

Rail firms face criticism for planning fare hikes of up to 87 per cent on certain routes just ten days after the general election, contradicting main party leaders' pledges to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron requested First Great Western urgently review fare increases on the London-Cotswolds route passing through his constituency, where off-peak returns would rise from £33.30 to £62.40 (87% increase). Other hikes include a 24.5% increase on Stafford-Liverpool routes and a 22% rise on Manchester-Stoke first-class returns. Rail firms attribute the increases to aligning unregulated fares (half their revenue) with other services, with Virgin Rail stating most hikes affect their cheaper "Virgin-only fares" and overall increases are below the industry average.

Former soldier John Young, 66, was left blind in one eye after being struck by a brick thrown through his front door in Oldham, Greater Manchester, while confronting vandals who had been throwing stones at his home. The attack occurred on Friday, April 18, while Young and his 54-year-old new wife Elaine, whom he married three weeks prior, were writing wedding thank-you cards in their living room. Young was injured when he opened the door to confront the attackers, suffering an open forehead wound and serious eye injury requiring emergency surgery that failed to save his sight. Police stated there is no known motive, suggesting it may have been "yobs messing around," and urged the public to come forward with information. Young and his wife plan to move out of the area due to safety concerns.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, 25, has signed a new one-year contract extension following his successful return from injury. He missed the entire 2014 season due to leg injuries sustained in a road accident where his father Keith died. After an ankle operation, he made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi and is now committed to the county until the end of the 2016 season.

A five-year-old boy named Harley Renshaw was diagnosed with aggressive neuroblastoma, a rare childhood cancer affecting his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones. During his year-long treatment involving chemotherapy, surgery, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy, he created and decorated a Ninja Turtle-themed superhero mask to help him cope. After battling the disease, doctors have given him the all clear, confirming he is cancer-free, though he will have regular check-ups. His family expressed joy at the news, and Harley became the face of Cancer Research UK's kids and teens campaign.

Jack Grealish, a 19-year-old Aston Villa player, is in a tug of war between representing the Republic of Ireland and England internationally following his impressive performance in Villa's FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool. Tim Sherwood, Villa's manager, advises Grealish to concentrate on forcing his way into the Villa first team rather than focusing on his international future, stating it is Grealish's decision but emphasizing his priority is club performance. Sherwood compares the situation to Nabil Bentaleb's choice of Algeria over France. Grealish's father, Kevin, agrees, saying his son must concentrate on club football first, with the international decision expected after the season. Grealish has played for Ireland's youth teams but is currently split between the two nations.

Private jet landing fees vary significantly across airports, with Tokyo's Haneda airport charging the highest at £4,559 ($6,850) for a 767-400 aircraft, followed by Narita (£3,728) and Osaka's Kansai (£3,594). Other top fee airports include Bristol (£2,929), Dublin (£2,729), and New York's La Guardia (£2,630). The passage notes Salzburg and Darwin as unexpected hubs. Private jet travel is a growing luxury industry, with 2.5 million US flights recorded in 2013 and a market worth $16.7 trillion in the US. Fees are highest during major events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix.

Cooper the Labrador eats ice cream in one bite while his companion Daisy takes ladylike licks, as shown in a video taken by Katie Gallegos from Clackamas County, Oregon. The video has been viewed over seven million times. Gallegos defends feeding Cooper ice cream, stating he is healthy and eats it weekly like her previous dog who lived to 19. She ensures Daisy gets her fill first due to her smaller size. A separate video shows Cooper consuming a Starbucks "pup-uccino," which contains only whipped cream.

Gary Locke has been appointed permanent manager of Kilmarnock on a three-year deal following his successful interim spell. He joined the club as assistant manager under Allan Johnston last summer, took charge when Johnston resigned in February, and has lost only once in seven games since. The 41-year-old will speak at a press conference on Friday morning.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, accused Seminole County Elementary of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son for wearing Doterra essential oils (lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood) applied to his neck and head to help him stay calm and focused. The school claimed the oils' scent was a distraction, prompting a letter stating the oils created a "problem." Kemp argued she could not use natural products with scent but could use chemicals, and vowed to continue fighting. The Lake County School District later stated it would not suspend Logan, calling it a "health issue."

A beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton Beach, the Sandpiper complex, was destroyed by a fire on Wednesday at 3 PM, obliterating 90 condos before the building collapsed. The intense fire, visible from three miles away and melting paint on nearby buildings, spread rapidly through the summer holiday homes used by residents between May and November. Twelve fire crews attempted to control the flames but could not enter the structure, and residents like owner Janice Sklarek and building manager Rob Taber lost everything. Officials are investigating claims the fire started near a parked car.

The Queen, aged 88, rides her fell pony Carlton Lima Emma in Windsor Great Park without a helmet, preferring a silk scarf instead, due to her hair. She has ridden since age four with her first pony Peggy and continues to breed fell ponies at Hampton Court despite reducing riding due to a knee injury. She also breeds Highland ponies at Balmoral and is known for her lifelong love of horses.

A Brisbane neighbour dispute over noise levels resulted in the death of 55-year-old Leon Yeaman, allegedly killed by a single punch from 28-year-old Phillip Pama during a confrontation on Thursday night. Yeaman, described by neighbours as a schizophrenic pensioner who played loud music, was making noise in his yard when Pama, a shift worker sleeping at the time, confronted him. Pama, a married father of three with no violent history, was charged with manslaughter and granted conditional bail with restrictions including surrendering his passport, a curfew, and weekly police reporting. Yeaman was pronounced dead at the scene around 11 pm.

52-year-old music teacher Yulia Simonova attempted to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old former student Damian Vanya after he ended their relationship. She offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) and gave specific instructions to the undercover police officer posing as a hitman, demanding he break the boy's arms and legs, damage his kidneys, and make him bleed out slowly. Police arrested her after she handed over expense money during a sting operation in Shatura, Russia. Simonova faces 15 years in prison for attempted murder. Damian, who ended the relationship for a classmate, expressed relief, hoping guards would "throw away the key" to her cell.

Jose Mourinho, Chelsea's football manager, states he prays to God daily but only discusses personal matters, never football. He does not attend church regularly, only when he feels the need to, and more frequently in Portugal. He emphasizes separating professional and family life, describes himself as a good family person and friend, and mentions his family's awareness of poverty through their work as ambassadors for the World Food Programme. Mourinho acknowledges making mistakes professionally but asserts his personal life is separate from his career.

For the first time in eight years, Bob Barker returned to host "The Price is Right" on April 1, handling the "lucky seven" game before handing over to Drew Carey. Barker, who hosted the show for 35 years until 2007, appeared spry at 91 and did not seem to miss a beat.

Off-duty Secret Service agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested at 12:30 am on Friday on the 3200 block of D Street SE in Washington D.C. for attempted burglary and destruction of property. His security clearance was revoked and he was placed on leave. Baldwin is assigned to the Foreign Missions Branch, which handles U.S. diplomatic activities.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life by approaching a hungry male lion within 10 feet at a city safari park, armed only with a camera. He crept from his car, lay on the ground, and captured a few frames before the camera shutter alerted the lion. The lion aggressively charged, forcing Saeed to hastily retreat to his car for safety. He described the lion treating him as prey during the brief encounter.

New York City Police released a tattoo image of an unidentified woman, believed 25-45 years old, found dead in Brooklyn on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Gravesend; she had no identification but a distinctive heart tattoo with "Monique" on her right leg, and police are seeking public assistance to identify her while awaiting the medical examiner's report.

a new zealand couple, hannah and alex, built a solar-powered two-bedroom home on a 1986 hino flatbed truck after returning from the uk in 2009 and being unable to afford traditional property. they spent approximately one and a half years constructing the wood and steel home, which is now located on a lot in nelson, new zealand. the home allows near self-sufficiency through solar power (first power bill $25), a wood-fired stove, gas for hot water, and spring water. it features stained glass windows, cypress wood interior, and is surrounded by nature. the project cost about $25,000, and the couple plans to build another similar home.

Children who share iPads in class significantly outperform peers who use individual iPads or no iPads in early literacy tests, scoring around 30 points higher, according to research by Courtney Blackwell of Northwestern University. The study, involving 352 kindergarten students over an academic year, found collaborative learning around shared devices—not just collaboration—drives the improved results. Blackwell suggests schools reconsider tablet usage in early grades for greater effectiveness.

A piglet born without back legs has learned to walk on its front trotters, becoming an internet sensation after a viral video showed it foraging while balancing unsteadily. Nicknamed "Super Pig," it belongs to farmer Ms. Duan in Qionglai City, Sichuan Province, China, where villagers visit to see it. The piglet mixes with its four-legged littermates, and its story parallels a walking rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo in Guangxi Province.

A pit crew member, Todd Phillips (front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing), was injured when struck by Francesco Dracone's car during the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana on Sunday. Dracone, who came in on lap 25 for tires and fuel, spun while exiting the pit box, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips received stitches for a leg cut at the infield care center and was released. Dracone did not finish the race, finishing 23rd. The race featured traction issues due to prior rain.

A husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, murdered his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, 29 (stage name Amanda Bueno), in Rio de Janeiro after she was accused of being a "slut." He smashed her head into concrete 11 times, punched her face 10 times, then shot her five times at point-blank range. Severiano confessed he acted due to jealousy over men looking at her. The incident occurred four days into their marriage, following an argument where he yelled she was a "slut." After fleeing in a neighbor's car, he was arrested after crashing it; police found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in his car. He now faces life in jail. Cicera belonged to the dance troop Jaula das Gostozuedas.

Sarah Wilson, author of the best-selling book 'I Quit Sugar', revealed her battle with mental illness, including a near-suicidal crisis driven by severe anxiety, isolation, and factors including thyroid disease and distant family. She described feeling life was pointless, with no light at the end of the tunnel, and stated anxiety is increasingly linked to depression, becoming 'the new depression' in Australia. Wilson noted one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime, emphasizing the need to acknowledge this connection to address rising mental health issues.

Elena Curtin of Portland, Oregon, was seven months pregnant when she assaulted her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar in November 2014 after finding her using heroin in Curtin's bathroom. Prosecutors dropped the second-degree assault charge because Curtin was "completely justified in her outrage" under Oregon law, which permits physical force against an intruder refusing to leave a residence. Curtin faced a potential six-year prison sentence if convicted.
Gemma the pit bull in California dislikes broccoli, spitting it out after her owner tricks her by adding it to her treats, while living with children who should learn to love vegetables.

HSBC apologized after a link on its website directing to its defunct Young Entrepreneur Awards page redirected visitors to a pornographic site. The URL was taken over by the porn site after the awards were scrapped in 2011 and the organizers allowed its registration to expire. HSBC removed the hyperlink, denied any association with the external site, stated it is not linked to the porn site, and apologized for the inconvenience while confirming its website remained secure.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, called 911 during a Sunday morning house fire in Clinton after his family's home caught fire on the first floor, trapping him and his nine-year-old sister Aaliyah in a second-floor bedroom. Marcus stayed calm during the 11-minute call, provided firefighters with directions (noting a black door in the back hallway), soothed his sister, and stated other family members were present. Firefighters entered via the home, broke a window, and rescued Marcus and Aaliyah; Marcus was handed out the window, and a firefighter gave his gas mask to Aaliyah. Both siblings were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while the other family members went to Medstar Hospital.

Blue fluorescent algae lighting up Australia's east coast was captured in Jervis Bay, NSW, by photographer Andy Hutchinson, who described it as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of plankton emitting light. The glow is from Noctiluca scintillans, a single-celled phytoplankton that blooms in spring and autumn, occurs naturally 90% of the time, and uses the luminous defense mechanism against diatoms. An expert confirmed no concern, noting a similar display occurred at Sydney's Manly Beach in 2014.

New genetic marker tests, such as EndoPredict, can identify low recurrence risk (as low as 5%) in breast cancer patients after surgery, potentially sparing them unnecessary chemotherapy. These tests analyze tumor samples to determine aggressiveness, providing results within days. Currently available privately at £2,500, they are hoped to become NHS-accessible. Experts argue NHS use would save costs by avoiding chemotherapy for low-risk patients, as the treatment's severe side effects often outweigh its benefits for them. A patient example showed a low test score led to avoiding chemotherapy, with recurrence risk comparable to chemo's effectiveness.

Over 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, including five from HMS Ocean in nine years and at least one from HMS Illustrious. Data shows 99 servicewomen were flown home from Afghanistan (2006-2013) and 102 from Iraq, with strict military rules banning pregnant personnel from war zones. The Ministry of Defence confirmed a "no touching" rule, indicating most pregnancies occurred before boarding or during leave. Women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990, with 9% female personnel in 2014.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium was found on the roof of Japan's Prime Minister's residence, raising terrorism concerns. The drone, equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing small cesium traces (a nuclear reactor byproduct), was discovered on the same day a court approved restarting nuclear reactors near Fukushima. Officials noted the cesium amount was not immediately harmful but linked the incident to potential terrorism threats, especially for the Olympics and G7 summit. Japan has no drone flight restrictions around government buildings in Tokyo, despite existing airport restrictions.

Lu Xincai, a security guard in Zhejiang Province, China, takes his 84-year-old mother with Alzheimer's to work daily on the back of his motorbike. He ties a sash around both their waists to prevent her from falling off, rides slowly for a one-hour, four-kilometer commute to chat, and checks on her at work where his employers provided a room. He does this because she gets lost when left alone, and he feels a duty to care for her after she devoted her life to raising him.

Heavy drinking among Americans rose 17.2 percent from 2005 to 2012, driven largely by increased rates among women. The CDC defines heavy drinking as exceeding one drink per day for women or two for men, and binge drinking as four or more drinks for women or five or more for men on a single occasion. Nationwide, women's binge drinking rates increased over seven times faster than men's. In 2012, 8 percent of Americans were heavy drinkers and 18 percent were binge drinkers. Contributing factors include changing social norms making women's drinking more acceptable, cheaper alcohol due to stable taxes, increased advertising spending ($3.45 billion in 2011), and weakened alcohol control policies.

UN officials warn doctors are performing caesarean sections too readily, risking women's and babies' health, as the procedure should only be medically necessary. In England, over 25% of births are caesareans—more than double the 1990s rate—though the WHO recommends an ideal rate of 10-15% due to risks like infections, disability, or death, and higher costs (£2,369 vs £1,665 for natural birth). The WHO contradicts NHS guidelines allowing caesareans for anxiety (tokophobia) or other non-medical reasons, noting the overuse diverts funds from other patient needs and underestimates risks, with one in ten caesareans causing infections.

A 44-year-old woman, Michelle Filkins of West Wareham, was arrested for breaking into a Martha's Vineyard home, living inside for at least a week, and selling items from the property in a yard sale. Charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property, she was discovered by the owner on April 17 after claiming ownership and fleeing when confronted. Police found a broken window covered by a blanket and arrested her hours later. Missing items include furniture, a grill, lamps, posters, and a painting. Authorities are requesting anyone who purchased items to return them, stating they are victims and can seek restitution through court. Her next court date is May 14.

A Melbourne woman, Bella Crooke, lost her iPhone at a friend's birthday party. The phone was handed in to Albury Police Station on the NSW-Victoria border. Police found it unlocked and used it to post humorous selfies and messages on Bella's Facebook page, including jokes about the phone being in a "holding cell," needing a password, and being "fully charged." The posts directed her to collect it from the station. Bella arrived at 1 PM, unaware of the posts, and was recognized by officers who let her reclaim it without providing her name. Friends shared the posts, calling police "legends." Bella later added a password to her phone.

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was thrown into the air and dragged across the water during a fight between two adult male hippos at Isimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa. The calf's mother watched in horror as it was caught in the conflict, unable to save it. The calf died hours later from injuries sustained when one adult grabbed it between its jaws. The mother had previously stayed with her herd to avoid the fight, believing it safer, but the sub-adult hippo that grabbed the calf caused it to be flung into the air.

A Knightsbridge, London, three-bedroom apartment is listed for £575,000, significantly below neighbouring properties, but has only three years left on its lease. The price equates to £191,000 per year or £15,000 monthly, matching local rental rates. The unmodernised property (1,990 sq ft) requires renovation. If the lease is extended, it could be worth up to £6 million. A second similar maisonette is listed for £595,000.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage affecting 8,000 stores in the US and Canada, causing baristas to give away free drinks as registers failed. The outage, caused by a daily system refresh failure, began Friday evening and was resolved by late Friday, with stores returning to business as usual on Saturday. Starbucks apologized for the inconvenience and stated the issue also impacted Evolution Fresh and Teavana stores. The incident occurred one day after the company reported record quarterly earnings of $4.6 billion. Some locations closed early to avoid giving away free products.

Terrorists are using rural areas in West Wales, specifically Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, for training and radicalising Muslims, according to an officer from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit. Detective Constable Gareth Jones stated that those involved participate in ordinary community activities with an ulterior motive. He noted terrorism issues are not confined to large cities, citing historical incidents including 1998 training in the Brecon Beacons by Abu Hamza's group, the 7/7 bombers' white water rafting in Bala, a Cardiff-based Al-Qaeda inspired plot, and Michael Adebowale's study of Arabic at the European Institute of Human Sciences near Llanybydder, which was set up by Iraqi clerics. Jones stressed the importance of community intelligence for authorities.

An Omura's whale, feared extinct, was found washed ashore on a remote Exmouth beach in Western Australia after Tropical Cyclone Olwyn, marking the first sighting in WA and second in Australia. Identified via DNA profiling as a 5.68 m juvenile female, the species was only scientifically described in 2003 and is typically found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The carcass is buried, with its skeleton to be recovered later for scientific study and potential museum display, as the find is highly significant for understanding the whale's regional distribution and unique features like 53 vertebrae.

Cheryl Rios, a Texas businesswoman, argues Hillary Clinton should not be president due to female hormones causing irrational decisions and potential unnecessary wars. The passage counters that male leaders' hormones have similarly impaired judgment (e.g., Iraq War), studies show women take fewer risks, and historical examples of male leaders' misconduct (e.g., cheating) are cited. It argues the real barrier to women in leadership is pervasive gender bias in the workplace—not biology—and provides evidence of bias (e.g., male corporate board names outnumbering women, gendered professor descriptions), concluding that ending this bias benefits society, the economy, and families. The text also corrects an error stating Canada's first female PM was Kim Campbell in 1993.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, 89, is selling over 200 items from his antique collection in a £100,000 auction at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in South Cerney, Gloucestershire, to downsize his Cotswolds home. The collection includes a 1960s hand-painted limewood diorama of the Battle of Agincourt (estimated £4,000-£6,000), a yew longbow with mother-of-pearl handle, a portrait of Hardy holding the bow, military artifacts, furniture, paintings, books, and crystal chandeliers, with 238 lots total.

Michael Scott Shemansky, a Florida man on parole for battery on law enforcement with a history of bipolar disorder and a prior involuntary psychiatric commitment, is a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, 57, found dead at their Winter Garden home on Saturday with foul play suspected. Shemansky failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day, and neighbors believe his mother prevented the meeting due to divorce stress, with him reportedly receiving "bad news" paperwork Friday. Authorities have the murder weapon but have not confirmed how Sandra was killed, and Shemansky fled on foot without provisions or medication, last seen asking for water at the trailer park office. Police urge anyone with information to contact them at 407-656-3636.

Eugene, Oregon, was awarded the 2021 IAAF World Championships by the IAAF council, bypassing the usual bidding process due to a "unique strategic opportunity" to host the event in the USA for the first time. This decision followed Eugene's failed 2019 bid (awarded to Doha) and a successful recent presentation to the IAAF, which convinced the governing body of Eugene's capability. IAAF president Lamine Diack stated the choice was strategic to access a key market and leverage public, private, and NBC support.

Leonie Granger, 25, a care assistant from Gillingham, Kent, was jailed for 16 years for manslaughter after luring professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56, to his death. Granger befriended Hassan at a London casino, using her looks to gain his trust and receive gifts, cash, and restaurant trips. She left Hassan's flat door unlocked for her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson, 28, and accomplice Nicholas Chandler, 29, who tied up Hassan, kicked him to death, and ransacked his home for hidden winnings. Hassan died with multiple broken bones in his own blood. Granger was convicted of manslaughter (10-2 vote), while Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and jailed for life with a minimum term of 36 years. Judge William Kennedy described the attack as "pitiless and wicked." Granger claimed she was in love with Jackson and "fell in with his desires," but the judge deemed her deceitful. The killers stole £3,000, a TV, and a phone before being caught via her phone records.

Cesc Fabregas struggles in the second half of the season, as evidenced by his poor performance in Spain's 2-0 defeat by Holland, where he received a low rating. Despite a strong start to the season with 15 Premier League assists by mid-January, his form has significantly declined, with only one assist in five games since and four total in 15 appearances in 2015. Barcelona previously noted his "downward trend" and "traditional post-Christmas slump," where his contributions decrease late in the season. This slump threatens his chance to break Thierry Henry's assist record (20), though his passing ability has previously created opportunities for Chelsea against key opponents. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho remains concerned about Fabregas's durability as the team aims for the Premier League title.

west ham are discussing a deal for jamaican 17-year-old forward deshane beckford, who impressed during a two-week trial with their academy. beckford, from montego bay united, has offers from belgium and is described as one of the hottest caribbean prospects. additionally, west ham revealed season tickets at the olympic stadium will cost as little as £289 for the 2016-17 season, the cheapest in the premier league.

Police dropped an investigation into a vicious assault on Mike Lane, 40, joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, despite evidence including video footage, names, and car registration numbers of suspected attackers. Lane was beaten with iron bars on ropes during a hunt using artificial scent, suffering concussion, broken teeth, memory loss, and facial swelling. He and supporters condemned the decision as "pathetic" and "disgraceful," stating police had sufficient evidence. Wiltshire Police confirmed the case was shelved due to insufficient evidence, recorded as "undetected," and could be reopened if new evidence emerged.

Adam Gadahn, 36, a U.S. citizen known as Al-Qaeda's "American mouthpiece" and chief English-language propagandist, was killed in January 2015 during a U.S. counterterrorism operation. Born in 1978, he converted to Islam in 1995, moved to Pakistan in 1998, and joined Al-Qaeda, adopting the alias Abu Suheyb. He rose to prominence after 9/11, appearing in multiple videos threatening attacks on U.S. and Western targets, criticizing U.S. presidents, and urging Muslims to carry out lone-wolf attacks. A federal grand jury indicted him in 2006 for treason and material support to Al-Qaeda, listing him among the FBI's "most wanted terrorists." His final video was posted in September 2014. The White House stated he was not specifically targeted, and he was not one of Al-Qaeda's top leaders but a prominent member.

Five-year-old Mai Zizhuo, who has played basketball since age two and a half, is gaining viral fame in China for a video showcasing advanced skills, including scoring consecutively while dribbling two basketballs simultaneously without losing rhythm. His abilities have won him widespread admiration across China, with netizens expressing astonishment, questioning if the video uses special effects, and comparing their own skills unfavorably to his. The passage notes he follows Yao Ming, China's prominent NBA player, as a basketball icon.

Tom O'Carroll, a former leading member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), which campaigned to legalise child sex in the 1970s and 80s, has joined supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. PIE, formed in 1974, sought to legalise sex with children (including lowering the age of consent to ten with 'consent') and incest. Hacked Off, established after the phone-hacking scandal, campaigns for state regulation of the press via a statutory body as recommended by the Leveson inquiry. O'Carroll attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on 25 February to lobby MPs, which will embarrass the group due to his PIE history.

The Icebergs Club pool in Bondi was drained on Thursday to serve as a catwalk for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The fashion label Ten Pieces presented a capsule collection of ten unisex clothing pieces designed to be worn in 20 different ways. Models walked through the empty pool and along the break wall with the ocean as a backdrop. The event occurred on a warm 28°C day, with guests enjoying food and drinks from Icebergs and Santa Vittoria, and beachgoers watching from the road above.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan spent a family day at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom in Northern California with his wife Faryal and daughter Lamysa, posing with giraffes and sea lions and feeding a rare white tiger. Khan also announced he will fight Chris Algieri at welterweight on May 30, ending speculation about facing Kell Brook.

A Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, 16, whose name was placed on an Israeli memorial wall at Mount Herzl honoring fallen soldiers and terrorism victims, had his name removed following complaints from his family and the organization Almagor. Abu Khdeir was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, an act Almagor described as a "rogue attack" and not a terror victim incident. His father objected, stating he refused his son's name to be listed "between soldiers of the occupation." Almagor demanded removal, threatening to remove their own family members' names if not complied with. The National Insurance Institute of Israel agreed to remove his name, which had already been taken off their website, following the complaints.

A California-based YouTube user filmed his young son repeatedly trying to use their family cat as a pillow in the garden. The boy chased the cat, sat on it, but the cat moved away each time after a brief moment. This sequence occurred three times before the cat went indoors. Later, the boy and cat reconciled, with the boy feeding the cat treats.

Robert Kushner, a former drug dealer testifying in a Philadelphia police corruption trial, lost his varsity coaching position at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after his testimony about past marijuana sales and arrests. The school, which hired him in 2010 after a background check, was unaware of his 2007 arrest (later expunged) and 2011 arrest (for which he received probation). Kushner stated he never intended to deceive the school and considered his past "a bad phase" he had moved past. He continues coaching in a summer league, described as "excellent" with kids.

Six people were injured in an explosion at a chemical plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian province, China, which sparked a fire at an oil storage facility following an oil leak. Five of the six were hurt by broken glass and hospitalized; no toxic chemical spill was reported. Over 600 firefighters controlled the blaze. The plant produces paraxylene (PX), a carcinogenic chemical. It previously exploded in July 2013 with no casualties or toxic leaks. The plant was relocated from Xiamen in 2007 after protests over pollution concerns, as PX plants have sparked demonstrations in several Chinese cities.

Jack Grealish, Aston Villa's teenager, maintains a superstition of wearing his socks high above his shin pads, refusing to change despite referees' requests. He uses children's size shin pads and states he will keep this practice, as he hasn't been injured and hopes to avoid it. Grealish made his first Premier League start in a 3-3 draw against QPR, expressing satisfaction at the manager's faith but disappointment with the game's result.

Bobbi Kristina Brown has "global and irreversible brain damage" and remains unresponsive, according to her grandmother Cissy Houston, who stated she can live in this condition for a lifetime. She is no longer in a medically induced coma but does not respond to visitors or familiar voices, and her eyes do not follow people. She has a tracheostomy. While her father Bobby Brown claimed she is "awake" and "watching him," and her family attorney stated her condition has improved (she has left ICU and begun rehabilitation), the grandmother and a medical source confirmed she remains in the same neurological state for nearly three months, with the quality of her life unknown.

Russia leads Germany 2-0 in the Fed Cup tie after Svetlana Kuznetsova beat Julia Goerges in straight sets and Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to defeat Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6(4), 6-3. Pavlyuchenkova noted Lisicki's powerful play disrupted her rhythm, while both players struggled with serves (Pavlyuchenkova had 13 double faults, Lisicki 63 unforced errors). Russia needs one win from Sunday's matches to reach the final and win their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales are warned to brace for more floods and damage as another east coast low storm is predicted to hit from Thursday through Saturday, following last week's severe weather. Meteorologists indicate the system, similar to last week's, will bring heavy rain, particularly affecting coastal areas in the state's northeast and southeast Queensland, with peak impacts expected Thursday-Saturday. The State Emergency Service (SES) has over 4,000 jobs still to complete from last week's 24,196 requests, and SES spokeswoman Stephanie Wills emphasizes concern about hampered clean-up efforts and heightened flood risks in the Hunter region, which was severely impacted last week. Weatherzone meteorologist Kim Westcott notes this system will be less severe over Sydney than last week's event, with rain likely concentrated further north. The SES urges communities to prepare homes and families to prevent further devastation.

Nina Moric denied attempting suicide, stating she collapsed due to low blood pressure from a fall at home, requiring hospital treatment on Saturday night.
