She clarified she was recovering at home, had no suicide intent, and her boyfriend was in Naples at the time. Italian media reported she was found by her mother and claimed her boyfriend confirmed a suicide attempt, but Moric stated the reports were incorrect and she was "shocked" by the claims. She shared photos of bruising on her Instagram.

A YouGov poll for the Sunday Times shows Diana is the top name choice for a girl (12%), followed by Alice and Charlotte (9% each), while James is preferred for a boy (13%). A quarter of 2,200 polled people hope for a girl, with only 3% wanting a boy for Prince George. Social media users strongly support naming a girl Diana. Additionally, 68% of Brits approve William taking six weeks paternity leave.

A suicide bomber killed 17 and wounded 64, including an Afghan lawmaker, near protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, on Thursday. The Taliban denied responsibility, and the protesters were heading to a rally against the provincial governor.

Dani Alves has rejected Barcelona's final three-year contract offer, which required him to play 60% of matches, ending negotiations after seven years at the club where he won four Spanish titles and two Champions Leagues. He will leave the Nou Camp this summer. His agent stated negotiations are over and criticized Barcelona for not addressing his contract until April.

Pablo Osvaldo, on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton, has urged Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentine club. He believes they would be a good fit for Boca due to their playing style, would be loved by fans at La Bombonera, and has scored three goals in six games for Boca.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, sustained only a nose cut after a spectacular double somersault fall from his horse Merrion Square at Wincanton. The fall, which became an internet sensation viewed by hundreds of thousands, left him undeterred; he returned to mucking out stables the next morning and is eager to ride again. Ferguson described the fall as "just a blur," noted he could do nothing to avoid it, and joked about possibly pursuing gymnastics after racing.

James Haskell, London Wasps captain, posted an Instagram photo dressed as Iron Man to promote the Avengers: Age of Ultron movie, captioning it "Avengers movie is out so thought I would release the inner Iron Man." The passage details his rugby career: he joined Wasps in 2002, left for Stade Français in 2009, then played in Japan (Ricoh Black Rams) and New Zealand (Highlanders) before returning to Wasps for the 2012 season. Since returning, he has made over 100 appearances for Wasps and earned 57 England caps.

Wide-leg trousers are a key SS15 trend replacing skinny jeans, offering an effortless alternative. Styling tips include pairing with high heels to elongate legs, simple tops like knits for proportion, and choosing denim for ease. The trend, recalling 1970s flares, appears in collections from Gucci, Celine, and Stella McCartney, with Topshop's Miller jean as a high-street option. Shorter individuals should focus on high heels and high-waisted cuts for flattering proportions.

The University of Michigan will screen "American Sniper" despite a petition from over 200 students who objected to its Iraq War depiction, which they felt negatively portrayed the Middle East. The university reversed an initial cancellation, stating the decision conflicted with its commitment to free expression. A counter-petition prompted the reversal, and the university will also offer "Paddington" as an alternative film. The film stars Bradley Cooper, who was Oscar-nominated for portraying Navy SEAL Chris Kyle, who was killed in 2013.

Two French male tourists, aged 18 and 24 from Cockburn Central, allegedly ignited an aerosol spray with a lighter on Rottnest Island, Western Australia, on April 3, causing a large flame to contact a quokka. The quokka survived but was singed. The men were evicted from the island, charged with animal cruelty, and will appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. Detectives seized video evidence and questioned them.

A 102-year-old former dancer, Alice Barker, who performed in 1930s-1940s New York nightspots like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar alongside Bill "Bojangles" Robinson and Frank Sinatra, had never seen footage of herself dancing. Her motion pictures, photographs, and memorabilia had been lost. Filmmakers from jazz-on-film.com and volunteers compiled early "soundies" (music videos) and showed them to her at her nursing home, where she was delighted.

A study by OSV reveals that car washing at home is declining in Britain, with 31% of men and 75% of women never washing their own car. Only 12% of those who wash cars do so regularly. Reasons include more Sunday shop openings, live football, the rise of car washes, and larger vehicles like 4x4s. During Easter, 15 million cars were washed by owners, though one in four did it merely to leave the house. Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield have the highest owner washing rates; Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh the lowest. Audi, Toyota, and BMW owners wash most often; Range Rover, Peugeot, and Mercedes owners least often. An OSV spokesman noted the decline from a former Sunday tradition due to busier schedules, bigger cars, and readily available car washes.

Martin Skrtel praises Steven Gerrard as "one of the best players in the world" and states Gerrard is synonymous with Liverpool, acknowledging his impact since Skrtel joined in 2008. Gerrard is set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, aiming to reach the final on his birthday (May 30) before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel admits Liverpool will be different without Gerrard but believes the club has players capable of replacing him with proper support. Both Gerrard and Skrtel return from three-match bans for the Villa match.

At age 75, Jack Nicklaus made his first hole-in-one at Augusta National during the Masters Par-3 contest, hitting the 130-yard fourth hole. This contributed to a record-tying five hole-in-ones that day. Nicklaus played alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. Camilo Villegas also recorded two aces but lost the contest to Kevin Streelman in a playoff.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas Wednesday night as storms brought reports of twisters, including one near Goddard (6 miles northwest, less than 17 miles west of Wichita) that moved northeast. CNN severe weather expert Chad Myers warned nighttime tornadoes are the most deadly. Tornado reports also came from southwestern Kansas near Aetna. In Missouri, a possible tornado touched down in Potosi (70 miles from St. Louis), causing wind damage, flooding, and fallen trees. Baseball-sized hail was reported in Farmington. The National Weather Service forecast more storms across the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

Oklahoma reserve deputy Robert Bates pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris during an arrest, claiming he intended to use a taser but accidentally fired a gun. Bates was granted permission to vacation in the Bahamas during the case, which Harris's family condemned as insensitive. A preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo on July 11. He unveiled a new tiger face tattoo on his stomach, captioned "if you see the tiger, it's too late. you're food." McGregor also has a gorilla eating a heart tattoo on his chest. He claims Aldo lacks motivation to defend his eighth title defense, stating Aldo "doesn't want to be near me" and "doesn't want the belt in his presence." This follows an incident in Dublin where McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt during a promotional tour.

australian prime minister tony abbott skolled a schooner of beer in six seconds at an australian rules function, drawing criticism from anti-drinking campaigners and professor julie robert who called it "problematic" for glorifying binge drinking and associating masculinity with excessive alcohol consumption. robert argued it promotes drinking as a competitive act rather than socialising. health minister sussan ley defended abbott, stating "nothing wrong" with his actions. critics urged abbott to set an example that being a "true blue aussie bloke" does not require heavy drinking.

Indiana's Scott County has seen a significant HIV increase to 120 confirmed cases and 10 preliminary cases, up from 106 the previous week, linked to intravenous drug use involving the painkiller Opana. A 30-day needle exchange program approved by Governor Mike Pence is nearing its end on April 25, with health officials seeking an extension amid the outbreak. Governor Pence opposes needle exchanges as anti-drug policy, while legislation to expand such programs to high-risk counties faces uncertainty. Federal funding bans for needle exchanges and sustainability concerns are also noted.

An Arsenal fan made his girlfriend, Saskia, take a school-style football knowledge test about the club. She scored 87% (43.5 out of 50), earning an 'A' grade. The test included multiple choice, tables, and essay questions covering team trivia, player positions, and match details. Saskia struggled with some answers, such as confusing player positions and missing the 11th starting squad member. Her creative responses, like calling Alexis Sanchez "buff" and Hazard a "p***k," earned extra points. The boyfriend graded her, provided corrections in capitals, and drew angry faces for errors. He rewarded her score by not ending their relationship. Twitter reactions were mixed: many praised the boyfriend as a "legend" and Saskia as "proper gf material," while others felt he took things too far.

Carlos Toro, 66, a former Medellin cartel member who worked as a DEA undercover informant for 27 years after fleeing Colombia in the 1980s, faces deportation despite his service. He provided critical information leading to the prosecution of figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega, aiding global DEA operations. The DEA promised him U.S. citizenship in exchange for his work, but he has not received it. After retiring due to declining health and losing his temporary visa, he is now in the U.S. illegally. The DEA refused to assist him with citizenship after he went public with his plight. Toro fears immediate death if deported to Colombia and states the U.S. government has "sentenced me to death." He remains in limbo, unable to obtain a green card or passport, collect Social Security, or secure his promised citizenship.

A 14-year-old girl set herself on fire after allegedly being gang-raped by five men from her village in Kosi Kalan, Uttar Pradesh's Mathura district, while she went outside to relieve herself. Her family reportedly told her to keep quiet about the attack. She is now critically injured with 70% burns at Delhi's Safdarjung Hospital. The accused men have been arrested.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal confirms Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw are not fit enough to play in the Sunday derby against Manchester City. Van Gaal states van Persie was initially deemed fit but has ruled him out, and also rules out Shaw. Van Gaal emphasizes the team's focus on winning to secure third place in the league table, avoiding Champions League qualifying, and states he is not motivated by revenge for a previous 1-0 away defeat to City. He acknowledges City's challenge but expresses desire for victory as a "big step up the table."

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested high ticket prices by leaving seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Premier League match at Emirates Stadium. They cited the £5.14 billion TV rights deal and ticket prices starting at £64 (among the highest in the league) as reasons for the protest, displaying banners reading "£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket" and "Football without fans is nothing." Organizers from groups like Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement and Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly called prices "extortionate," stating football has "sold its soul" and demanding tangible price reductions for working-class fans.

A newborn baby named Star Reader was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life-threatening liver condition causing jaundice and blocked bile ducts, shortly after birth in Barnsley, West Yorkshire. After an unsuccessful surgery to unblock bile ducts, a liver transplant was required. Neither parent was a suitable match, so her maternal aunt and mother's twin sister, Shanell Reader, donated part of her liver. Star underwent the transplant in November, spent six weeks in hospital, and has since made a good recovery with weekly blood tests and lifelong anti-rejection medication. Her mother expressed deep gratitude, stating the transplant gave Star a chance at a normal life.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake participated in Audi's football challenge against teammates Loic Remy and Willian. In the first challenge (shooting balls into a car boot), Hazard and Ake won 5-3. In the second challenge (sinking balls into a convertible Audi), they won 6-0 overall. In the final challenge (shooting through a convertible's top), Remy and Willian won. Willian accidentally smashed a car's wing mirror during the final challenge, causing damage.

Robert Dellinger, a 54-year-old former Fortune 500 executive from New Hampshire, caused a December 2013 highway crash in Lebanon that killed Amanda Murphy (24, eight months pregnant) and her fiancé Jason Timmons (29), along with Murphy's unborn baby. Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault for the fetus's death, facing 12 to 24 years in prison. During sentencing, he stated he was not suicidal, contradicting prosecutors' claims he told investigators he was attempting suicide. His defense cited Ambien withdrawal, psychiatric drug overdose, and multiple sclerosis symptoms, while his wife described him as "a man of ethics, integrity and friendship." The couple, who met while working at a home for the elderly, were killed instantly when his truck crossed a median at over 100mph, shearing the top off their SUV.

Lacey Spears of Scottsville, Kentucky, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for the second-degree murder of her five-year-old son Garnett-Paul Spears, whom she poisoned with salt via his feeding tube while continuing to blog about his condition. She showed no emotion during sentencing, which spared her the maximum 25 years to life. The boy's father, Chris Hill, expressed on Facebook his hope she would die in prison, calling her a "crazy a** woman" and criticizing her lack of emotion. The judge stated Spears suffers from mental illness and described the crime as "unfathomable in its cruelty." Prosecutors argued Spears used her son's medical issues for attention, causing his "short and tormented life" through repeated hospitalizations and the poisoning.

Two new influenza strains (H3N2 and B/Phuket) caused increased deaths in Europe and the US due to a previous vaccine mismatch. Australia's vaccine has been updated to include protection against these strains, but stock arrival is delayed by one month. High-risk groups (young, elderly, most Indigenous Australians) will receive free flu shots from April 20. Experts state the updated vaccine is a better global match and worth the delay, urging everyone to get vaccinated to protect high-risk individuals.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb face criticism over a National Geographic magazine description calling it "all the historical character of an office lobby" and budget cuts threatening site management, coinciding with the 150th anniversary of Lincoln's assassination. Illinois Governor Bruce Rauner proposed eliminating the state historic preservation agency that manages the tomb, potentially rolling it into another department. The tomb recently underwent over $2.5 million in renovations, including $730,000 for interior lighting upgrades, and is described as being in "excellent physical condition." Despite the negative critique, officials and some visitors dispute the portrayal, calling the site "gorgeous" and "impressive," while staff reductions and reduced hours follow a $1.1 million funding cut.

The passage describes the resurgence of 1990s and 2000s fashion trends, listing nine "worst offenders" that should be left in the past, including bucket hats, camouflage print, double denim, Ugg boots, Daisy Dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outerwear, and harem trousers, with examples of celebrities who popularized or revived each trend.

Four rainbows over New York after heavy rain, China banning exotic dancers at wakes, RDJ's frustration during a UK interview, the #KylieJennerChallenge lip plumping trend, a 102-year-old's bomb-themed prom-posal rejected by a school, Ewan McGregor cast as Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast,' Johnny Depp unrecognizable in 'Black Mass' trailer, and pregnancy announcements referencing 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air' and a military dad photobomb.

Serena Williams reached her 700th career victory at the Miami Open by defeating Sabine Lisicki 7-6, 1-6, 6-3 in the quarter-finals, earning a celebratory cake. Her semi-final hopes against sister Venus Williams were ended when Venus lost to Carla Suarez Navarro. Williams will face Simona Halep in the semi-finals after Halep defeated Sloane Stephens. The Miami Open has featured cake celebrations for both Williams' 700th win and Andy Murray's 500th victory.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani activist and cafe owner in Karachi, was shot dead by two gunmen at point-blank range after closing her second-floor cafe, T2F, which hosted discussions on technology, human rights, women's entrepreneurship, and sensitive topics like Balochistan. She had recently led a discussion on Balochistan, a topic authorities sought to silence, and had received prior death threats for addressing it. Her killing, which also wounded her mother, shocked Pakistan as she was a prominent figure advocating for humanism, tolerance, and free speech. Police found no claims of responsibility or motive, but her work focused on creating space for dialogue on issues deemed dangerous in mainstream Pakistani discourse. She was described by a close friend as "the bravest woman in the world" and a symbol of progressive values.

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu refugee who fled West Pakistan during India's 1947 partition, lives in abject poverty in Indian Kashmir as a second-class citizen denied property ownership, voting rights, or state government employment. Around 100,000 West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs), mostly Hindus from Punjab now in Pakistan, have been trapped in refugee status for 70 years due to Kashmir's dispute with Pakistan and fears of upsetting the region's demographic balance. Denied citizenship rights under pre-independence law, three generations remain impoverished, unable to access state-run education or jobs. The recent political success of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist BJP party in Kashmir's state elections has sparked hope for WPRs to gain full rights, with the BJP pledged to champion their cause. Activists warn the community will take action if hopes are unfulfilled.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is considering a potential move to Chelsea, who have reportedly made a £4 million offer. Muto, 22, stated he needs to think carefully about joining a club where he can play regularly and develop his potential. FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane confirmed Chelsea's offer. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho acknowledged knowing about Muto but declined to comment on the transfer, citing professionalism. Real Zaragoza boss Ranko Popovic praised Muto's intelligence, speed, and potential.

Australia has dropped its policy of excluding overseas rugby players, a move praised as sensible while England is criticized for maintaining restrictions. The passage argues England's coach Stuart Lancaster should select the best players regardless of their club location, citing examples like Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell (performing well for Toulon), Steffon Armitage (improved after moving to France), and Nick Abendanon. It states players often become better overseas, as seen with Jonny Wilkinson, and that England's policy undermines World Cup success. The author insists selecting the strongest team, including overseas-based players, is essential for England's home World Cup campaign and that clubs benefit from a winning national team. The text contrasts Australia's approach with England's, noting Toulon's success with international players like Bryan Habana and Leigh Halfpenny.

Firechat, a messaging app downloaded over five million times, enables chatting without internet or mobile signals by using Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) or similar Android features to create wireless mesh networks. Messages travel between nearby devices (up to 30 feet) via nodes, but original range is limited to about 200 feet. Greenstone, an egg-shaped device developed by Open Garden, acts as a beacon to extend this range, currently working at 20 feet with a one-year battery and capacity to store 1,000 messages. It aims to strengthen off-grid communication for communities, events, or areas with no connectivity, though it remains under development.

Burlesque performer Lillian Bustle from New Jersey uses her TED talk to reframe the word 'fat' as a neutral, body-positive self-description, similar to 'short' or 'wife', arguing it should not equate to 'ugly'. She cites a 66% rise in workplace size discrimination over 30 years and a study showing girls aged 11-17 often wish to be thinner. Bustle promotes body diversity through burlesque performances, which she states help audiences accept different body types, as studies show increased exposure leads to greater tolerance and preference for diverse bodies. Starting burlesque in 2012 after being inspired by the art form, she found it empowering. Her TED talk, posted on YouTube three weeks prior to the passage, garnered nearly 38,000 views with mostly positive feedback, including a letter from a teenage girl who said it helped her and her sister reevaluate body image, leading Bustle to conclude "we... are winning" in the body-positive movement.

Theo Walcott has been frequently on the bench for Arsenal this season, named on the substitutes' bench for 17 of 33 Premier League games. He was pictured in a Lanvin photoshoot with teammates Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, Mesut Ozil, and model Olga Sherer. Walcott came on for the last six minutes in Arsenal's 0-0 draw with Chelsea and has not started since March 14. He will be part of the squad for the FA Cup final against Aston Villa on May 30.

An auction of 417 props and puppets created by legendary makeup effects artist Rick Baker, valued at an estimated $746,100, will be held on May 29 at Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on PropStore.com. The collection includes items from over 50 productions spanning Baker's 30-year career, such as Men in Black, Batman Forever, How the Grinch Stole Christmas, and Gremlins 2. Specific items mentioned include Alien Edgar Bug ($40,000 estimated), The Grinch costume ($8,000), and others from films like Batman & Robin, Mighty Joe Young, and Michael Jackson's Moonwalker. PropStore describes it as a "no reserve live auction" of over 400 items.

A seven-year-old British boy, Carwyn Scott-Howell from Wales, died after falling 164ft in dense woodland in the French Alps while skiing with his family. Separated from his mother during a last run, he reportedly entered the woods to reach the resort he saw through the trees, removing his skis to walk. Police found his body via footprints in the snow, with sliding marks indicating he slid down inclines. His family described him as "daring, outgoing, and determined" with a "handsome smile," stating his death has left a "vast void in their hearts," and noted he was a "very competent skier" who loved the mountains and farming.

Fifteen-year-old Laura Scurr from Whitley Bay developed anorexia after feeling pressured to be "size zero" following bullying about her weight. She restricted her intake to around 100 calories daily (often just one piece of fruit), hid food from her parents, and lied about eating. Her condition worsened, causing her heart rate to slow dangerously, leading to collapse and a week on a heart monitor at North Tyneside General Hospital. Laura described obsessive behaviors like hiding food and eating mashed potato to conceal uneaten portions. After hospitalization, she received support from eating disorder teams and CAMHS, recovering fully. She now competes in Miss Teen GB, a contest avoiding "size zero" stereotypes. The passage notes anorexia nervosa is a serious mental health condition often involving food restriction, vomiting, or excessive exercise, commonly affecting women aged 16-17, with an estimated 72,500 UK sufferers having anorexia.

Liverpool supporters told Raheem Sterling they expect him to remain at the club during the unveiling of the new home kit at Anfield. New Balance signed a record-breaking £300 million four-year kit deal to replace Warrior as Liverpool's supplier. Despite Sterling recently rejecting a £100,000-a-week contract offer and being linked with Arsenal, Liverpool are adamant he will not leave this summer. The kit features a tribute to the Hillsborough disaster (number 96) and the new balance logo. Players also discussed the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa.

The largest single high-definition map of dark matter, covering 0.4% of the sky, has been created by University of Manchester researchers using data from the Dark Energy Survey (DES). This map, produced by measuring the shapes of 130 million galaxies via gravitational lensing, reveals clumps of dark matter (red = more, blue = less) and shows how galaxies form along dark matter filaments. It is the first in a series aiming to map 12.5% of the sky over five years, eventually enabling a 3D view of dark matter. The DES uses the Dark Energy Camera on the Victor M. Blanco telescope in Chile, with the goal of studying dark matter's role in galaxy formation and probing dark energy, which causes the universe's accelerated expansion. Dark matter makes up approximately 80-85% of the universe's matter and is detectable only through its gravitational effects.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign 21-year-old PSV Eindhoven winger Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal keen to make him his first summer signing. Van Gaal is familiar with Depay from Holland's 2014 World Cup campaign. Depay, who has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season, helped PSV win the Dutch championship. Premier League rivals Tottenham had previously offered £15 million last summer, but PSV technical director Marcel Brands stated Depay is now worth more, with Manchester United in pole position amid interest from Paris-Saint Germain and another major European club.

chelsea defeated manchester city's young side 3-1 in the youth cup final, with tammy abraham scoring twice (his 35th and 36th goals of the season) and dominic solanke adding a late goal to secure the victory.

Marco Rubio states people are born with a sexual preference but believes marriage should be defined as between one man and one woman, with states deciding on same-sex marriage through legislation rather than courts or constitutional rights. He would attend a same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer he cares for, even if he disagreed with the decision, emphasizing respect for loved ones despite personal disagreement.

Pablo Mandado (27, Spanish) and Ilze Zebolde (31, Latvian) quit restaurant jobs in Manchester to cycle around the world with no fixed plans or agenda, aiming to "discover different parts of this planet a pedal at a time." After 356 days, they've cycled nearly 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) through 16 countries, living on less than €3 per day total (€1.00 per km). They rely on free accommodation (camping, Couchsurfing, Warmshowers), minimal food expenses (€2.74 per person daily), and pedal power for transport. They crossed from Europe into Asia at the Greece-Turkey border, are now in Armenia, and plan to continue cycling through Asia and eventually the Americas.

A Texas couple married in 2012 sued Premiere Photos owner James Evans after their photo booth prints allegedly included the racial slur "poor n ***** party." The couple, unidentified, learned of the slur months later from the bride's sister, who withheld the information to avoid spoiling the wedding. Attorney Cathy Hale filed the lawsuit under the Texas deceptive trade practices act, alleging negligence and breach of contract, as Evans allegedly refused to apologize and told them to "sue" him. The couple seeks an apology, not monetary damages, and mediation is scheduled before a July trial.

Mike Brown, England full-back, is adopting a cautious approach to recovery after a recent concussion, unsure of his return date following his withdrawal from Harlequins' match against Saracens. He pulled out of the England-Ireland Six Nations clash due to concussion symptoms, crediting rugby's online awareness modules for helping him recognize the need to prioritize health over playing. Brown cited concerns about long-term risks, referencing Johnny Sexton's 12-week absence and George North being advised not to play again this season after four concussions. Brown emphasized the importance of not rushing recovery to avoid extended absences.

Smartphone and internet use may contribute to a decline in sexual frequency among British heterosexual couples, with research cited in Professor David Spiegelhalter's book showing a drop from five times monthly in 1990 to four times in 2000 and currently three times monthly. Spiegelhalter attributes this to blurred boundaries between work, home, and personal life due to constant connectivity, reducing quiet time for intimacy, as noted by researcher Catherine Mercer who states sex falls down priority lists amid competing demands like late-night work emails.

Tibetan Mastiffs, once valued at up to £1.2 million each as status symbols, have dramatically declined in popularity in China. Their market collapse is partly blamed on the government's anti-corruption crackdown, which ended the practice of giving them as bribes to officials, and recent bans on owning dogs over 50kg in cities like Beijing and Shanghai. Breeders cross-bred the dogs for profit, leading to a glut of poor-quality specimens that cannot be sold. As a result, many are now being sent to slaughterhouses for cheap hotpots, with reports of dogs found in cramped cages without food or water, destined for meat and leather. Urbanization has also reduced their suitability as city pets.

A survey of 600 women in the Paris area found that every woman reported experiencing sexual harassment on public transport, with half first assaulted before age 18. Harassment ranged from insults and unwanted comments to sexual assault or rape, leading 60% of women to fear attacks on transport (compared to 30% of men). The report states such abuse, often unreported, limits women's freedom by forcing them to alter daily routines. Presented to the French women's rights ministry, the findings prompted calls for a campaign to address sexist behavior, with officials emphasizing that harassment is punishable by law and urging education for both women and aggressors.

Direct Line ran a #EverydayFix competition where Makerversity groups designed products to solve common daily problems identified in a survey of 2,000 people. The top problem was not being able to sleep (46%), leading to the "Snooze" alarm clock that silences phone notifications. The shortlisted products were the "Forget Me Lock" (a key-mounted device showing door status via color), and "Nipper" (a portable phone charger using household batteries). The winner, chosen via Twitter votes with #everydayfix, will be funded through Kickstarter.

Police and Crime Commissioner Vera Baird faces a Ministry of Justice investigation after awarding over £500,000 in public funds to Victims First Northumbria, a charity she directs, alongside Chief Constable Sue Sim who is also a director of the charity. Critics, including Labour's Keith Vaz, accuse the arrangement of being an inappropriate conflict of interest and a "soap opera." Baird states all Ministry of Justice procedures were followed, while the Ministry of Justice confirmed it will investigate potential conflict of interest rules breaches.

Three people received prison sentences and two await sentencing for assaulting Greg Valecce, a 53-year-old unemployed man, in Philadelphia. Corry "Corey" Campbell, 21, was the ringleader of the group dubbed "tattoo terrorists," who beat Valecce, tied him to a chair for three days, and tattooed offensive designs on him after believing he injured Campbell's cat. Valecce suffered multiple injuries, including broken bones. Campbell received 20 years, Carl Halin 20 years, and Sandra Ng 23 months; David Harrison and Jennifer Pratt await sentencing.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign 21-year-old PSV Eindhoven winger Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal keen to make him his first summer signing. Van Gaal knows Depay from the 2014 World Cup, where Holland finished third. PSV rejected Tottenham's £15m bid from last summer, with technical director Marcel Brands stating Depay is now worth more and that United, Paris-Saint Germain, and a third major club are in talks with "bigger amounts of money." Depay has scored 20 goals in 26 Eredivisie games this season, including a stunning free kick in PSV's 4-1 victory over Heerenveen that secured their first Dutch championship in seven years. He is compared to Arjen Robben and Cristiano Ronaldo by scouts and teammates, with PSV manager Phillip Cocu noting Depay's potential.

chelsea defeated manchester city 3-1 in the youth cup final, with tammy abraham scoring twice and dominic solanke adding a third goal late in the match. the victory gave chelsea a commanding lead heading back to west london.

Marco Rubio claims people are born with a sexual preference but believes marriage should be defined as between one man and one woman, stating same-sex marriage is not a constitutional right. He insists states should regulate marriage through legislation and political debate, not courts, and would attend a same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer even if he disagreed with the decision. As a Catholic, he also stated he would not stop loving someone who was divorced. Rubio announced his presidential run and noted fundraising commitments exceeding $47 million.

Pablo Mandado (27, Spanish) and Ilze Zebolde (31, Latvian) quit restaurant jobs in Manchester to cycle around the world with no plans or agenda, aiming to "discover different parts of this planet a pedal at a time." After 356 days, they've cycled nearly 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) through 16 countries, living on less than 3 euros per person daily (10 euro cents per kilometer). They rely on free accommodation (camping 161 nights, Couchsurfing 66 nights, WarmShowers 44 nights), with food (2.74 euros per person daily) as their main expense, sourced from pasta, bread, rice, seasonal produce, free meals, and occasional dumpster diving. They traveled from London through France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia, crossing into Asia at the Greece-Turkey border. They plan to continue cycling through Asia and eventually the American continent, remaining on the road for years.

Mike Brown, England's full-back, is taking a cautious approach to recovering from a concussion, admitting he is unsure when he will return after withdrawing from Harlequins' match against Saracens. He experienced a headache post-France game and avoided rushing back to prevent extended absence like Johnny Sexton. George North, after suffering four quick concussions, has been advised by medics not to play again this season. Brown highlighted the importance of concussion awareness from World Rugby online modules, which helped him recognize symptoms and withdraw from the Ireland match, stressing the need to prioritize health over playing.

Smartphone and internet use may cause a decline in sexual frequency among couples, with British heterosexual couples now having sex three times monthly compared to four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. Professor David Spiegelhalter attributes this to eroded boundaries between home, work, and public life, leading to busier schedules and less focused time with partners due to constant connectivity like checking emails.

Tibetan mastiffs, once valued up to £1.2 million each as status symbols in China, are now being sent to slaughterhouses for cheap hotpots due to declining popularity. This decline is primarily blamed on the government's anti-corruption crackdown, which ended the practice of wealthy businessmen giving mastiffs as gifts to officials, and recent bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in major cities. Unscrupulous breeding led to a glut of poor-quality dogs, and urbanization has made people realize the breed is unsuitable for city living. Rescuers found 20 mastiffs crammed in cages, many dead or suffering, en route to slaughterhouses.

Direct Line ran a #everydayfix competition based on a survey of 2,000 people identifying top everyday emergencies, with not being able to sleep (46%) as the most common. Shortlisted products include Instruments' 'Snooze' alarm clock that silences phone notifications for better sleep, Onn Studio's 'Forget Me Lock' that attaches to keys and changes color (green=open, red=locked) to confirm door status, and Impulse's 'Nipper' phone charger using household batteries for emergency charging. The winner will be funded via Kickstarter after Twitter voting with the #everydayfix hashtag.

The 2009 convention featured over 6000 guests and musical performers, including Patrick Stewart, William Shatner, Leonard Nimoy, Terry Gilliam, Bruce Boxleitner, James Marsters, and Mary McDonnell.
